questions.text: 1. A 60-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling is reducible in the neck and increases in size on coughing and performing the Valsalva maneuver. The given presentation is due to an enlarged diverticulum in ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a laryngocele, and it occurs due to the abnormal distention of the saccule present in the ventricle of the larynx (sinus of the larynx).

The ventricle/Sinus of the larynx is a deep, elliptical space between the vestibular and vocal folds. The saccule is a diverticulum of the mucous membrane, which starts from the anterior part of the ventricular cavity and extends upwards between the vestibular folds and the lamina of the thyroid. When abnormally enlarged and distended, the saccule may form a laryngocele—an air-containing sac that may present in the neck.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck, which increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva manoeuvre. Laryngocele in adults may be associated with carcinoma. 

A CT scan helps in assessing the extent of the lesion.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialisation, and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.







Other options:

Option A: The vestibule is the upper portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the laryngeal inlet and the vestibular folds. It is related to the posterior surface of the epiglottis anteriorly, the aryepiglottic folds laterally, and the anterior surface of the arytenoids posteriorly. 

Option C: The infraglottic larynx (subglottic space) is the lower portion of the laryngeal cavity, in between the vocal folds and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. Histologically, it is the transition zone between the stratified squamous epithelium of the vocal cords and the respiratory epithelium of the trachea.

Option D: Rima glottidis (glottis) is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity, measuring 24 mm in men and 16 mm in women anteroposteriorly. It is present between the two vocal cords. The anterior two-thirds of the glottis, known as the phonatory glottis, is formed by the membranous cords, while the posterior one-third, known as the respiratory glottis, is formed by the vocal processes of the arytenoids. 

The image given below shows the glottis.

questions.text: 2. A 45-year-old male with abdominal pain and jaundice for the last 2 months is diagnosed to be positive for Hepatitis B. Which of the following indicates the correct correlation between HBsAg titre and disease status?

choices.text: Mild chronic hepatitis > Severe chronic hepatitis
Resolved hepatitis B > Acute hepatitis B

questions.solution:
The HBsAg titre is higher in a patient with mild chronic hepatitis than in a patient with severe chronic hepatitis.

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection may present as acute or chronic hepatitis, depending on the immune response of the host. Liver damage primarily occurs due to immune-mediated destruction of infected hepatocytes rather than direct viral cytotoxicity.

HBsAg is the earliest serological marker of HBV infection and indicates the presence of active viral replication. Its titre correlates inversely with the degree of hepatocyte injury, being higher in mild chronic hepatitis and lower in severe or fulminant cases due to extensive hepatocyte loss.

Other options:

Option A: Immunocompromised hosts have higher HBsAg titres than immunocompetent hosts because their reduced immune activity allows greater viral replication and less hepatocyte destruction.

Option C: HBsAg titres are very low in acute fulminant hepatitis due to massive hepatocyte necrosis, which leads to decreased antigen production when compared to chronic hepatitis.

Option D: In resolved hepatitis B, HBsAg becomes negative and anti-HBs antibody appears, whereas in acute hepatitis B, HBsAg remains positive with no detectable anti-HBs.

questions.text: 3. A 20-year-old bodybuilder started a diet of raw eggs as a source of protein, following which he developed dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscular pains. On investigation, he was diagnosed with a vitamin deficiency. Which of the following enzymes does not require this vitamin as a coenzyme?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of features like dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, and muscle pain developing in an individual on a raw egg diet is suggestive of biotin deficiency, and carbamoyl phosphate synthetase is the enzyme that is not dependent on biotin.

A protein called avidin is present in the egg white, which binds to biotin in the diet, making biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption. Avidin is heat labile, and boiling of the egg neutralizes its inhibitory activity. One molecule of avidin can bind with four molecules of biotin.

Biotin deficiency is rare, except in individuals on prolonged total parenteral nutrition and those consuming raw eggs. Individuals with a biotin deficiency may develop features such as dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia, and hallucinations. Treatment is the administration of an injection of 100–300 mg biotin.

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for several carboxylase enzymes:

* Acetyl-CoA carboxylase

* This enzyme adds CO2 to acetyl CoA, forming malonyl CoA.

* It is the rate-limiting reaction in the biosynthesis of fatty acids

* Pyruvate carboxylase

* Pyruvate + CO2 +ATP → Oxaloacetate +ADP + Pi

* It provides oxaloacetate, which is the catalyst for the TCA cycle and is an important enzyme in gluconeogenesis.

* Propionyl CoA carboxylase

* Propionyl CoA +CO2 + ATP → Methyl malonyl CoA + ADP + Pi

* Methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase

Biotin also plays a role in the regulation of the cell cycle.

Biotin-independent reactions:

* Urea and pyrimidine synthesis, with carbamoyl phosphate synthetase as the stepping stone

* Addition of CO2 to form C6 in the purine ring

* Conversion of pyruvate to malate by malic enzyme

questions.text: 4. A filamentous bacterium shows positive Gram staining and hyphae-like branching on microscopy. What is the sequence of the acid-fast staining technique used to identify the same organism?

choices.text: Carbolfuchsin → heat → 4% sulfuric acid → methylene blue
Methylene blue → heat → 4% sulfuric acid → carbolfuchsin
Crystal violet → Iodine solution → ethanol → carbolfuchsin
Carbolfuchsin → Iodine solution → ethanol → crystal violet

questions.solution:
The gram-positive, filamentous bacterium, with a hyphae-like branching is Nocardia. The sequence for acid-fast staining for Nocardia is Carbolfuchsin → heat → 4% sulfuric acid → methylene blue.

Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive hyphae-like branching. They are gram-positive, catalase-positive, and produce urease. They are weakly acid fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin (routine acid-fast stain) and retain when decolorized with 1-4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. This means that once the bacterium is stained, it cannot be decolorized using acids routinely used in the process. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid fast. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Neelsen are as follows:

* The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.

* It is then decolorized with 20% sulfuric acid. Later, methylene blue is used for counterstaining.

* The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

Note: Crystal violet → Iodine solution → ethanol → carbolfuchsin (Option C) is the sequence followed for Gram stain.

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.

questions.text: 5. A 50-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of heaviness in the lower abdomen and flatulence for the past few months, associated with painless bleeding per rectum that is bright red. On examination, there is tenderness in the left iliac fossa, which radiates to the back. Colonoscopy was performed, and the image is as follows. Which of the following systems is used to stage this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario indicates diverticular disease of the colon, and Hinchey’s classification is used to stage diverticulitis. 

Diverticula are hollow outpouches of mucosa that herniate through the circular muscle at the points where blood vessels penetrate the bowel wall. This occurs due to a combination of altered collagen structure with ageing, disordered motility, and increased intraluminal pressure, especially in the narrow sigmoid colon. 

It commonly occurs in people who consume a low-fibre diet as it increases the transit time, reduces the stool weight, and reduces the bulkiness of stool, which in turn raises the intraluminal pressure and causes muscle hypertrophy. This progresses to colonic narrowing and segmentation, resulting in pulsion diverticula of only mucosa adjacent to the taenia in the antimesenteric region. It's common in the sigmoid colon. However, these are false diverticula as there is no muscularis layer in the diverticulum. 

Other risk factors associated with this disease are a non-vegetarian diet, NSAIDs intake, smoking, alcohol consumption, long-standing constipation, laxative abuse, etc. The majority of diverticulosis remain asymptomatic with no complications. Some develop complications like diverticulitis, abscess, peritonitis, intestinal obstruction, haemorrhage, and fistula formation.

Hinchey’s system is used to stage complicated diverticulitis as follows: 

* Grade I: Mesenteric/pericolic abscess 

* Grade II: Pelvic abscess

* Grade III: Purulent peritonitis 

* Grade IV Faecal peritonitis

Clinical features include abdominal distention, lower abdominal pain, left iliac fossa tenderness with radiation to the back, passage of frank, bright red blood per rectum, and pneumaturia (colovesical fistula). Occasionally, a mass is palpable. Early stages are usually asymptomatic. Symptoms depend on the complication they develop. 

Investigations include a CT scan, which is useful in identifying bowel wall thickening, abscess formation, and extraluminal disease. Colonoscopy demonstrates the neck of diverticula within the lumen of the bowel. Management includes a high fibre diet, antispasmodics to relieve the pain, intravenous antibiotics, bowel rest, operative procedures like drainage of abscess, Hartman’s procedure, and primary anastomosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Montreal classification for Inflammatory Bowel Disease is used to classify the severity of Crohn’s disease and Ulcerative Colitis. 

Option C: Dukes’ staging system is used for colorectal cancer. 

Option D: The Amsterdam criteria are a set of guidelines used to identify families who may have Lynch syndrome.

questions.text: 6. A surgeon performing a modified radical neck dissection on a patient decides to preserve only the spinal accessory nerve. What type of MRND being performed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Type 1 MRND involves the preservation of the spinal accessory nerve.

Modified radical neck dissection (MRND): It is similar to radical neck dissection but with the preservation of one or more of the following structures:

* Spinal accessory nerve

* Internal jugular vein

questions.text:
7. What is the most likely rationale for adding dexamethasone before or with the first dose of antibiotics in H. influenzae meningitis?

SIADH - Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion

CSF - Cerebrospinal fluid

choices.text: Reduces hearing loss and neurologic sequelae
Enhances penetration of antibiotics into the CSF

questions.solution:
Dexamethasone is used in H. influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis primarily to reduce the risk of sensorineural hearing loss and other neurological sequelae.

When antibiotics are administered, they rapidly lyse the bacteria, releasing large amounts of inflammatory cell wall components (e.g., lipooligosaccharides in Hib). This triggers a host of inflammatory responses in the subarachnoid space, causing damage to the cochlea and neural tissue.

Administering dexamethasone before or with the first dose of antibiotics blunts this inflammatory reaction by inhibiting cytokine production (especially TNF-α, IL-1, and IL-6), thus protecting the auditory pathway and brain tissue.

For uncomplicated cases of H. influenzae meningitis, intravenous antimicrobial therapy should be administered for 7 to 14 days. Both ceftriaxone and ampicillin can penetrate the blood-brain barrier during acute inflammation, reaching concentrations sufficient for treatment. Dexamethasone is used as adjunctive therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Dexamethasone do not reliably reduce mortality in bacterial meningitis. The primary benefit is in reducing complications, not death rates.

Option B: SIADH is a complication of meningitis due to hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction, which is not prevented by dexamethasone. Management involves fluid restriction and monitoring, not corticosteroid therapy.

Option D: Dexamethasone does not help antibiotics reach higher concentrations in CSF rather it reduces CSF penetration of some antibiotics (like Vancomycin) by decreasing meningeal inflammation.

questions.text: 8. A patient presents with an antalgic gait, which had a chronic course. On examination, there was true shortening of his left lower limb. An X-ray of the hip joint is shown below. What is the stage of the disease here?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of true shortening of the limb along with the X-ray showing mortar and pestle hip are suggestive of tuberculosis (TB) of the hip. It is seen in the stage of arthritis with subluxation.

Clinical features seen in the four stages of TB hip:

* Stage of synovitis (Option D) presents with apparent lengthening of the limb due to abduction deformity. 

* Stage of early arthritis (Option A) presents with apparent shortening of the limb due to adduction deformity.

* Stage of advanced arthritis (Option C) leads to true shortening of the limb because of the destruction of the articular cartilage of the femur and the acetabulum.

* Stage of arthritis with subluxation leads to true shortening of the limb. The destruction of the acetabulum leads to the dislocation of the femur head. This is also known as the wandering acetabulum/ mortar and pestle hip because of the widened acetabulum and diminished size of the femur head.

The TB of the hip finally results in fibrous ankylosis of the hip joint.

Note: The apparent length of the limb is measured from the umbilicus to the medial malleolus and the true length of the limb is measured from the anterior superior iliac spine to the medial malleolus. The apparent length is increased when there is abduction deformity of the limb and decreased when there is adduction deformity of the limb.

questions.text: 9. A patient came with ulcerative lesions around the oral cavity with a characteristic tapir nose and a destroyed nasal septum. Microscopy from the punch biopsy of the lesion shows the presence of amastigotes. What is the causative organism for the disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of mucocutaneous leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania braziliensis.

The Leishmania braziliensis complex causes both cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) and the more severe mucocutaneous leishmaniasis (MCL), also known as espundia. MCL is characterised by ulcerative lesions of the nose and oral cavity. Progressive tissue destruction may lead to loss of the nasal septum and the classical “tapir nose” deformity.

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressive protozoal disease transmitted by the bite of an infected female sandfly. In India, it is endemic in Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

Clinical forms of leishmaniasis:

* Visceral leishmaniasis 

* Cutaneous leishmaniasis

* Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

* Amastigote form (LD bodies): It is seen within macrophages, monocytes, neutrophils, or endothelial cells and contains a kinetoplast.

* Promastigote form: It is the infective form present in the sandfly.

The image given below shows a severe case of mucocutaneous leishmaniasis.



Other options:

Option A: Leishmania mexicana causes cutaneous leishmaniasis, characterised by chiclero ulcer and ulceration in the pinna as shown in the image below.



Option C: Leishmania tropica is characterised by a painless oriental sore (shown in the image below) in the face and hands, which later ulcerates.



Option D: Leishmania recidivans is a granulomatous response (shown in the image below) producing new lesions, which are scaly, erythematous, and usually occur years after infection by L. tropica.



Note: Leishmania braziliensis and Leishmania mexicana are categorised under New World cutaneous leishmaniasis, while Leishmania tropica is under Old World cutaneous leishmaniasis. Old World leishmaniasis is transmitted by Phlebotomus sandflies, while New World leishmaniasis is spread by Lutzomyia species.

questions.text:
10. An elderly male was brought to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal distension and not passing flatus or stools for the past 2 days. On examination, he appears dehydrated and has a warm, tense, tympanic abdomen. His radiographic image is as follows. His blood reports are available. What will be the best line of management?

Hb: 10.9 mg/dL TLC: 22,300 cells/mm3 Platelets: 2.19 lakhs/mm3

Sodium: 115 mEq/L Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L Chloride: 102 mEq/L

choices.text: NG tube aspiration and observe for 72 hours
Sigmoid colon fixed to the lateral wall of the abdomen
Proximal colostomy and distal mucous fistula from the rectum

questions.solution:
The above scenario points towards a sigmoid volvulus, which is at the verge of going for gangrenous change, and the best line of management is Paul-Mikulicz Surgery, which involves resection of the gangrenous sigmoid and the proximal cut end brought out as a colostomy and the distal end brought out as a mucous fistula from the rectum. 

A volvulus is a twisting or axial rotation of a portion of the bowel about its mesentery. The rotation obstructs the lumen with >180-degree torsion and vascular occlusion with 360-degree torsion.

Causes that predispose to volvulus of the sigmoid colon include an overloaded pelvic colon, long pelvic mesocolon, narrow attachment of pelvic mesocolon, and a band of adhesions (peridiverticultis).



The symptoms are primarily of large bowel obstruction as early distension, lesser pain, and late presentation of vomiting. When the colon has gone for gangrene or impending gangrene, features like dehydration, tense, tender abdomen, elevated total count, and dyselectrolytemia manifest as in this patient. 

X-ray abdomen (erect): Bent Inner Tube / Coffee Bean sign 

Initial Conservative Measures (Early, Non-gangrenous Volvulus)

* Nasogastric decompression (4th-hourly aspiration/continuous suction) (Option A)

* IV fluid and electrolyte correction (Hartmann’s or normal saline)

* Urinary catheterization, antibiotics

* Observation for 72 hours

Endoscopic/Non-surgical Detorsion

* Attempted via flatus tube or rigid sigmoidoscope (Option B)

* Successful detorsion: Relief of distension, passage of flatus/feces.

* Risks: High recurrence rate and danger of perforation → Not suitable if gangrene suspected.

Operative Management a. Sigmoidopexy (If bowel is viable and patient is fit for surgery) - After manual derotation, the sigmoid colon is fixed to the lateral pelvic wall or posterior abdominal wall to prevent recurrence (Option C)

b. Paul–Mikulicz Procedure (Non-viable or gangrenous sigmoid colon, or high suspicion of gangrene)

* Resection of the gangrenous sigmoid colon

* Proximal end → brought out as a colostomy

* Distal end → brought out as a mucous fistula

* Provides decompression and diversion, reducing risk of sepsis

* Definitive restoration of continuity (colostomy closure) can be done later.

c. Primary Resection and Anastomosis - Not advisable in gangrenous or contaminated field due to high risk of anastomotic leak and peritonitis.

questions.text: 11. A 58-year-old postmenopausal woman with a dragging sensation in the pelvis and a vaginal bulge that worsens with standing and after bowel movements. On pelvic examination, a central posterior vaginal wall bulge is noted in the upper 1/3rd above the hymen. Which procedure should be performed during surgery to address this defect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the woman has an enterocele. The appropriate surgical procedure to address this defect is McCall culdoplasty.

McCall culdoplasty is specifically performed to repair or prevent an enterocele, which is a herniation of the pouch of Douglas (rectouterine pouch) into the vaginal apex, especially after a vaginal hysterectomy. It involves obliteration of the cul-de-sac and suspension of the posterior vaginal apex using the uterosacral ligaments, providing durable support to prevent future prolapse.

This patient's findings, specifically, a bulge in the upper third of the posterior vaginal wall above the hymen, are consistent with an enterocele, rather than a rectocele, which typically affects the lower two-thirds of the posterior vaginal wall. Hence, procedures like posterior colpoperineorrhaphy (Option C)(which address rectocele and perineal laxity) are not appropriate in this case.

Other procedures, such as uterosacral ligament suspension (Option A), are more commonly used for apical prolapse rather than isolated posterior compartment defects, and Burch colposuspension (Option D) is indicated for stress urinary incontinence.

Pearl PM1916: Management of Vaginal prolapse

questions.text: 12. A post-menopausal woman presents with frequent bloating. She is found to have a pelvic mass on USG. She also has elevated serum AFP and β-hCG levels. A biopsy of the pelvic mass is shown below. Which other tumor marker will be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of a pelvic mass on ultrasound, elevated AFP and beta HCG and Call-Exner bodies on the histopathology image makes granulosa cell tumor the likely diagnosis. Inhibin is the most likely marker to be elevated in this patient's case.

Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian sex-cord stromal tumors made up of cells closely resembling the granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle. The majority of the time it is seen in post-menopausal women.

These tumors are usually unilateral. In adult women, they may be associated with proliferative breast disease, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma. The presence of this tumor in prepubertal girls may lead to precocious puberty. The serum and tissue inhibin levels are elevated.

The cut section is soft and has a yellowish reticular or trabecular appearance with interstitial hemorrhage. On microscopy, Call-Exner bodies are seen which are small, distinctive, gland-like structures filled with an acidophilic material that resemble immature follicles. 

Other Options:

Option A: β2-microglobulin is elevated in multiple myeloma and various other tumors like lymphoma. This is also elevated in amyloidosis where it is deposited in joints and soft tissues, and also in patients on long-term hemodialysis where it is not filtered out by the machine.

Option B: PLAP is a germ cell tumor marker elevated in seminomas, dysgerminomas, and embryonal carcinomas.

Option C: KIT is a proto-oncogene that codes for tyrosine kinase receptors. It is elevated in seminomas, dysgerminomas, and embryonal carcinomas.

questions.text: 13. A 30 year old male who lost his job recently, came to psychiatry OPD with complaints of low mood since last 2 weeks. He feels worthless and fatigued all the time. He gave history of early morning awakening and inability to concentrate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has complaints of low mood, worthlessness, fatigue, early morning awakening (terminal insomnia) and the inability to concentrate for a period of 2 weeks. Hence the diagnosis is depression.

Diagnostic criteria for depression:

* Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period.

* At least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.

* Depressed mood most of the day

* Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities

* Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, decrease or increase in appetite

* Insomnia or hypersomnia

* Psychomotor agitation or retardation

* Fatigue or loss of energy

* Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt

* Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness

* Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is characterised by emotional or behavioural symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends. Diagnostic criteria of an adjustment disorder include:

* Onset of symptoms within 3 months of the stressor.

* The symptoms disappear within 6 months if the stressor is removed.

* The symptoms of distress are clearly in excess of the normal.

* Mostly depressive but can also have anxious symptoms.

However, adjustment disorder is not diagnosed if the symptoms meet criteria for a specific mental disorder or represent an exacerbation of an existing disorder.

Option B: Subclinical depression is a condition in which a person has depressive symptoms but does not meet the criteria for a depressive disorder.

Option D: Dysthymia is characterized by depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents, for at least 1 year.

questions.text: 14. A 28-year-old woman, 30 minutes postpartum, continues to bleed profusely despite uterine massage and administration of oxytocin. On examination, the uterus is firm, and retained placental tissue is noted. Which of the following placental abnormalities, shown in the images below, can lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) secondary to retained placental tissue, which is seen in placenta succenturiata, depicted in image 3.

Placenta succenturiata is characterised by the presence of one or more small accessory lobes connected to the main placenta by a leash of blood vessels. This anomaly can lead to several complications, including:

* Retained placental tissue

* Postpartum haemorrhage

* Subinvolution of the uterus

* Uterine sepsis

* Placental polyp formation

In some cases, if the connecting vessels traverse the internal cervical os, vasa previa may occur, which can cause fetal haemorrhage during labour or membrane rupture.

Other options:

Image 1 illustrates a velamentous placenta. In this condition, the umbilical cord inserts into the fetal membranes (amnion and chorion) instead of the placental disc. The vessels then travel unprotected by Wharton’s jelly before reaching the placenta. If these vessels cross the internal os, it results in vasa previa, presenting as painless vaginal bleeding of fetal origin and leading to fetal distress or death.

Image 2 shows the battledore placenta, where the umbilical cord inserts at the placental margin rather than the centre. Although usually benign, it may predispose to cord compression during labour, causing variable fetal heart rate decelerations and occasionally fetal hypoxia.

Image 4 is of the circumvallate placenta. In this variant, the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate, causing infolding of the membranes and fibrin deposition at the placental margin. It is associated with second-trimester abortions, antepartum haemorrhage, preterm labour, and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

questions.text: 15. A 6-month-old male infant presents with failure to thrive, chronic steatorrhea, and developmental delay. On examination, the child has hypotonia and diminished reflexes. Peripheral smear shows acanthocytes, and serum lipid profile reveals marked hypocholesterolemia and undetectable triglyceride levels. Which of the following additional findings would most strongly support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of fat malabsorption (steatorrhea), neuromuscular signs (hypotonia, delayed milestones), and acanthocytosis strongly points toward abetalipoproteinemia. The undetectable LDL and absence of ApoB are the most defining laboratory features of abetalipoproteinemia

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the MTP gene (microsomal triglyceride transfer protein), which is crucial for lipidation and secretion of ApoB-containing lipoproteins:

* ApoB-48 (chylomicrons – intestinal)

* ApoB-100 (VLDL/LDL – hepatic)

Thus, lipids accumulate intracellularly. In abetalipoproteinemia, there is an absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL (apoB containing lipoproteins), and deficient levels of plasma cholesterol and triglycerides. This is predominantly seen in children during their first year of life, presenting with failure to thrive, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin E. 

This can lead to neurological manifestations like ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, and progressive pigmented retinopathy. Acanthocytosis is often observed on a peripheral smear due to an altered red cell membrane lipid composition. Intestinal biopsy reveals lipid-laden, vacuolated epithelium resulting from triglyceride accumulation.



Treatment includes a low-fat diet enriched with medium-chain triglycerides and high-dose supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins.

Other options:

Option A: Elevated chylomicrons and low HDL suggest Type I hyperlipoproteinemia (LPL or ApoC-II deficiency); in abetalipoproteinemia, chylomicrons are absent, and HDL is normal.

Option B: Elevated VLDL and high ApoB are seen in familial combined hyperlipidemia; ApoB is absent in abetalipoproteinemia.

Option D: Low triglycerides can be seen, but elevated Lp(a) is inconsistent in abetalipoproteinemia because Lp(a) is derived from LDL, which is absent in this condition.

questions.text: 16. A patient who underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy 3 days ago now presents with abdominal pain, guarding, and rigidity. USG shows a collection in the hepatorenal pouch. MRCP shows a complete transection of the common hepatic duct. Which of the following is the definitive management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The definitive management of a major bile duct injury such as transection of the common hepatic duct, identified in the postoperative period, is a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. 

Diagnosis of iatrogenic bile duct injury should be considered in any patient who presents with new-onset symptoms following cholecystectomy. Patients will usually present with abdominal pain, fever, jaundice, and features of peritonitis such as guarding and rigidity. Abdominal USG will show fluid collection. The immediate management is to drain the biliary collection by percutaneous drain insertion. MRCP is then done to evaluate the biliary tree and determine the injury's level and extent.

Biliary-enteric continuity is reestablished using Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. If the injury is high-up, near the hepatic duct bifurcation, or involves the intra-hepatic ducts, long-term stenting is done following Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy to improve patency rates.

If biliary tree injury is identified during the surgery, the management depends on the extent of the injury:

* <50% circumference of the wall of the duct injured: managed by primary repair over a T-tube

* >50% circumference of the wall of the duct injured: managed by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

17. A 30-year-old man experiences brief, severe stabbing pain around his right eye and temple, accompanied by tearing and nasal congestion. After a thorough checkup, a physician classifies this as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia. Which is the least likely diagnosis?

SUNCT - Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform Headache with Conjunctival Injection and Tearing
questions.solution:
The least likely diagnosis for a patient classified with Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia (TAC) based on the given symptoms is trigeminal neuralgia.

Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgias (TACs) are a group of primary headache disorders marked by brief, recurrent attacks of severe unilateral pain accompanied by ipsilateral cranial autonomic features such as tearing (lacrimation), eye redness (conjunctival injection), ear fullness, or nasal congestion. These episodes can recur several times within a single day.

TACs include:

* Cluster headache (option A)

* Paroxysmal hemicrania

* SUNCT – Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival Injection and Tearing (option D)

* SUNA – Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial Autonomic symptoms

* Hemicrania continua (option B)

Trigeminal neuralgia is a distinct clinical entity and is not classified as a TAC because it lacks the characteristic cranial autonomic symptoms seen in TACs.

questions.text: 18. Which sterilization method uses gas vapors in the form of free radicals for sterilization?
questions.solution:
Plasma sterilizer uses gas vapors in the form of free radicals for sterilization. 

Plasma is a state of matter that consists of ions, free electrons, and free radicals, such as (OH-). A plasma sterilizer/STERRAD is a specialized device designed to generate this plasma state.

In the process, an electrical field is applied within the sterilizer's chamber to create gas plasma. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) breaks down into free radicals, like hydroxyl (OH-) and hydroperoxyl (HO2), which actively kill microbes. These free radicals then interact with essential cellular components, including enzymes and nucleic acids, to achieve sterilization.

Other options: 

Option A: Incineration is used specifically for non-plastic infectious waste. It sterilizes the waste by using very high temperatures ranging from 870 to 1200°C, converting it into ash, flue gas, and heat.

Option B: Steam sterilizer or autoclave kills microorganisms by irreversible coagulation and denaturing of enzymes. 

Option C: Ionising radiation causes ionization of molecules at low temperature (cold sterilization) by using cobalt 60 gamma rays or electron accelerators.

questions.text: 19. The given blood smear shows a characteristic cell type. It is most likely seen in infection with which of the following viruses?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows neoplastic tumour cells with multilobulated “cloverleaf” or “flower” nuclei, characteristic of Adult T-cell Leukaemia/Lymphoma (ATLL) caused by Human T-cell Leukaemia Virus type 1 (HTLV-1).

Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma (CD4+):

* It is observed in adults infected by human T cell leukaemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1)

* It is characterised by skin lesions, generalised lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia.

* Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells)

* A rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

questions.text:
20. A 40-year-old woman complains of shortness of breath and chronic dry cough for the past few months. She has no history of fever, weight loss, or night sweats and she is a non-smoker. Examination reveals erythema nodosum. Laboratory investigations show hypercalcemia. Her chest X-ray is shown below. What is the primary mechanism of hypercalcemia in this condition?

FGF23: Fibroblast growth factor-23
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is that of sarcoidosis, characterized by lung involvement (chronic dry cough, shortness of breath, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray), erythema nodosum, and hypercalcemia. The primary mechanism of hypercalcemia in sarcoidosis is increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D.

Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. These granulomas express 1-alpha hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium which results in hypercalcemia.

The lungs are most commonly affected in sarcoidosis, and the patients commonly present with cough and dyspnea. The involvement of the right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar lymph nodes leads to a characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement known as the Garland triad, 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign. 

Other options: 

Option A: While hypercalcemia can result from increased bone resorption in conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism, it is not the primary mechanism in sarcoidosis-associated hypercalcemia.

Option B: Fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) plays a role in phosphate homeostasis and is associated with conditions like tumor-induced osteomalacia, but it is not implicated in sarcoidosis-related hypercalcemia.

Option C: Increased parathyroid hormone secretion leads to hypercalcemia in primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: 21. You are an intern posted in the medical intensive care unit. There is a patient admitted there with heart failure. He has low cardiac output with oliguria. Which of the following inotropes would be preferred in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Dopamine is used in the treatment of severe congestive heart failure, particularly in patients with oliguria, as it improves renal function.

It is administered at 2–5 mcg/kg/min intravenously. Stimulation of dopaminergic and β-adrenergic receptors produces increased glomerular filtration, heart rate, and contractility.

Other options:

Option A: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α- and β-adrenergic receptors. It increases cardiac contractility but decreases renal perfusion. It is mainly used in anaphylactic shock.

Option B: Norepinephrine is a potent α and β1 agonist, with very little effect on the β2 receptor. It can be used to raise blood pressure in intensive care conditions, but since it decreases the renal blood flow, it is not preferred in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Fenoldopam is an agonist for peripheral D1 receptors and is used to control hypertension.

questions.text: 22. An alcoholic patient was brought to the emergency room by his relatives in a state of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness. His spot blood glucose level was found to be 45 mg/dL. Which of the following is responsible for this low blood glucose level?

choices.text: Decreased diversion of acetyl CoA to ketogenesis

questions.solution:
This patient has ethanol intoxication, and increased lactate/pyruvate ratio is the reason for his low blood glucose levels.

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by dehydrogenases is accompanied by the reduction of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to NADH. This will result in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions that require NAD+ are inhibited:

* Glycolysis

* Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favored)

* Pyruvate dehydrogenase

* Fatty acid oxidation

Apart from this, there is an increase in two reactions:

* Pyruvate to lactate 

* Oxaloacetate to malate

Both of these reactions lead to a decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis; a reduced level of these substrates leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgment, and combativeness.

A decrease in oxaloacetate can impair the ability of the citric acid cycle to metabolize acetyl-CoA and divert fatty acid oxidation toward ketogenesis.

questions.text: 23. Which of the following is associated with immune complex-mediated complement activation and inflammatory response?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with immune complex-mediated complement activation and inflammatory response, as in a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction. 

Type III hypersensitivity reactions develop as a result of the excess formation of immune complexes (Ag-Ab complexes), which initiate an inflammatory response through activation of the complement system, leading to tissue injury. Connective tissue disorders like rheumatoid arthritis (Ab against human immunoglobulin) and systemic lupus erythematosus (Anti-DNA Ab) result from autoantibodies forming immune complexes with self-antigens.

Other options:

Option A: Atopic dermatitis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction due to IgE production.

Option B: Rh incompatibility is a type II hypersensitivity reaction due to antibodies reacting with red blood cell antigens. 

Option D: Contact dermatitis is a TDTH  cell-mediated delayed type 4 hypersensitivity.

questions.text: 24. A patient presented with severe vaginal bleeding not responding to medical management. An abdominal hysterectomy was performed. On post-op day 1 the patient was diagnosed with significant hemoperitoneum. A laparotomy was performed and the source of bleeding was identified as the Sampson artery. Which of the following structures is likely to have been improperly clamped during hysterectomy resulting in hemoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the round ligament, which is supplied by the Sampson artery, is likely to have been improperly clamped during the hysterectomy, resulting in hemoperitoneum. The round ligament is the only ligament that receives a blood supply.

The round ligament originates below and anterior to the origin of the fallopian tubes. Clinically, this orientation can aid tube identification during puerperal sterilization. Each round ligament extends laterally and down into the inguinal canal, through which it passes, to terminate in the upper portion of the ipsilateral labium major. The Sampson artery, or artery to the round ligament, is a small branch from the uterine artery or ovarian artery and runs within the ligament.

The cardinal ligaments(lateral or transverse cervical or Mackenrodt's ligaments) are situated along the inferior border of the broad ligament and continue from the side of the cervix and lateral fornix of the vagina. They contain the uterine artery and uterine veins.

The broad ligament is a fold of the peritoneum that attaches the pelvis to the ovaries and uterus.

Infundibulo pelvic ligament (suspensory ligament) - attaches the lateral surface of the ovary to the peritoneum lining the lateral pelvic wall. It contains the ovarian vessels and nerves.



The sequence of clamping of structures in abdominal hysterectomy

* The first clamp includes the round ligament and the infundibulopelvic ligament(When ovaries are to be removed)

* The second clamp includes the uterine artery. 

* The third clamp includes the Cardinal ligament and the uterosacral ligament.

In an abdominal hysterectomy, the cardinal(Mackenrodt) ligament is clamped before the uterosacral ligament.

The sequence of clamping of the structure in vaginal hysterectomy

* The first clamp includes the uterosacral ligament, Mackenrodt’s ligament, and the descending cervical artery.

* The second clamp includes the uterine artery and the base of the broad ligament.

* The third clamp includes the round ligament, fallopian tube, mesosalpinx, and ligament of the ovary.

In a vaginal hysterectomy, the uterosacral ligament is clamped before the cardinal(Mackenrodt) ligament.

questions.text: 25. You have 4 drugs that can be given to control blood sugar. Which of the following measures will you use to choose a drug with more consistent blood sugar levels?
questions.solution:
The measure used to choose a drug that controls blood sugar more consistently is the coefficient of variation (CV).

The coefficient of variation is a statistical measure of relative variability, expressing the dispersion of data points around the mean as a proportion of the mean. It is also known as the relative standard deviation (RSD). CV is used to compare variability across different datasets and is particularly useful here for determining which drug maintains more consistent blood sugar levels regardless of differences in their average effects.

Other options:

Option A: Variance (var or SD²) represents the mean of the squared deviations from the mean and measures data spread. However, it cannot be used to compare consistency across drugs with different mean values.

Option B: Coefficient of determination (r²) indicates the proportion of variance in one variable explained by another. Since this scenario does not involve a relationship between two variables, it is not applicable.

Option D: Standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. Since in this scenario we are not comparing the sample means with the population mean, this is not used in the given scenario.

Pearl PM1088: Coefficient of Variation

* The coefficient of variation (CV) is a statistical measure of the relative dispersion of data points in a data series around the mean.

* It is done to measure of relative variability and it is also known as relative standard deviation (RSD).

* It is expressed as a percentage of the mean and its formulas are given in the image below:



where σ and s = standard deviation; and μ and x = mean

* In simpler terms, coefficient of variation (CV) = standard deviation x 100/mean.

* CV usually gives an idea into the performance of a test or method. A CV of 5% gives the general idea that the method is good in its performance but a CV of more than 10% gives an idea that the method isn’t very good.

Pearl PM1089: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

* Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.

* Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):

* This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.

* Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.

For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.

* Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:

* The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)

* Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape

* Assuming all samples are identical in size

* The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 

* Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):

* The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

* Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 

* More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 

SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: 26. A 60-year-old man with a history of renal transplantation taking Tacrolimus and Mycophenolate mofetil develops a yellowish nodular plaque near his right groin. Biopsy findings are shown. What is the most likely underlying pathogenic mechanism for this finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with biopsy findings showing basophilic concretions (Michaelis–Gutmann bodies), is most likely suggestive of cutaneous malakoplakia, which results from an acquired defect in phagocyte (macrophage) function.

Malakoplakia is an inflammatory condition that occurs in the background of chronic bacterial infection by Escherichia coli or Proteus species in immunosuppressed individuals, like renal transplant patients immunosuppressants like tacrolimus and mycophenolate mofetil. It typically occurs in the urinary tract.

The cutaneous form of malakoplakia is less prevalent, and it most commonly occurs in the perianal or genital regions. Ulcers, sinuses, fluctuant masses, abscesses, tender nodules, and papules may be seen. It can also be observed in other organ systems, such as the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system.

The histopathological findings include:

* Large, foamy macrophages containing abundant granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products

* Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, which are PAS-positive basophilic concretions due to calcium deposits in lysosomes

* Occasional multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes

The image given below shows the Von Kossa stain demonstrating calcium and iron-containing Michaelis-Gutman bodies (MG bodies) in malakoplakia:



Other options:

Option A: Defective keratinisation is seen in disorders like Psoriasis, Actinic Keratosis, or Ichthyosis, where either keratinocyte maturation or turnover is abnormal.

Option C: Autoimmune destruction of keratinocytes is seen in the Pemphigus group of disorders. It shows acantholysis forming intraepidermal clefts and blisters. Basal cells stay attached to the basement membrane but separate from one another, resembling a row of tombstones.

Option D: HPV induced koilocytic change will be seen as warty lesions on the skin, and microscopic findings show perinuclear clearing and nuclear irregularity. The image below shows a koilocyte on a pap smear:

questions.text: 27. A 45-year-old female patient presents to the casualty due to reduced urination. A Foley catheter is placed. The urine analysis reveals proteinuria. Her BP was found to be 200/100 mmHg. She has a history of scleroderma. Which of the following drugs will be the mainstay in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of proteinuria, accelerated hypertension, and oliguria along with a past history of scleroderma is suggestive of a scleroderma renal crisis. ACE inhibitors like captopril are the first line drugs in the management of a scleroderma renal crisis.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency characterized by acute onset malignant hypertension and kidney failure, usually in the absence of previous evidence of significant kidney disease. The use of steroids is associated with an increased risk of scleroderma renal crisis.

Clinical features of scleroderma renal crisis are:

* Accelerated hypertension - headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, hypertensive retinopathy, and hypertensive encephalopathy.

* Acute kidney injury - oliguria, mild proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, renal failure.

* Pulmonary edema, congestive heart failure.

* Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes), thrombocytopenia.

Risk factors for scleroderma renal crisis include African-American race, male sex, and diffuse or progressive skin involvement. Up to 50% of patients with scleroderma renal crisis have anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies, whereas patients with anti-centromere antibodies appear to be protected from this complication.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

* Antinuclear antibody (ANA) (Option 1) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis. 

* Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis

* Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody (Option 2)- usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Option 2)

* Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody (Option 4)- usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Scleroderma renal crisis is a medical emergency and should be treated with angiotensin II receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, and direct renin inhibitors. Glucocorticoids should be used at a low dose only when necessary.

questions.text: 28. A milk sample received by health care workers is to undergo a quality checking process. All the following tests can be used to check the efficiency of pasteurization, except:
questions.solution:
All the given tests can be used to check the efficiency of pasteurization except the methylene blue reduction test.

Methylene blue reduction test is an indirect method for the detection of microorganisms in milk. The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization to check for gross contamination, and not to check the efficiency of pasteurization.

Tests to check the efficiency of pasteurization:

* Phosphatase test

* Standard plate count

* Coliform count

questions.text: 29. A tourist presented with fever, lymphadenopathy, and a skin lesion as shown below after a forest hike. He remembers getting an insect bite during the forest hike. Which of the following is the causative organism for the above disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an insect bite followed by fever and lymphadenopathy, and the clinical image of eschar formation, are suggestive of scrub typhus. The causative organism for scrub typhus is O. tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus is caused by O. tsutsugamushi, and the vector is the trombiculid mite. Clinical features include fever, lymphadenopathy, headache, and eschar where the chigger has been fed.

Serologic assays are used for diagnosis. Doxycycline, Azithromycin, or chloramphenicol are also used for the treatment. In the case of pregnant women where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated, azithromycin may be preferred.

questions.text: 31. In which of the following diseases will you find an increase in the ratio of upper segment to lower segment (U/L) of the body?
questions.solution:
The ratio of the upper segment to the lower segment (U/L) is increased in rickets.

The lower segment is defined as the length from the symphysis pubis to the floor. The upper segment is measured by subtracting the lower segment from the height.

 High U/L ratio is seen in:

* Rickets

* Achondroplasia

* Untreated congenital hypothyroidism 

* Short limb dwarfism

* Turners syndrome

Low U/L ratio is seen: 

* Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia

* Vertebral anomalies

* Hypogonadism

* Marfan syndrome

The U/L ratio is

* 1.7 at birth

* 1.3 at 3 years

* 1 after 7 years

* 0.9 in adults



Pearl PM1959: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

* Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 

* Delayed appearance of the epiphysis

* Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.

* Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.

* Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis

* Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices

* In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

* Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia

* Wrist: especially the ulna

* Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text: 32. A 4-year-old boy was found to have the following arterial blood gas findings. The pH is 7.24, serum bicarbonate is 18mEq/L, and pCO₂ is 35mmHg. Which of the following is the most common cause of the given ABG presentation in children?
questions.solution:
The given ABG findings are suggestive of metabolic acidosis because the pH is low (acidosis) with low bicarbonate (metabolic) and normal pCO2 levels. Diarrhoea is the most common cause of metabolic acidosis in children overall because of the loss of bicarbonates from the body.

Acidosis can be due to either low serum bicarbonate/increased organic acids (metabolic) or high pCO2 (respiratory). The normal values in ABG are:

* pH = 7.35-7.45

* [HCO3-] = 22-28 mEq/L

* pCO2 = 35-45 mmHg

* Anion gap = 6-12 mmol/L

The amount of bicarbonate lost in the stool depends on the volume of diarrhoea and the bicarbonate concentration of the stool, which tends to increase with more severe diarrhoea.

Causes of Metabolic acidosis include,

Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

* Diarrhoea (Loss of bicarbonate is compensated by chloride reabsorption)

* Renal tubular acidosis

* Urinary tract diversions (reabsorption of ammonium and hydrogen by the bowel)

High anion-gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA)

* Lactic acidosis (hypoxia, malignancy)

* Ketoacidosis (diabetic, starvation)

* Poisoning (ethylene glycol, methanol, salicylate)

Pearl PM1343: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: 33. β-Alanine supplementation is known to enhance athletic performance, particularly during high-intensity exercise. What is the most likely biochemical basis for this effect?

choices.text: Increases mitochondrial density in oxidative muscle fibers
Stimulates insulin release to enhance glucose uptake in muscle fibers
Buffers intracellular hydrogen ions during anaerobic glycolysis
Inhibits lactate production by suppressing lactate dehydrogenase

questions.solution:
β-Alanine buffers intracellular hydrogen ions during anaerobic glycolysis. 

β-Alanine is a precursor of carnosine, a dipeptide formed from β-alanine and L-histidine, by the enzyme carnosine synthetase. Carnosine acts as an intracellular buffer in anaerobically contracting skeletal muscle.

During high-intensity exercise, hydrogen ions accumulate as a result of rapid ATP hydrolysis and other metabolic reactions, leading to a decrease in intracellular pH. The imidazole group of the histidine residue in carnosine accepts excess hydrogen ions, thereby stabilizing muscle pH and helping maintain optimal enzymatic activity under acidic conditions. This buffering action delays muscle fatigue and supports short-term, high-intensity performance.

Carnosine in the bloodstream is hydrolyzed by the enzyme carnosinase into β-alanine and histidine. Because β-alanine availability limits carnosine synthesis, β-alanine supplementation effectively increases muscle carnosine concentration, enhancing the muscle’s buffering capacity during anaerobic exercise.

Other options:

Option A:  Increased mitochondrial density in oxidative muscle fibers is an adaptation to aerobic endurance training, not the effect of carnosine.

Option B: β-Alanine does not affect insulin secretion or glucose uptake directly. Its primary role is in carnosine synthesis for intracellular buffering and not energy metabolism.

Option D: Carnosine does not inhibit lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Lactate production continues, but carnosine helps manage the H⁺ accumulation that accompanies it.

questions.text: 34. A 10-year-old child was brought with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, white-grey exudative substance adherent to his oropharynx as shown. He was prescribed erythromycin for the same. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of action of erythromycin is inhibition of the 50s subunit of the ribosome.

The above clinical scenario of fever, sore throat, extensive submandibular, cervical swelling and oral examination findings are suggestive of diphtheria. 

Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic. It is a bacteriostatic agent that inhibits protein synthesis by binding reversibly to 50S ribosomal subunits in susceptible microorganisms.

It is commonly used for the treatment of gram-positive infections. Erythromycin is the traditional drug of choice in diphtheria and in the carrier state. Erythromycin is also used for the treatment of atypical pneumonia. It is given for prophylaxis of endocarditis and rheumatic fever in people with valvular heart disease and allergic to penicillin, respectively.

The adverse effects of anorexia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Erythromycin acts on motilin receptors, resulting in stimulation of the gastrointestinal motility and causing gastrointestinal disturbances. This therapeutic paradox has led to erythromycin's off-label use as a prokinetic agent in the intensive care setting and in patients with diabetic gastroparesis. 

Erythromycin, particularly the erythromycin estolate formulation, results in cholestatic hepatitis (jaundice, impaired liver function) as a result of a hypersensitivity reaction. It inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme and results in increased accumulation of various drugs like theophylline, warfarin, cyclosporine, and methylprednisolone.

Other options:

Option A: Tetracyclines (Eg, doxycycline, minocycline) and aminoglycosides (eg, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin) inhibit protein synthesis by binding to the 30S subunit of the ribosomes of susceptible organisms.

Option C: Glycopeptides (Eg, vancomycin) inhibit the transglycosylase enzyme, resulting in the prevention of elongation of peptidoglycans and cross-linking in the cell wall.

Option D: Beta-lactam group (penicillin group of drugs like cephalosporins, meropenems, etc) of antimicrobials inhibits the cell wall synthesis by binding and inhibiting the cell wall transpeptidase.

questions.text: 35. A newborn presents with cyanosis. Echocardiography reveals a condition consistent with Tricuspid atresia. This anomaly results from the abnormal development of which embryological structure?

choices.text: Right horn of the sinus venosus

questions.solution:
Tricuspid atresia results from improper development or fusion of the endocardial cushions during heart formation.

During normal heart development, the atrioventricular (AV) septum forms from the fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions in the AV canal. These cushions divide the common AV canal into right and left channels, contributing to the formation of the tricuspid and mitral valves as well as the membranous part of the interventricular septum.

When these cushions fuse too far to the right or fail to align properly with the interventricular septum, the tricuspid orifice fails to form, leading to the absence of the tricuspid valve and a hypoplastic right ventricle. Blood is then shunted from the right atrium to the left atrium via a patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect, where it mixes with oxygenated blood, resulting in reduced overall oxygen saturation.



Other options:

Option A: Defect in the septum primum results in an atrial septal defect (ASD). Incomplete growth or excessive resorption of the septum prevents closure of the foramen primum or secundum, allowing interatrial communication.

Option C: Defect in the spiral septum causes transposition of the great arteries, tetralogy of Fallot, or persistent truncus arteriosus. Improper formation or spiralling of the septum dividing the truncus arteriosus and bulbus cordis leads to malalignment of the outflow tracts.

Option D: Defect in the right horn of the sinus venosus leads to abnormal formation of the smooth part of the right atrium (sinus venarum).

questions.text: 37. Which of the following techniques is not used for the treatment of a dislocated shoulder?
questions.solution:
The Allis maneuver is not used for the reduction of a dislocated shoulder. It is used for the reduction of a posteriorly dislocated hip. All the other options are used for the reduction of an anteriorly dislocated shoulder.

A hip dislocation, whether anterior, posterior, or central, constitutes an orthopaedic emergency. It is considered so because delaying the reduction of a dislocated hip increases the risk of osteonecrosis of the femoral head due to loss of blood supply.

Initially, a trauma survey is made, and life-threatening injuries are ruled out. After that, the dislocated hip takes precedence over any other orthopaedic injury. After radiological assessment, closed reduction of the hip should initially be attempted in the emergency department if the dislocation is simple, i.e., without any associated complicated acetabular fractures or proximal femoral fractures. It can be performed either under light sedation or general anaesthesia.

The most common method used for the reduction of a posteriorly dislocated hip is the Allis maneuver. It is performed with the patient in the supine position. An assistant stabilises the pelvis by applying pressure on both the ASIS. Traction is applied along the line of the femur, and the hip is gently flexed to 90°. The hip is now gently rotated, internally and externally, with continued longitudinal traction till reduction is achieved.

A clunk sound is heard when the femoral head reduces into the acetabulum and can be confirmed radiologically later on. Distal femoral or proximal tibial skeletal traction can be applied after reduction so that redislocation can be prevented. Other methods used for the same are Bigelow’s method, Watson-Jones' method, etc.

The image below shows Allis' maneuver.



Other options:

Option B: In Hippocrates' method, the surgeon applies a firm and steady pull on the semiabducted arm. The head of the humerus is levered back into position using the foot of the surgeon as a fulcrum and kept in the axilla.

Option C: The Milch maneuver involves gentle abduction and external rotation of the arm while applying upward pressure on the humeral head to guide it back into the glenoid cavity. Reduction is confirmed by a clunk sound, which is produced when the head is pushed into the glenoid cavity.  

Option D: Kocher’s method consists of longitudinal traction of the arm with the elbow flexed to 90 degrees, external rotation while continuing steady traction, adduction by carrying the elbow towards the torso,  and medial rotation whereby the arm is rotated internally so that the hand falls across the torso to touch the opposite shoulder.

Pearl PM2325: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.



Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: 40. The wife of a middle-aged man complains of her husband having detailed conversations in his sleep, which have led to disturbed sleep for the whole family. On awakening, he has no recollection of the conversations, and he has no history of organic or neurological disorder. Which of the following EEG waveforms is characteristic of the sleep stage during which such an event occurs?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Somniloquy or sleep talking, which happens in the N3 and N4 stage of NREM sleep. Delta waves are present during this stage of Sleep.

Sleep comprises two physiological states: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. REM sleep refers to rapid eye movements that occur during this stage of sleep. Except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone. Low amplitude, high frequency saw tooth waves are seen in this stage (Option B). Nightmares, nocturnal penile tumescence, and narcolepsy are REM Sleep Disorders.

In wakefulness, EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed-frequency activity. When eyes are closed, alpha activity is seen. When the eyes are open, beta waves are seen (Option C)

questions.text: 41. A 68-year-old man with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (not on dialysis), hypertension, and diabetes, is scheduled for lumbar decompression surgery. The anaesthesia team plans to use systemic opioids for pain relief. Which opioid is the safest and most appropriate for perioperative analgesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Sufentanil is the most appropriate choice for perioperative analgesia in this patient as it is relatively safe in renal failure.

Sufentanil is highly lipophilic, extensively metabolised in the liver, and does not have active metabolites. It is minimally affected by renal dysfunction, making it one of the opioids that can be used in renal failure patients.

In patients with renal impairment, fentanyl, alfentanil, sufentanil, and remifentanil do not deliver a highly active metabolite load or suffer from significant prolonged clearance. They are safe to use in renal failure.

Other Options:

Option A: Morphine is metabolised in the liver to active metabolites (M3G and M6G), both of which are renally excreted. In renal failure, M6G accumulates and can cause prolonged sedation and respiratory depression.

Option B: Normeperidine is a metabolite of Meperidine (Pethidine). It accumulates in renal failure and is neurotoxic, increasing the risk of seizures.

Option C: Hydromorphone is metabolised to hydromorphone-3-glucuronide, which is renally excreted. Accumulation of this active metabolite in patients with reduced GFR or those not on dialysis can lead to neuroexcitation, cognitive dysfunction, or myoclonus. Hence, it should be used with caution in such patients.

* Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

* Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)

* Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

questions.text:
42. Rahul is screened for an infectious disease before a job. He is worried about a false positive result, while the employer wants to avoid hiring diseased individuals. Which indicator is most important for Rahul and the employer, respectively?

PPV - Positive predictive value NPV - Negative predictive value
questions.solution:
The most important indicators for Rahul and the employer are Positive Predictive Value (PPV) and Sensitivity, respectively.

Rahul is worried about being falsely labelled positive, so he wants confidence that a positive result truly indicates infection. The indicator reflecting the proportion of true positives among all positive results is PPV. Thus, a high PPV minimises false positives and is most important for Rahul.

The employer wants to ensure that no diseased individual is missed, which means avoiding false negatives. The indicator measuring the proportion of correctly identified diseased individuals is Sensitivity, making it most important for the employer.

NPV shows the proportion of true negatives among those testing negative, and Specificity reflects true negatives among all disease-free individuals. However, these do not address the specific concerns in this scenario.

Note: Specificity can also be considered to be relevant for Rahul, as a highly specific test will have fewer false positives.

Pearl PM2399: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: 43. Cyproheptadine has been used in the treatment of a patient who presented with flushing, altered mental status, muscular rigidity, hyperreflexia, and dilatation of pupils. Which of the following is correct regarding the mechanism of action of the drug used?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of serotonin syndrome, in which Cyproheptadine, used, is an H1 and  5HT2A antagonist, which has both antihistamine and antiserotonin activity. 

Cyproheptadine is a first-generation antihistamine that has both antihistamine and antiserotonin activity by antagonizing the 5-HT2A receptor, and also has significant anticholinergic effects and can increase appetite. Side effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, and weight gain.  

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to serotonin overstimulation. Clinical features include altered mental status, neuromuscular hyperactivity (hyperreflexia, myoclonus, rigidity, tremors), and autonomic dysfunction(abdominal pain, diarrhea, diaphoresis, fever, flushing, labile hypertension, mydriasis, tearing, salivation, tachycardia). Complications include hyperthermia, lactic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, and multisystem organ failure.

It can occur with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels, like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), and dextromethorphan.

Ketanserin is a 5-HT2A blocker(Option C) used in migraine and some cases of depression. Options B and D are distractors. No clinically used drugs are available with such actions.

questions.text: 44. A 50-year-old man presents with complaints of periorbital edema and frothy urine without any evidence of hematuria. The electron microscopy of the glomeruli is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with nephrotic syndrome, characterised by periorbital oedema and frothy urine without hematuria. The key feature visible on the electron microscopic image is the presence of diffuse subepithelial electron-dense deposits, which are the hallmark of Membranous nephropathy. 

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It occurs commonly in men aged between 30-50 years. Most cases are classified as idiopathic or primary and are caused by autoantibodies targeting the renal antigen known as phospholipase A2 receptor. These autoantibodies are absent in secondary membranous nephropathy.

Light microscopy in the case of membranous nephropathy shows diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes and a dome pattern can be seen on the silver staining.

Immunofluorescence microscopy shows granular deposits containing IgG and complement proteins along the glomerular basement membrane. IgG4 is the principal immunoglobulin deposited in most cases of primary membranous nephropathy.

Electron microscopy shows electron-dense subepithelial deposits (also referred to as membranous spikes) and podocyte foot process effacement are observed, as illustrated below.



Other options:

Option B and C: Focal Segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and Minimal change disease (MCD) are also causes of nephrotic syndrome, but differ on electron microscopy. Both show diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes without electron-dense deposits. Podocyte foot process effacement has been illustrated in the image given below.



Option D: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) typically presents as a nephrito-nephrotic syndrome. In MPGN type I, electron microscopy reveals subendothelial deposits (option D), whereas MPGN type II (Dense Deposit Disease) shows intramembranous dense deposits. The image given below demonstrates electron-dense subendothelial deposits.

questions.text: 45. A 4-month-old infant presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and recurrent lactic acidosis. Blood work reveals hypoglycemia, elevated lactate, and metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap. Enzyme studies suggest a defect in pyruvate carboxylase. Along with biotin, which trace element is essential for the optimal function of this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Manganese is the trace element that is required for the optimal functioning of pyruvate carboxylase.

Pyruvate carboxylase is a mitochondrial enzyme that converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate, a key step in gluconeogenesis and anaplerotic replenishment of the TCA cycle. It belongs to the class of ligases. It requires biotin as a coenzyme, which carries activated CO2 used to carboxylate pyruvate, and manganese acts as a metal cofactor that stabilizes the enzyme’s active site.

Manganese is absorbed in the small intestine and stored mainly in the liver, pancreas, bone, and mitochondria-rich tissues. Deficiency of manganese may worsen energy metabolism, especially in infants with inborn errors like pyruvate carboxylase deficiency, which presents with:

* Lactic acidosis

* Hypoglycemia

* Failure to thrive

Other biochemical roles of manganese include:

* Mitochondrial superoxide dismutase (Mn-SOD) is used in antioxidant defense

* Arginase in the urea cycle

* Glycosyltransferases for cartilage formation and bone health

* Activation of hydrolases and decarboxylases

Other options:

Option A: Zinc is a cofactor in carbonic anhydrase, dehydrogenases, and DNA/RNA polymerases.

Option C: Copper is required for cytochrome c oxidase, tyrosinase, and lysyl oxidase.

Option D: Molybdenum is a cofactor for xanthine oxidase and sulfite oxidase.
