questions.text: 47. You are assisting in a tubal sterilization procedure where the senior resident performs the following technique. This procedure is known as:
questions.solution:
The sterilization procedure shown in the above image is Irving's procedure. It involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

It is often done in conjunction with caesarian sections. It is a reliable method of sterilization, but not a reversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

Other methods of sterilization include:

1. Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:

* Pomeroy's procedure: The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised. It is surgically reversible.

* Madlener's procedure: A loop of the fallopian tube is crushed and then ligated with a nonabsorbable suture.

* Kroener's technique: It refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum. It is irreversible.

* Uchida's method: The serosa in the midsegment of the tube is stripped off from the mucosa and then excised. The proximal segment is ligated and buried in the broad ligament. The minimum tubal excision preserves the potential for tuboplasty.

* Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected between two clamps.







2. Laparoscopic techniques: Each fallopian tube is picked up near the isthmic end (2–3 cm away) and clipped or banded with silastic bands, Filshie clips, Hulka band, or falope silastic rings. It is a reversible technique.



3. Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It is made of a flexible stainless steel inner coil and a nickel-titanium outer coil (nitinol). Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) in the inner coil causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text: 48. A teacher arranges the marks scored by students in an exam in the following format. What is the mode of the data?
questions.solution:
The mode of the data presented in the stem-and-leaf display is 75.

In a stem-and-leaf display, each data value is split into two parts: the stem and the leaf. Usually, the stem represents the digits to the left (such as tens, hundreds, or thousands), and the leaf represents the final digit (units place). For example, a stem of 7 and a leaf of 5 correspond to the number 75.

Given the stem-and-leaf representation, the data values translate to:

30, 31, 35, 43, 45, 61, 63, 63, 73, 75, 75, 75, 82, 87, 88, 95, and 98.

The mode is the value that occurs most frequently in the dataset. Here, the number 75 appears three times, more than any other value, so the mode of the data is 75.

Pearl PM1147: Stem-and-Leaf Displays



* A stem-and-leaf plot is used to graphically display small to moderate sized data.

* In this type of representation, the values of the data are separated into two parts, the stem and the leaf.

* Usually, the stem represents the tens, hundreds, thousandth digits, etc. and the leaf part represents the remainders of the digits.

* For example, if a set of data containing marks of students of out 100 is 94, 90, 84, 87, 89, 85, 83, 79, 72, 70, 72, 68, 69, 65, 53. Then the stem-and-leaf for this set of data would be as shown in the image.

Pearl PM0971: The Mode in Biostatistics

* The mode is most frequently occurring observed value in a distribution.

* A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.

* If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.

* If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.

* The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.

* It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.

* Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

questions.text: 49. Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient with breast cancer. Which of the following subtypes indicates the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
The luminal A molecular subtype of breast cancer is associated with the best prognosis. 

The cells in breast cancer may overexpress estrogen receptors (ER), progesterone receptors (PR), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2/neu (HER2/neu), and androgen receptors (AR). Ki-67 mitotic index indicates the degree of mitosis or proliferation. 

Based on these factors, breast cancer is classified into 5 subtypes. These include: 

* luminal A

* luminal B

* HER2/neu enriched

* basal

* normal-like group

The luminal A subtype is the most common. They are defined as hormone receptor-positive (ER-positive and/or PR-positive), HER2/neu negative, and low Ki67 by immunohistochemistry. These tumors have a low histological grade, low degree of nuclear pleomorphism, and low mitotic activity. They are associated with a good prognosis and a significantly lower relapse rate.

questions.text: 50. A 16-year-old football player presented with left knee pain after an accidental fall. X-ray revealed the following findings. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An avulsion fracture of the tibial condyle over its anterolateral aspect is known as a Segond fracture. It is pathognomonic of an underlying anterior cruciate ligament injury.

Internal rotation with varus stress on a flexed knee, as seen in sports like football and soccer, can cause this injury. The fracture is caused by tension from the anterolateral ligament complex or lateral capsule, which avulses a small bone fragment during rotational stress. 

The classical appearance of a Segond fracture on an X-ray is that of a curvilinear or elliptic bone fragment projected parallel to the lateral aspect of the tibial plateau. The Segond fracture itself is not the main problem. Its presence serves as a red flag for a more serious ligament injury of the knee joint. It can be easily missed if not specifically looked for. A patient with a second fracture should undergo an MRI of the affected knee to delineate the associated underlying ligamentous injuries.

The fracture, per se, does not require treatment, but the associated ligamentous injuries might require surgical reconstruction based on the extent of injury.

Other Options: 

Option A: Maisonneuve fracture is a fracture of the proximal fibula associated with distal tibiofibular syndesmotic injury, disruption of the interosseous membrane, and either a medial malleolus fracture or deltoid ligament rupture at the ankle. 

The image below shows a Maisonneuve fracture.



Option C: Hoffa’s fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal femoral condyle, typically in the coronal plane. 

The image below shows Hoffa's fracture.



Option D: Cotton’s Fracture is a tri-malleolar fracture of the ankle, involving fractures of the medial malleolus, lateral malleolus, and the posterior malleolus, usually associated with ankle dislocation or subluxation.

The image below shows Cotton's fracture.

questions.text: 51. A middle-aged male came to the OPD with complaints of swelling over the anterior aspect of the neck for the past 4 months. On examination, the swelling moves with deglutition. Which of the following ultrasonographic features is diagnostic of malignancy?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a thyroid swelling. Macroscopic capsular breach is one of the diagnostic features of malignancy, although others are features of malignancy. 

A middle-aged male with a thyroid swelling is a case of high suspicion for malignancy. Ultrasonography (USG) is the first investigation of choice for thyroid swellings, for it is useful in picking up malignancy and is non-invasive. Only macroscopic capsular breach and nodal involvement are diagnostic of thyroid malignancy.

USG features in any thyroid neoplasia include:

* Macroscopic capsular breach

* Nodal involvement

* Hypoechogenicity (Option D).

* Irregular margins

* Microcalcification (Option A)

* Increased vascularity (Option C)

* Taller than wide shape

* Absence of halo (hypoechoic/anechoic rim surrounding the nodule).

The other investigations needed to evaluate thyroid swellings are thyroid function test, which is the first investigation, autoantibody titres to identify thyroiditis and lymphomas, fine needle aspiration cytology, radiological imaging like computed tomography scan, isotope scan, and ultimately histopathological examination of the operated specimen.

Pearl PM2352: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.



 It can be:

* X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or

* Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

* Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.

* Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: 53. A postmenopausal lady underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer. She presented a few weeks later with complaints of swelling around the incision site. The finding is as shown below. What is the 1st line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows the development of a seroma. It is initially treated with aspiration.

Seroma is a collection of fluid in a surgically created cavity, which results from the transection of vessels and lymphatics. It presents as a localized, well-circumscribed swelling with discomfort. The fluid is clear, yellow, and viscous. Closed suction drains that obliterate the space between the pectoralis major and skin flap are placed to prevent seromas. A seroma that reaccumulates after at least two aspirations is evacuated by opening the incision and packing the wound (Option B) with saline-moistened gauze. It is then allowed to heal with secondary intention.

Risk factors:

* Large skin flaps

* Mesh usage

* Premature drain removal

* Use of electrocautery

* Vigorous shoulder exercises post-procedure

Other options

Option C: Waiting and watching a seroma may lead to further extension of the cavity and in some cases superimposed infection.

Option D: Antibiotics are prescribed when seromas are chronic, long-standing, or infected.

questions.text: 54. Identify the ocular test performed in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows an ocular ultrasonography.

Ocular ultrasonography is a diagnostic imaging technique used in ophthalmology that relies on the 'pulse-echo' method. It employs ultrasonic frequencies for diagnostic purposes. The processed signal is displayed on cathode ray tubes in one of two modes: A-scan or B-scan.

The A-scan mode is mainly used to measure:

* Axial length for intraocular lens (IOL) power calculations

* Anterior chamber depth and other intraocular distances

The B-scan mode is used for:

* Assessing the posterior segment with opaque media

* Examining intraocular and orbital tumors

* Locating foreign bodies in the eye or orbit. 

Other options:

Option B: Optical Coherence Tomography (shown below) is a non-invasive imaging system that provides high-resolution cross-sectional images of the posterior segment. OCT is similar to B-scan ultrasonography but employs near-infrared light interferometry instead of sound waves.



Option C: Electroretinography (ERG) measures changes in the eye’s resting potential in response to a flash of light. It is conducted on a dark-adapted eye using an active electrode on the cornea and a reference electrode on the forehead.

Option D: Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is a diagnostic tool for evaluating various fundus disorders. It enables examiners to observe changes in blood flow of fluorescein dye through the retina and choroid, aiding in the identification and assessment of these conditions. Below is the image showing FFA of central retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text: 55. Which of the following is least preferred for giving intravenous contrast in a contrast-enhanced CT?
questions.solution:
Among the given agents, Diatrizoate is not preferred for intravenous injection because it is an ionic, high-osmolar contrast medium (HOCM).

Water-soluble iodinated contrast media are classified by osmolality into high-, low-, and iso-osmolar types. The higher the osmolality, the greater the risk of pain, allergic reactions, and nephrotoxicity. Therefore, non-ionic low- or iso-osmolar agents are preferred for intravenous use in contrast-enhanced CT.

Diatrizoate's osmolality is 4–5 times higher than plasma, leading to significant reactions and increased risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. Therefore, it is reserved for oral or rectal use in gastrointestinal contrast studies.

Other options:

Option A: Ioxaglate is an ionic dimer with intermediate osmolality, causing fewer adverse effects than traditional HOCM but still less preferred than non-ionic agents for intravenous use.

Option C: Iohexol is a non-ionic, low-osmolar contrast medium (LOCM) that is commonly used for intravascular administration in CECT due to its good safety profile.

Option D: Iodixanol is a non-ionic, iso-osmolar contrast medium (IOCM) whose osmolality equals that of plasma, making it a safe choice, particularly in patients with renal impairment, diabetes, or at high risk for contrast-induced nephropathy.

questions.text: 56. An oral diabetic drug which stimulates AMPK and inhibit gluconeogenesis can also be used for which of the following therpeutic purpose?
questions.solution:
Metformin is an oral diabetic drug that stimulates AMP kinase and can be used for ovulatory dysfunction as an adjuvant therapy in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) patients with glucose intolerance.

Metformin is a type of medication known as a biguanide, commonly used to manage type 2 diabetes mellitus as an oral hypoglycemic agent. It acts by activating the AMP-dependent protein kinase, thus stimulating hepatic fatty acid oxidation, glucose uptake and preventing gluconeogenesis.

By improving insulin sensitivity and reducing hyperinsulinemia, metformin helps restore menstrual regularity and ovulation in some women with PCOS. It is beneficial for those with insulin resistance or glucose intolerance.

The most common side effects of metformin are gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, indigestion, abdominal cramps, bloating, and diarrhea. The use of metformin is also associated with lower blood levels of vitamin B12.

Other options:

Option B: Lactic acidosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of metformin, not a therapeutic use.

Option C: Metformin is not used for treating contrast nephropathy. In fact, it should be withheld in at-risk patients undergoing contrast studies.

Option D: Metformin has no therapeutic role in alcohol use disorder, and alcohol increases the risk of lactic acidosis when combined with metformin.

questions.text: 57. A patient who recently travelled to North America for a trip presents with ulcerative lesions on the face and extremities, with shortness of breath and cough for the past 1 month. Culture is performed to confirm blastomycosis. The organism shows:

choices.text: Mycelial form at 25℃, yeast form at 37℃
Both yeast and mycelial forms at 37℃
Mycelial form at 37℃, yeast form at 25℃
Both yeast and mycelial forms at 25℃

questions.solution:
Blastomycosis, also known as Gilchrist's disease, is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, which on culture yields mycelial form at 25℃ and yeast form at 37℃.  

Blastomycosis, caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, is endemic to North America. The most common presentation is pulmonary blastomycosis, resembling tuberculosis. Cutaneous lesions such as papules, ulcers, and verrucous plaques may also occur, especially in disseminated disease.

Culture is the gold standard diagnostic method. Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungus that, on Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA), shows:

* Mycelial form at 25°C: Filamentous septate hyphae with numerous round or oval conidia. Older cultures may show chlamydospores.

* Yeast form at 37°C: Thick-walled, round yeast cells (8–15 µm) showing single broad-based budding (classically a “figure-of-8” appearance).

Cutaneous lesions and yeast form showing the “figure-of-8” appearance:



Example of some other dimorphic fungi:

* Histoplasma capsulatum

* Coccidioides immitis

* Paracoccidioides brasiliensis

* Sporothrix schenckii

* Talaromyces marneffei

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text:
58. A 55-year-old female patient presents with diminished vision, headache, and eye pain. She had a history of herpes infection. On examination, there is an increase in IOP. The ophthalmologist prescribes an eye drop for increased IOP. After a week, the patient presents with herpetic keratitis. Which of the following is the most likely drug to have favored the development of herpetic keratitis?

(IOP- Intraocular pressure)
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is the most likely drug to have favored the development of herpetic keratitis in this patient.

Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue and acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow thus reducing the IOP. Latanoprost is preferred over β-blockers due to its decreased systemic side effects. 

Prostaglandin analogues induce the release of endogenous prostaglandins in the iris and ciliary which enhances the cell-to-cell spread of HSV resulting in reactivation of the herpes infection. 

Adverse effects:

* conjunctival hyperaemia

* eyelash thickening 

* iris pigmentation 

* promotion of herpetic keratitis in a patient with a history of herpes infection

* if used preoperatively, cystoid macular edema following cataract surgery

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a bilateral, symmetrical disease with an adult-onset type. In this condition, there is an increase in the IOP due to trabecular sclerosis leading to decreased aqueous outflow. The clinical features include headache, difficulty in dark adaptation, frequent change of glasses, and blurring of vision. 

On ocular examination, an open anterior chamber angle, glaucomatous optic nerve head changes, visual field defects, and an increased IOP of more than 21mmHg are noted.

Other options:

Option A: Timolol is a non-selective β-blocker that decreases the IOP by reducing the aqueous humor production through blockade of the β-receptors on the ciliary epithelium. The adverse effects include:

* Ocular effects are allergy, decreased corneal sensation, and punctate keratitis

* Systemic effects-

* Potentially fatal bronchospasm in asthmatic patients and reversible airway diseases due to blockade of β2 receptors in bronchial smooth muscle

* Heart blocks, bradycardia, worsening of heart failure, and hypotension are some of the cardiovascular adverse effects

Option C: Brimonidine is a selective alpha-2 agonist which decreases aqueous synthesis and increases uveoscleral outflow. It can cross the blood-brain barrier and, hence, causes drowsiness and CNS depression. It is contraindicated in infants and children.

Option D: Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases IOP by reducing aqueous formation. The main adverse effect is the bitter taste following administration. It is contraindicated in people with allergies to sulfonamide antibiotics.

questions.text: 59. A patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on one side. Which of the following best explains these findings?

choices.text: Skull base erosion affecting CN VI

questions.solution:
The triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis indicates Horner syndrome, which, in the context of nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), is caused by tumor extension to the cervical sympathetic chain.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. NPC often spreads to surrounding structures, including the parapharyngeal space, where it can invade the cervical sympathetic plexus, resulting in Horner syndrome. This manifestation is part of ophthalmoneurologic involvement, which is a known pattern in advanced NPC.

Other options:

Option A: Skull base erosion affecting CN VI causes diplopia and lateral rectus palsy, not Horner syndrome.

Option B: Involvement of the cavernous sinus leads to multiple cranial nerve palsies (III, IV, V1, VI), not isolated sympathetic dysfunction.

Option D: Retropharyngeal lymph node compression leads to neck stiffness or mass effect but not Horner syndrome.

Pearl PM2092: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

* Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).

* Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).

* Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

* Mild enophthalmos,

* Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,

* Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,

* Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.



In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: 60. A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, drowsiness, and massive splenomegaly. Lab results reveal leukocytosis and thrombocytosis. The peripheral smear is shown below. All of the following are true about this condition except:

choices.text: There are no known familial associations
t(9;22) BCR-ABL (190 kDa) is commonly detected
Accelerated phase is defined by 10–19% blasts
Myeloid to erythroid ratio is more than 15:1

questions.solution:
The case described, alongside the peripheral smear image, is indicative of Chronic Myeloid Leukaemia (CML), which commonly harbours the t(9;22) BCR-ABL fusion gene encoding a 210 kDa BCR-ABL protein, not the 190 kDa protein.

The 190 kDa BCR-ABL protein, resulting from a different breakpoint in the BCR gene, is commonly seen in Philadelphia chromosome-positive Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia (Ph+ ALL) and rare cases of CML. When present in CML, this variant is associated with a worse prognosis.

CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm with no documented familial pattern (option A). The disease is classified into three stages:

* Chronic Phase (blasts <10%)

* Accelerated Phase (10–19% blasts, option C)

* Blast Crisis (>20% blasts)

Bone marrow in CML exhibits marked hypercellularity and a significantly increased myeloid to erythroid (M:E) ratio, often greater than 15:1 (option D). Characteristic features include scattered macrophages with green-blue cytoplasm, dwarf megakaryocytes, and pseudogaucher cells. The peripheral blood smear in CML closely resembles bone marrow morphology, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: 61. A 17-year-old female patient presented with primary amenorrhea. On examination, she is found to have normally developed breasts and swelling in the right inguinal region and female-type external genitalia. Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal the uterus or cervix. The karyotype is 46XY. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings in the question are seen in androgen insensitivity syndrome/ testicular feminizing syndrome. In this syndrome, the affected individual has testes producing the androgens, but the response of the androgen receptors to androgens is defective.

The findings of the given case can be explained as follows:

* Primary amenorrhea - Due to the absence of uterus and cervix.

* Normally developed breasts - Due to the conversion of the excessive androgens into estrogen.

* Swelling in the inguinal region - Suggestive of an underdeveloped ectopic testis, due to loss of action of testosterone on its receptor.

* Absence of uterus and cervix - Due to the production of mullerian inhibiting substance from the sertoli cells of the testis.

* The XY karyotype indicates that the patient is a genotypic male.

Option A - Swyer's syndrome : although the karyotype is 46XY, the testes are dysgenetic and do not produce androgens. As a result the external genitalia resemble that of a female. The Mullerian system is preserved as the dysgenetic gonads fail to produce anti Mullerian hormone.

Option C - Mullerian agenesis is another cause of primary amenorrhea characterised by absent uterus, fallopian tubes, cervix and upper vagina. The secondary sexual characteristics are preserved due to the presence of estrogen producing ovaries. However the karyotype is 46XX.

Option D - Turner's syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping reveals 45XO and the individual has streak ovaries and absent secondary sexual features.

questions.text: 62. A 13-month-old child brought to the PHC is tagged as a "Zero-Dose" child. What is the defining criterion for this classification?

choices.text: Child given only birth doses: BCG, OPV, HepB
Child who missed the first Pentavalent dose by 12 months
Child who hasn't received 2 doses of fIPV by 12 months
Child who has missed all the doses of OPV by 12 months

questions.solution:
Zero-dose children are those who have not received any basic vaccines. Operationally, this is defined as children who have not received the first dose of the Pentavalent vaccine by 12 months of age.

It is calculated by subtracting the number of infants vaccinated with the first dose of the Pentavalent vaccine from the total number of surviving infants in the same age group. In other words,

Zero-Dose Children = Surviving Infants − Infants vaccinated with Pentavalent-1.

The Zero-Dose percentage (ZD%) is then calculated as:

ZD% = 100 − (Coverage percentage of Pentavalent-1)

The WHO Immunisation Agenda 2030 (IA2030) identifies the number of zero-dose children as a key equity indicator. Its impact goal includes reducing the number of zero-dose children by 50% by 2030 at the national, regional, and global levels.

Other options:

Option A, C and D: All these children have received some vaccines but missed others as per the national immunisation schedule, categorising them as partially vaccinated or drop-out children.

questions.text:
63. A 30-year-old man presents with progressive jaundice and fatigue. Abdominal examination reveals hepatomegaly. His facial expression reveals a peculiar, fixed-grin-like appearance. He also suffers from dysarthria and tremors. His lab values are given below. A Liver biopsy was ordered, which shows the given finding. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the patient’s condition?

AST-120U/L ALT- 130U/L Total bilirubin- 4.2 mg/dl AST- Aspartate Aminotransferase ALT- Alanine Aminotransferase

choices.text: Coombs' positive hemolytic anemia is seen
MRI brain shows Mercedes Benz sign

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and biopsy image showing ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes are suggestive of Wilson’s Disease and it shows Mercedes Benz sign on MRI brain.

MRI findings reveal multiple findings in the Basal Ganglia, like Basal ganglia hyperintensity, Face of Giant Panda sign, Bisected and Trisected Pontine Hyperintensity (Mercedes Benz Sign), Bright Claustrum sign. 

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene on Chromosome 13q. It is characterised by impaired copper excretion into bile and failure to incorporate copper into ceruloplasmin, leading to toxic copper accumulation, mainly in the liver, brain, and cornea.

Hepatic involvement is often the earliest and most prominent, with liver biopsy typically showing fatty changes such as ballooned hepatocytes, prominent Mallory hyaline bodies, moderate to severe portal inflammation, hepatocyte necrosis, and perisinusoidal fibrosis. The periportal zone is most commonly involved. Neurologically, patients may develop tremors, dysarthria, risus sardonicus, dystonia, and psychiatric symptoms due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia. 

A hallmark ocular finding is the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings, green to brown deposits of copper in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on slit-lamp examination. It is most commonly present in patients with neurologic involvement. Renal tubular dysfunction can lead to abnormal electrolyte loss due to the direct effect of copper toxicity. Rickets and Osteoporosis can occur due to renal loss of calcium and phosphorus.

In acute presentations, Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia is commonly present, as it is also due to the direct toxic effect of copper (Option A). Low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels, increased urinary copper excretion (>100µg/24 h) (Option B), and increased hepatic copper content (Option D)are the characteristic laboratory findings.

Treatment with chelating agents like penicillamine or trientine, and zinc therapy is the mainstay.

questions.text: 64. An intern noticed the following findings while removing the catheter in a 30-year-old patient. A manual reduction was attempted but was unsuccessful and hence a dorsal slit was made. Surgery was planned 3 weeks later. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition and the definitive procedure, done for this patient?

choices.text: It is precipitated after sexual intercourse
It is associated with dorsal chordee

questions.solution:
The clinical history and the image showing swollen glans are suggestive of paraphimosis and circumcision is the definitive procedure done after 3 weeks. It is not associated with dorsal chordee but can lead to ventral chordee. 

Paraphimosis is a condition in which the retracted prepuceal skin over the glans cannot be placed back as a result of which a ring-like constriction is seen proximal to the corona and prepuceal skin. 

This leads to pain and swelling of the glans. Sexual intercourse (Option B) and urethral catheterization can precipitate the condition. 

Treatment includes manual reduction of the skin. When it is not possible, a dorsal slit has to be made to relieve the pain and compression along with analgesics and antibiotics. This is followed by circumcision after 3 weeks. Alternatively, Sedation and multiple hyaluronidase injection in 10 ml saline are injected to reduce edema followed by circumcision. 

Circumcision is a surgical procedure which involves cutting the dorsal skin up to the corona later extending it circumferentially and ventrally. 

Indications for circumcision include

* Religious

* Phimosis - In this condition, the prepuce cannot be retracted over the glans.

* Paraphimosis after doing initial dorsal slit

* Balanitis and balanoposthitis - Balanitis is the inflammation of the glans, whereas balanoposthitis involves both glans and prepuce

* Early carcinoma of the glans penis or prepuce—Here it is both diagnostic as well as therapeutic

* Certain sexually transmitted diseases, e.g. herpes infection

Complications:

* Infection

* Reactionary hemorrhage - It can be due to slippage of ligature from the frenular artery and dorsal vein (Option A)

* Urethral stricture near the external meatus in children

* Chordee due to removal of excess skin on the ventral aspect-Ventral chordee

* Priapism can occur rarely (Option C)

questions.text: 65. An elderly male patient was brought to the OPD with a whole body isotope uptake study for regular follow-up of his thyroid malignancy. His records are suggestive of papillary thyroid carcinoma, which has been recurrent. However, you observe that there is no uptake in the scan. What is the likely reason?

choices.text: Papillary carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignancy
It arises from parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland
The tumour has lost its iodine avidity
The patient has developed iodine deficiency

questions.solution:
In recurrent thyroid malignancies, wherein multiple doses of radioiodine treatment have been given, the tumour loses its iodine avidity. This is known as radioiodine-refractory disease. 

Radioiodine (I131) can be given to deliver tumoricidal doses of radioactivity directly to the thyroid tissue, both benign and malignant. For radioiodine to act effectively, high levels of TSH are required. This is done by making the patient hypothyroid (off thyroxine) or administering recombinant TSH before the radioiodine therapy. 

Following radioiodine administration, a uptake study is performed. The entire body’s uptake of thyroid can be used to identify any metastatic disease that is not recognised on initial imaging. It helps in risk assessment following initial therapy. Apart from this, radioiodine therapy is useful in cases of recurrence. Multiple doses are useful in unresectable, recurrent, or cases with distant metastasis. 

Differentiated cancers usually take up iodine in uptake studies. However, with advancing age and if the disease is multiply recurrent, ie the tumour has recurred repeatedly despite treatment, it loses its avidity to iodine, called radioiodine refractory disease. External beam radiotherapy is considered in such cases. 

Other Options: 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma is the prototype example of a differentiated tumour of the thyroid.

Option B: It arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid. The tumour that arises from the parafollicular cells of the thyroid is medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option D: Repeated administration of iodine causes refractoriness and not deficiency.

questions.text: 66. Which of the following clinical findings would typically be seen in a patient with an injury to the bulbar urethra?
questions.solution:
Butterfly perineal hematoma is the typical finding seen in the bulbar urethral injury.



Marked bruising of the penis, scrotum, and pubic area is commonly associated. Urethrogram with water-soluble contrast is used for confirmation of the diagnosis.

Option C: Cobb's collar refers to the congenital narrowing of the bulbar urethra seen in patients with posterior urethral valves.

Option D: Deep pelvic extravasation of urine (in the deep perineal pouch) is typically seen in patients with injury to the membranous urethra only.  In contrast, bulbar urethral injury leads to extravasation of urine in the superficial perineal space, scrotum and the lower anterior abdominal wall.

questions.text: 67. During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants, it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

* LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.

* As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.

* There is delayed separation of the cord, which is usually associated with infection of the cord stump.

There are three types of LAD:

* LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 

* LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.

* LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

Other options:

Option A: Persistent urachus will usually present as a urine leak from the umbilicus.

Option B: An umbilical granuloma is seen due to the proliferation of tissues at the umbilicus, usually once the stump falls off.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency causes hemolytic anemia secondary to drugs such as the sulfa drugs, primaquine, etc. Consumption of fava beans and certain infections also may lead to hemolysis.

Pearl PM1572: Defects in Leukocyte Function

Disease

Defect

Mutations in fucosyltransferase

Chediak–Higashi syndrome

Decreased leukocyte functions because of mutations affecting protein involved in lysosomal membrane traffic (LYST)

Chronic granulomatous disease

Decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO-H2O2 system


Pearl PM2352: Chronic granulomatous disease

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is due to the defect in NADPH oxidase. This interferes with the killing of bacteria by oxidative burst. Hence, the patients are at increased risk of infection from catalase-positive bacteria.



 It can be:

* X linked - Defect in one of the membrane-bound components (gp91phox) or

* Autosomal recessive - Cytoplasmic components (p47phox and p67phox)

Diagnosis of CGD includes:

* Nitroblue tetrazolium test - This is the standard for phagocyte oxidase activity measurement. The colorless compound NBT is reduced to blue formazan by the activity of the functional phox enzyme system. Normally, more than 95% of the granulocytes will be positive. The NBT is negative in CGD due to absence of phox enzyme activity.

* Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test - The most accurate diagnostic test for CGD. Normally functioning phagocytic cells oxidize DHR to the strongly fluorescent compound rhodamine which is quantified by flow cytometry.

questions.text: 68. Riya lives with her mother, younger brother, and maternal grandparents. Her parents separated two years ago, and her father no longer lives with them. What type of family does this represent?
questions.solution:
Riya lives in a family in which her parents have separated, which means this represents a broken family. 

A broken family is a family where the parents are separated or where one or both parents have passed away.

Other options:

Option A: Problem families are those that fall behind the rest of the community in terms of living standards. In such families, life conditions are often well below the accepted minimum, and parents struggle to fulfill the physical and emotional needs of their children.

Option B: A joint family includes several married couples and their children living together in a single household.

Option C: A nuclear family comprises a married couple and their dependent children living together.

Pearl PM0845: The Family as a Social Organization

* A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.

* It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.

* The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

* Types of families:

* A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.

* The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.

* A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.

* A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.

* A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.

* Functions of the family:

* Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)

* Division of labour

* Reproduction and raising children

* Socialization and social care

* Economic functions

* Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.

* Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text:
70. A 50-year-old obese female, a non-smoker and non-alcoholic, presents with complaints of pain in the right upper quadrant. Her lab findings are given below. USG shows diffuse steatotic changes. Which of the following is the next best step in her management?

AST=118U/L ALT=137U/L TAG=210 mg/dl FBS 150 mg/dl

AST- Aspartate Aminotransferase ALT- Alanine Aminotransferase TAG- Triacylglyceride FBS- Fasting blood sugar
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD). The next best step in management is risk stratification i.e., to calculate the fibrosis score.

NAFLD is characterized by excessive fat accumulation in the liver in the absence of significant alcohol consumption. It represents a spectrum:

* Simple steatosis: Fat accumulation without inflammation or fibrosis.

* Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH): Steatosis plus hepatocellular injury (ballooning degeneration, necrosis, inflammation).

* Fibrosis/Cirrhosis: Advanced stage leading to chronic liver disease.

The clinical features include asymptomatic in most cases, right upper quadrant discomfort (from hepatic capsular stretching), acanthosis nigricans — marker of insulin resistance, and features of chronic liver disease like palmar erythema, spider angiomas, jaundice, splenomegaly, ascites.   The laboratory findings seen in NAFLD are elevated levels of Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). Ultrasound findings include increased liver echogenicity, reflecting diffuse steatotic changes.   Risk Stratification (Next Step): Before initiating treatment, fibrosis assessment is essential to identify patients at risk for progression to cirrhosis with non-invasive scoring systems like:

* NAFLD Fibrosis Score includes Age, BMI, Diabetes status, AST/ALT ratio, Platelet count, Albumin

* FIB-4 (Fibrosis-4) Score 

Calculate the NAFLD Fibrosis score to assess risk of fibrosis.

* Low risk: Manage in primary care with lifestyle modification.

* Intermediate/High risk: Refer for FibroScan (transient elastography) to assess hepatic stiffness (Option D)

* If FibroScan suggests advanced fibrosis → confirm with Liver biopsy (gold standard) (Option B)

The mainstay of treatment for NAFLD is lifestyle modifications. Vitamin E (Option C) can be used as an antioxidant to reduce oxidative stress. Vitamin E is used with caution in diabetics and heart disease patients.

questions.text: 71. A 14-year-old boy presents with high-grade fever for 5 days and severe pain with swelling over the right leg. On examination, the limb is red, warm, and tender, and there is restriction of movement due to pain. Laboratory findings show leukocytosis and elevated ESR/CRP. X-ray of the right leg is normal. What is the next best in management?
questions.solution:
The next best line of treatment for this patient is empirical antibiotic therapy, as all features of acute osteomyelitis are present clinically in this case. These include a red, warm, tender right leg with restriction of movement due to pain. Laboratory findings also show leukocytosis and elevated ESR/CR, further strengthening the diagnosis of acute osteomyelitis. 

If osteomyelitis is suspected on clinical grounds, blood and fluid samples should be taken for laboratory investigation, and then treatment started immediately without awaiting final confirmation of the diagnosis.

There are four important facets to the management of a suspected case of acute osteomyelitis

* Appropriate antimicrobial therapy (first empirical, then specific).

* Surgical drainage of pus if required

* Splinting and the rest of the affected part

* Supportive treatment for pain and dehydration.

Blood and aspiration material are sent immediately for examination and culture, but the prompt intravenous administration of antibiotics is so vital that treatment should not await the result. Once the culture report comes, antibiotics can be changed accordingly. But initially, early empirical broad-spectrum antibiotic administration needs to be started.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common at all ages, but treatment should also provide cover for other bacteria that are likely to be encountered in each age group. Factors such as the patient’s age, general state of resistance, renal function, degree of toxaemia, and previous history of allergy must be taken into account.

For neonates and infants up to 6 months of age, the drugs of choice are flucloxacillin plus a third-generation cephalosporin such as cefotaxime. Alternatively, effective empirical treatment can be provided by a combination of flucloxacillin, benzylpenicillin and gentamicin.

For children of 6 months to 6 years of age, empirical treatment is best provided by a combination of intravenous flucloxacillin and cefotaxime or cefuroxime. In older children and previously fit adults, the vast majority in this group will have a staphylococcal infection and can be started on intravenous flucloxacillin and fusidic acid.

Other Options:

Option A: MRI of the affected limb can be helpful in cases of doubtful diagnosis. It will help in demonstrating bone marrow inflammation. It is extremely sensitive, even in the early phases of bone infection, and it can therefore assist in differentiating between soft-tissue infection and osteomyelitis. However, it need not be taken in a clinically obvious case of Acute osteomyelitis. 

Option B: Immediate surgical debridement, as the x-ray is unremarkable, further radiological scans can be done to look for the presence of an abscess. It can be debrided under empirical antibiotic coverage, and the sample collected can be sent for culture

Option D: Bone Scan with Technicium 99- Radioscintigraphy with Technicium 99 reveals increased activity in both the perfusion phase and the bone phase. This is a highly sensitive investigation, even in the very early stages, but it has relatively low specificity, and other inflammatory lesions can show similar changes.

questions.text: 72. As a surgery intern, you are asked to check for the presence of Blumer shelf nodules in a 55-year-old female patient, who is a known case of gastric cancer. Which of the following methods will you use?
questions.solution:
Blumer shelf nodules indicate metastatic tumour deposits in the pouch of Douglas/ retrovesical pouch, identified on per rectal examination. It is seen in cases of advanced gastric cancer. 

A complete history and physical examination should be performed in patients with gastric cancer, with special attention to any evidence of advanced disease. Heme-positive stool and hard nodularity extraluminally and anteriorly may be seen on a rectal examination, indicating Blumer shelf nodules. It can also be seen in advanced cases of pancreatic, colonic or lung malignancies.

It is one of the atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma. Other atypical presentations of gastric carcinoma include:

* Virchow's node

* Supraclavicular sentinel lymph node involvement 

* Sister Mary Joseph's nodule

* Due to periumbilical metastasis. 

* Seen in both gastric cancer (most common) and ovarian cancer. 

* Krukenberg’s tumour

* Bilateral ovarian metastasis

* Due to retrograde lymphatic spread

* Irish nodule

* Left axillary lymphadenopathy.

* Trousseau syndrome

* Migratory thrombophlebitis

* Leser Trelat sign

* Multiple seborrheic keratoses

* Resolves after gastrectomy

* Tripe palms

* Hyperkeratosis palm.

questions.text: 74. Identify the critical path
questions.solution:
The critical path is 1 → 2 → 5 → 7 → 10. The longest path of the network is called the critical path.

* Option A is the longest path (2 + 3 + 3 + 3 = 11 days).

* Option B = 2 + 2 + 2 + 2 = 8 days

* Option C = 2 + 4 + 4 = 10 days

A delay on the critical path will delay the entire project.

Pearl PM0164: Network Analysis in Health Management

A network is a graphic plan of all events and activities to be completed in order to reach an end objective. Two types of network analysis: PERT and CPM

1. Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)

* An arrow diagram of all events in logical sequence is drawn.

* Time to finish each activity can be calculated and critical activities can be identified.

* It aids in planning, scheduling and monitoring of the project.



2. Critical Path Method (CPM)

* The longest path of the network is called the critical path.

* A delay in the critical path will cause a delay in the entire project.

questions.text: 75. A 42-year-old male patient was brought to the casualty following blunt trauma to the abdomen. His vitals are stable and examination reveals a positive Kehr's sign. What is the investigation of choice for the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
A positive Kehr's sign in a patient with a history of blunt abdominal trauma is suggestive of splenic injury. CECT is the investigation of choice for the evaluation of this patient, as he is hemodynamically stable.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament, leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by a subphrenic hematoma leads to a positive Kehr's sign.

Initial investigation for abdominal injury in hemodynamically unstable patients is FAST (focused assessment with sonography in trauma) to explore for free fluid. In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterising splenic injuries.

The management of splenic injury is given below:



Pearl PM1368: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale



Pearl PM1369: Indications for Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) in splenic trauma

Indications :

* Patient younger than 55 years

* Grade I, II, or III (in selective cases) splenic injury

* Physiologic stability, as indicated by normal blood pressure, lack of tachycardia, absence of physical examination findings indicating shock, and absence of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: 77. A 38-year-old female presents with a photosensitive rash as shown below. She also complains of having hair loss and myalgia for the past 3 months. Investigations showed low serum complement level. Which of the following features is true regarding the patient's condition?

questions.text: 78. A patient with fatigue, fever, and abdominal pain for the past 1 week presents to you after travelling to different cities and having street food. PICC - Peripherally Inserted Central Catheter
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the given X-ray is a chemoport insertion.

Chemoports are totally implantable venous access devices used to facilitate the administration of chemotherapy and other long-term intravenous treatments. On a chest X-ray, the chemoport appears as a subcutaneous metallic port chamber, typically located in the infraclavicular region, connected to a radiopaque catheter that courses through the subclavian vein and terminates in the superior vena cava.

They are used for long-term venous access in patients receiving chemotherapy or prolonged intravenous therapy. The internal jugular and subclavian veins are the most commonly used access veins for port placement. These devices can be retained for 1 to 2 years or longer, after which they are safely explanted once therapy is completed.

Below is an image of the chemoport:



Other options:

Option A: Peripherally inserted central catheters (PICCs) are used for parenteral nutrition and long-term intravenous therapy. They are inserted through the upper arm veins and advanced until the catheter tip lies in the superior vena cava. A chest X-ray showing PICC placement is given below.



Option C: A central venous catheter (CVC) is an indwelling device inserted into a large central vein and advanced until the terminal lumen resides within the inferior vena cava, superior vena cava, or right atrium. The following image shows central venous catheterisation:



Option D: A transvenous pacemaker is a temporary pacing device used to manage arrhythmias. The pacing lead is inserted through a central vein into the right ventricle to maintain cardiac rhythm. The following image shows a chest X-ray after transvenous pacemaker insertion.

questions.text: 81. A patient presents with LMN-type facial weakness as shown in the image below. Thorough investigations were done which did not reveal any significant abnormality. The doctor as a diagnosis of exclusion prescribed him prednisolone for 5 days and he recovered 3 weeks later. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Right facial nerve is affected and weakness of right half of face
Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the contralateral side
Corner of the mouth is drawn to affected side
Left facial nerve is affected and weakness of right half of face

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of acute onset facial paralysis recovering within 3 weeks, a classical case of Bell's palsy, where the right half of this patient's face is weak, and the right facial nerve is affected.

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. The onset of Bell's palsy is fairly abrupt. 

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, facial muscle weakness, poor eyelid closure, etc., can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralized to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of artificial tears and covering the eye at night prevents corneal drying.

Approximately 85 to 95% of patients recover fully. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favourable prognostic sign. Recurrences are seen in some cases. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigation.

questions.text: 82. Which of the following is a method of transport in cytopempsis?
questions.solution:
Transport in cytopempsis, i.e. transcytosis, involves both endocytosis and exocytosis.   

Transcytosis refers to the transport of macromolecules, such as plasma proteins, across endothelial cells. The process begins with endocytosis on the capillary (luminal) side and ends with exocytosis on the interstitial side. The vesicles involved are typically caveolin-coated, and this process is also termed vesicular transport or cytopempsis.

Other options:

Option A and B: Phagocytosis is a type of endocytosis in which bacteria, dead cells, or other microscopic materials are engulfed by cells such as polymorphonuclear leukocytes in the blood.

Option D: Pinocytosis, known as cell drinking, is also a type of endocytosis process in which vesicles of small size and the substances ingested are in solution.

questions.text:
83. Which of the following are used for measuring glomerular filtration rate?

* Creatinine 

* p-Aminohippuric acid 

* Inulin

* Urea
questions.solution:
Creatinine (1) and Inulin (3) are used for measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR). 

GFR is the volume of plasma filtered by the glomeruli per minute, and it can be estimated by measuring the plasma concentration and urinary excretion of a substance that is freely filtered but neither reabsorbed nor secreted.

Inulin clearance is considered the gold standard for measuring GFR because inulin is freely filtered at the glomerulus and neither reabsorbed, secreted, nor metabolised by the renal tubules.

Creatinine clearance (CCr) is the most commonly used clinical method to estimate GFR. Although accurate, it slightly overestimates true GFR since a small amount of creatinine is secreted by the renal tubules.

Other statements:

Statement 2: p-Aminohippuric acid (PAH) is not used for GFR measurement. It is employed to estimate renal plasma flow (RPF), as PAH is both filtered and secreted, resulting in almost complete plasma clearance in one renal passage at low doses.

Statement 4: Urea is not a reliable marker for GFR because it is reabsorbed in the renal tubules, especially in states of dehydration or low urine flow.

questions.text: 84. A 1-day-old term neonate has oxygen saturation levels slightly higher than expected at the same arterial PO₂ as the mother. What is the cause of enhanced oxygen affinity in the given clinical scenario?

choices.text: Enhanced Bohr effect in fetal hemoglobin
Reduced affinity of fetal hemoglobin for 2,3-BPG
Increased activity of bisphosphoglycerate mutase in fetal RBCs
Absence of the Rapaport–Luebering cycle in fetal red blood cells

questions.solution:
This enhanced oxygen affinity in fetal hemoglobin is due to reduced affinity of fetal hemoglobin for 2,3-BPG.

Fetal hemoglobin (HbF) has a higher affinity for oxygen because it binds poorly to 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG), a compound that normally reduces the oxygen affinity of adult hemoglobin (HbA). This reduced interaction is due to the replacement of β-chains (in HbA) with γ-chains in HbF, which alters the 2,3-BPG binding site.

* In adults, 2,3-BPG binds to the central cavity of deoxyhemoglobin, stabilizing the T (tense) state, promoting oxygen unloading, and shifting the oxygen dissociation curve to the right.

* In fetal hemoglobin, this interaction is weaker, so HbF remains in the R (relaxed) state longer, holding onto oxygen more tightly, resulting in a left shift of the oxygen dissociation curve.

This allows for efficient placental oxygen transfer from mother to fetus.

The different causes for the shift to the right and shift to the left are shown in the image below:



Other options:

Option A: Fetal hemoglobin causes a left shift of the dissociation curve and hence has a reduced Bohr effect compared to HbA, not enhanced.

Option C: Bisphosphoglycerate mutase makes 2,3-BPG, but it does not explain HbF’s higher O₂ affinity. Moreover, the activity of bisphosphoglycerate mutase is also reduced in fetal RBCs as compared to that in adults.

Option D: Rapoport–Luebering cycle is a metabolic shunt in red blood cells that produces 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) from 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate during glycolysis. Fetal RBCs have an active Rapoport–Luebering cycle, and the higher O₂ affinity of HbF is due to weaker binding of 2,3-BPG to γ chains, not the absence of the cycle.

questions.text:
85. Which of the following congenital infections is most likely to present with active retinochoroiditis in adolescence due to reactivation?

VZV - Varicella-Zoster virus HSV - Herpes simplex virus
questions.solution:
Toxoplasmosis is the congenital infection most likely to present with active retinochoroiditis during adolescence due to reactivation of dormant tissue cysts.

Congenital toxoplasmosis, caused by Toxoplasma gondii, is often subclinical at birth. When symptomatic, it may present with the classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications. The parasite forms tissue cysts in the retinal tissue that can reactivate later in life, especially during adolescence or early adulthood.

Transmission occurs following primary maternal infection in an immunocompetent woman. First-trimester infections usually cause severe fetal disease, whereas third-trimester infections are more likely to be milder.

Reactivation leads to focal necrotising retinitis, which appears as retinochoroiditis, often presenting with:

* Blurred vision

* Floaters

* Photophobia

* Visual field defects

The fundus exam typically shows active retinal lesions with surrounding chorioretinal scars.

Other options:

Option A: Congenital rubella may cause salt-and-pepper retinopathy, which is non-progressive and does not reactivate. Vision loss is usually static and presents early, if present at all.

Option B: While reactivation of latent VZV occurs (e.g., herpes zoster ophthalmicus), it’s not a manifestation of congenital infection. Congenital varicella syndrome typically causes limb hypoplasia, cutaneous scars, and CNS defects, but not reactivating retinitis.

Option C: Congenital HSV is rare and typically presents in the neonatal period with skin, eye, or CNS disease. HSV-related retinitis (e.g., acute retinal necrosis) is not a typical congenital reactivation phenomenon in immunocompetent adolescents.

questions.text: 86. A 28-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks of gestation with a known history of preeclampsia presents with generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Magnesium sulfate was administered. She is now hemodynamically stable, and there are no further seizures. There is no evidence of fetal distress. On PV examination, the cervix is dilated up to 2 cm. Which of the following is the next best step in her management?

choices.text: PGE2 pessary followed by artificial rupture of membranes
Wait and watch till 37 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Eclampsia. As the patient is stable and has no further seizures, and the cervix is only 2 cm dilated, the next best step in the management of this patient will be to give PGE2 pessary followed by artificial rupture of membranes.

At 35 weeks, the fetus is sufficiently mature, so corticosteroids are not routinely required at this stage. Usually, patients go into labor spontaneously after convulsions. In case it fails to happen, then further management depends upon control of seizures and the maturity of the fetus.

If seizures are controlled:

* Pregnancy ≥34 weeks, Immediate delivery is indicated (Option B)

*

* If the cervix is favorable, surgical induction by low rupture of the membrane is done.

* If the cervix is unfavorable, PGE2 gel/pessary is used before ARM

* C-section is not required unless there are obstetric indications such as fetal distress or failure to progress in labor.

* Pregnancy <34 weeks,

*

* Steroids are given (Option C), and delivery is done in a facility with a NICU (Neonatal Intensive Care Unit)

If seizures are not controlled within 6-8 hrs, termination of pregnancy should be done. Low rupture of membranes with oxytocin for induction can be tried. But if unfavorable factors are present, a Cesarean section is advised. Cesarean section (Option D) is indicated if eclampsia occurs in pregnancy <30 weeks of gestation with an unfavorable cervix, uncontrolled seizures occur despite treatment, malpresentation, or for any other obstetric indication. Following delivery, 10 IU Oxytocin is given to prevent Postpartum hemorrhage. MgSO₄ is given for another 24 hours after the last seizure or delivery (whichever is later).

questions.text: 87. FDA recently approved Tirzepatide, a dual GLP and GIP receptor agonist, for which of the specific conditions?
questions.solution:
The FDA has approved Tirzepatide for the treatment of moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in adults with obesity. 

OSA is characterised by episodes of complete or partial airway collapse, resulting in decreased oxygen saturation, fragmented, non-restorative sleep, and excessive daytime sleepiness. The drug has been previously approved for: 

* Type 2 diabetes mellitus

* Obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2 or > 27 kg/m2 in the presence of obesity-associated comorbidities)

Tirzepatide (subcutaneous injection) is a dual GLP-1 and GIP receptor agonist. This stimulates insulin release from the pancreas, combating hyperglycemia and increasing the levels of adiponectin. This enhances weight loss, which in turn improves OSA. The most common adverse side effects are nausea, diarrhea, constipation and abdominal pain.

Other Options:

Option A: It is contraindicated in people with a family history of medullary carcinoma thyroid or MEN-2

Option B: It is not used to treat Acute Pancreatitis. Its safety in patients with pancreatitis is not established, and therefore, caution is advised.

Option D: Tirzepatide is not indicated for the treatment or prevention of cholesterol gallstones.

questions.text: 88. A patient presents with right-sided flank pain and hematuria. The microscopic examination of his urine specimen is shown below. A diet low in which of the following amino acids could theoretically be beneficial for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with right-sided flank pain, hematuria and hexagonal crystals on microscopic examination of the urine points to the diagnosis of cystine stones. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the urinary excretion of cystine.

Cystinuria occurs due to a hereditary defect in an amino acid transporter in the renal proximal convoluted tubule and intestine. This prevents the reabsorption of amino acids like cystine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine. The only known complication of this disease is the formation of calculi, because of the low solubility of cystine in the urine. Cystine is more likely to precipitate in acidic urine.

Prevention of stone formation in patients with cystinuria can be done by increasing fluid intake and alkalinization of the urine with sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate. Chelating agents such as penicillamine have also been found to be useful. Tiopronin is currently the best choice drug for cystine reduction, but side effects like nephrotic syndrome may limit its long-term use. A diet low in methionine may theoretically reduce the excretion of cystine in the urine by directly reducing its formation, as shown below.



Pearl PM0311: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones



Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text:
89. Match the following enzymes with their disorder:

Enzymes Disorders
1. Argininosuccinate synthetase a. Hyperammonemia Type I
2. Argininosuccinate lyase b. Citrullinemia
3. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I  c. Argininosuccinic aciduria
4. Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) d. Hyperammonemia Type II
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Enzymes Disorders
1. Argininosuccinate synthetase b. Citrullinemia
2. Argininosuccinate lyase c. Argininosuccinic aciduria
3. Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I a. Hyperammonemia Type I
4. Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) d. Hyperammonemia Type II


Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I) catalyses the first step of the urea cycle, converting ammonia and CO₂ to carbamoyl phosphate. Its defect causes Hyperammonemia Type I due to the inability to detoxify ammonia.

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency leads to accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which is diverted to pyrimidine synthesis, resulting in elevated orotic acid and Hyperammonemia Type II. It is the only X-linked urea cycle disorder.

Argininosuccinate synthetase enzyme catalyses the condensation of citrulline and aspartate to form argininosuccinate. Its deficiency leads to the accumulation of citrulline in blood and urine, hence the disorder citrullinemia.

Argininosuccinate lyase enzyme splits argininosuccinate into arginine and fumarate. When deficient, argininosuccinate accumulates, leading to argininosuccinic aciduria, often presenting with brittle hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: 90. A 7-year-old boy from a rural area presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. He is icteric and has elevated liver enzymes. History reveals he consumed home-stored groundnuts over the past few weeks. Which of the following could have prevented this outcome?

choices.text: Floating the seeds in 20% salt water

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of aflatoxicosis. It is prevented by keeping the moisture content <10%.

Aflatoxicosis is caused by aflatoxins produced by fungi like Aspergillus flavus and parasiticus. These fungi infest stored food grains, such as groundnuts, maize, wheat, rice, and sorghum, and require moisture levels above 16% and temperatures between 11 °C and 37°C to produce toxins. Aflatoxins mainly affect the liver.

Proper storage of foodgrains after drying and keeping the moisture content below 10% prevents the growth of these fungi.

Other options:

Option A: Floating the seeds in 20% salt water is a method for removing ergot-infested grains due to Claviceps purpurea.

Option B: Deweeding the crop helps prevent endemic ascites and epidemic dropsy. Endemic ascites is caused by pyrrolizidine alkaloids found within Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia seeds. Epidemic dropsy is due to contamination of mustard seeds with Argemone mexicana seeds that contain sanguinarine.

Option C: Parboiling helps in the prevention of neurolathyrism due to a toxin called BOAA found in the seeds of Khesari daal.
