questions.text: 91. A 30-year-old female presents in the emergency following two episodes of painless spotting per vagina preceded by amenorrhea for 8 weeks. She complained of lightheadedness and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and the pulse rate is 138 beats/minute, with a positive urine pregnancy test. What should be the management of this patient?

choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate
Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario implies a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy and the management of this patient would be a laparotomy.

The given clinical scenario implies a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy, suggested by:

* History of amenorrhea for 8 weeks

* Bleed per vaginum: amenorrhea of >4 weeks preceding the current vaginal bleeding suggests an ectopic gestation.

* A positive urine test: suggestive of pregnancy.

* Unstable vitals: suggestive of internal blood loss.

An unstable patient with these findings should undergo urgent surgical exploration, ie, laparotomy. It reduces hemorrhage and hemodynamic instability, also giving a better view of the operating field for the surgeon.

Other options:

Option A: IV fluids followed by methotrexate are prescribed in unruptured cases if the patient satisfies the criteria for medical management of ectopic pregnancy.

Option C and D: Suction evacuation and dilatation, and curettage are done in cases following abortion. In case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, they are not likely to be beneficial.

questions.text: 92. A doctor performed Fincham’s test on a patient presenting with colored halos and blurred vision. During the test, colored halos are observed to remain intact. Which of the following is the definitive treatment for the presenting disease?
questions.solution:
In Fincham's test, colored halos of primary angle closure glaucoma remain intact, in which peripheral laser iridotomy is the definitive treatment. 

Primary angle-closure glaucoma occurs due to the sudden blockage of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris, leading to a rapid rise in intraocular pressure. The patient usually presents with severe eye pain, headache, nausea, blurred vision, and colored halos around lights, often accompanied by a mid-dilated, fixed pupil and red eye.

Fincham's test is used to distinguish between colored halos caused by cataracts (lenticular halos) and those caused by corneal oedema due to glaucoma. The test is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos. When the halos break into segments that revolve as the slit moves, this indicates the presence of lenticular halos. In contrast, intact halos with reduced intensity are observed in cases of glaucoma.

Peripheral laser iridotomy (Nd: YAG laser or Argon Laser) is the treatment of choice for all stages of primary angle-closure glaucoma, after the control of intraocular pressure. The opening should be at least 150-200 microns in size, in the mid-peripheral iris at 1 or 11 o’clock position.

Other options: 

Option B and C: Small-incision cataract surgery and phacoemulsification are extracapsular cataract extraction surgeries for adult cataracts. 

Option D: Pars plana vitrectomy is done in cases of retinal detachments, endophthalmitis, and vitreous haemorrhage.

Pearl PM2204: Fincham’s Test

Also called Emsley–Fincham Test

It used for differentiating between the colored halos due to cataract (lenticular) and those in corneal edema due to glaucoma. It is performed by passing a stenopaic slit across the pupil and observing the halos.

Halos are broken up into segments which revolve as the slit moves → Lenticular halo

Intact halos but the intensity and brightness are diminished → Glaucomatous halo



The image shows a stenopaeic slit.

It causes reduced size of blur circle in the meridian perpendicular to the slit and no change in the blur circle in the meridian coincident with it. So, it can be used to determine the axis of the cylinder in astigmatism.

In cases with corneal opacity, the optimal site for optical iridectomy is determined using a stenopaic slit.

questions.text: 93. All of the following are true about Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs) except:

choices.text: OAEs are preserved in VIIIth nerve lesions
OAE can be used for early detection of noise-induced hearing loss
OAEs can be affected by middle ear pathology
OAE are absent in retrocochlear lesions

questions.solution:
Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are present in retrocochlear lesions.

Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are sounds generated by the activity of outer hair cells in a normal cochlea. These sounds can be recorded using a sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal. OAEs are useful in evaluating cochlear function, particularly in newborn hearing screenings, as they are present when outer hair cells are healthy and absent when there is damage to the cochlea. OAEs are passive, non-invasive, and do not require active cooperation, making them ideal for use even after mild sedation, particularly when testing uncooperative or mentally challenged patients

OAEs are preserved in VIIIth nerve lesions (Option A), as they reflect the function of outer hair cells in the cochlea, not the auditory nerve. In VIII nerve (retrocochlear) pathologies, such as vestibular schwannoma or auditory neuropathy, the outer hair cells remain structurally and functionally intact, so OAEs are typically preserved. The presence of OAEs with abnormal auditory brainstem response (ABR) is a key finding in auditory neuropathy.

Noise-induced hearing loss can also be detected using otoacoustic emissions(Option B). Transient evoked OAEs (TEOAEs) are widely used for newborn hearing screening due to their quick, non-invasive nature and ability to detect mild to moderate cochlear hearing loss. They are evoked using brief click sounds and are sensitive to outer hair cell dysfunction.

Moreover, OAEs can be affected by middle ear pathology (Option C) as any conductive abnormality (e.g., otitis media, tympanic membrane perforation) can hinder sound transmission to and from the cochlea, resulting in absent or reduced OAEs, even when cochlear function is normal.

Pearl PM1754: OAEs - Otoacoustic emissions

It is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by the outer hair cells of a normal cochlea.

It is of two types:

* Spontaneous type- it is generated spontaneously and is present in 50% of normal individuals.

* Evoked types- also called Kemp echoes or cochlear echoes, are generated in response to sound stimulus and found in all individuals with normal hearing. The two subtypes are transient evoked and distortion product.

The applications are as follows:

* Screening test for neonates, infants, and small children for deafness due to inner ear causes.

* Helps to differentiate cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss- normal OAE indicates normal cochlea and hence retrocochlear pathology in a patient with sensorineural deafness.

* Early detection of noise-induced hearing loss- since it is generated by outer hair cells that are prone to damage by noise trauma.

questions.text: 94. A 10-year-old boy is taken up for emergency surgical exploration due to a suspected left sided testicular torsion. On table, the testis is deemed viable. What would be the suitable surgical decision in this case?
questions.solution:
Detorsion of the cord within 6 hours in a case of testicular torsion may salvage testis. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contra-lateral testes are fixed to the scrotum using non-absorbable sutures, as the anatomical predisposition would most likely be bilateral and use of absorbable sutures may lead to recurrence of torsion.

Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous. Early surgery undertaken to untwist the testis gives a better outcome .

The following are anatomical predispositions to testicular torsion:

* High investment of the tunica vaginalis causes the testis to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause in adolescents and is typically a bilateral abnormality

* Inversion of the testis. The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down.

* Separation of the epididymis from the body of the testis. This allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the epididymis.



Males in the age group of 10-25 years present with acute scrotal or groin pain with associated nausea and vomiting. On examination, the scrotum appears swollen and tender. The affected testis may be seen to be positioned higher (Deming's sign) while the contralateral testis may be seen to be position horizontally (Angell's sign).  

A doppler ultrasound may be taken to assess the blood supply but surgical exploration is still indicated as a clinical decision. If the testis is infarcted after the cord is untwisted, an orchidectomy must be undertaken and the opposite testis must be fixed to the scrotum to preserve fertility and prevent torsion. If the affected testis is viable after the cord is untwisted, both the affected and the contra-lateral testes are fixed to the scrotum (bilateral orchiopexy) using non-absorbable sutures.

questions.text: 95. Which of the following is a risk factor for primary postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Polyhydramnios is a risk factor for primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a loss of more than 500 mL of blood after the completion of the third stage of labor in vaginal delivery and more than 1000 mL in cesarean delivery.

Postpartum hemorrhage can be subdivided into primary PPH and secondary PPH. Primary PPH is bleeding that occurs within 24 hours of the delivery of the baby. Secondary PPH is bleeding that occurs beyond 24 hours of delivery and during puerperium. It is also known as delayed or puerperal hemorrhage.

Causes of primary PPH are atony, trauma, coagulopathy, and retained tissues. The atonic uterus can be caused by numerous factors that interfere with the contraction and retraction of the uterus.

The contributing risk factors for atonic hemorrhage are grand multipara, overdistension of the uterus due to multiple pregnancies or polyhydramnios or a big baby, anemia, antepartum hemorrhage due to placenta previa and abruption, prolonged labor, uterine fibroid, and placental implantation on the uterine septum of a septate uterus.

The causes of secondary PPH include retained membranes or placental cotyledons, infections like endometritis (Option C), and subinvolution of the placental site (Option A). Rare causes of secondary PPH are carcinoma cervix (Option D), chorioepithelioma, placental polyp, uterine arteriovenous fistula, and puerperal inversion of the uterus.

During labor, active management of 3rd stage of labor is known to decrease the risk of PPH by 60%. Carbetocin 100 micrograms IV can be used to prevent PPH.

Complications of PPH include shock, puerperal sepsis, pulmonary embolism, thrombosis, thrombophlebitis, Sheehan’s syndrome, and diabetes insipidus rarely.

questions.text: 96. A 25-year-old man presented with a slowly progressive swelling and pain in the middle of his right leg. On X-ray, multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions are seen in the tibial diaphysis. Microscopic examination of a biopsied specimen reveals epithelial cells in a fibrous stroma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Among the given tumors, adamantinoma is the most probable diagnosis based on the above-given clinical scenario.

Adamantinoma is a rare tumor of the diaphysis and presents commonly with pain. It usually presents in the 2nd or 3rd decade and arises from the epithelial cells. The most common site for adamantinoma is the tibia but it may also involve the ipsilateral fibula.

Radiological examination shows multiple sharply demarcated radiolucent lesions in the tibial diaphysis and a honeycomb/soap bubble appearance. Histology shows epithelial basaloid cell islands in a fibrous stroma.

Complete excision of the tumor is the treatment of choice.

The following image shows an X-ray and gross specimen of an adamantinoma.



Other options

Option B: Osteosarcoma is a metaphyseal tumour that shows periosteal reaction, represented by the Codman's triangle on X-ray. On histopathology, spindle cells producing bone matrix are seen.

Option C: Osteoclastoma or giant cell tumour is a benign epiphyseal tumour that shows 'soap bubble' appearance on X-ray and giant cells on histopathology.

Option D: Osteoid osteoma is also a benign tumour of the diaphyses; however, it presents with sharp pain, which is worse at night and is relieved on taking NSAIDs.

questions.text: 97. A 28-year-old overweight female presents with complaints of infertility despite regular unprotected intercourse with her husband for the past 3 years. Her USG findings are shown in the image below. The medical treatments advised by her previous doctors haven't given any results, so she prefers surgical management. Identify the incorrect option regarding the surgical management of her condition.

choices.text: Not more than two ovarian cysts are to be punctured in each ovary laparoscopically
Surgery is indicated if overstimulation occurs
Chromotubation and tubal testing can be done at the same time
Other causes of infertility like endometriosis can be assessed

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasound showing multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern suggest polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). The incorrect statement is not more than two ovarian cysts are punctured/drilled in each ovary in polycystic ovary syndrome. 

PCOS ovaries have multiple small cysts and thickened stroma that produce excess androgens. A few punctures (like 1–2) do not remove enough stromal tissue. Insufficient stromal destruction leads to no significant drop in androgen levels and there is no ovulation induction.

PCOS is a common endocrine disorder in a reproductive-age woman characterized by oligomenorrhoea, non-ovulation (infertility), obesity, and hirsutism. Rotterdam criteria are used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS

* Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism (alopecia, acne, hirsutism)

* Irregular menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhoea/non-ovulation)

* Polycystic ovaries

Surgery is indicated when medical treatment fails, overstimulation happens, infertile individuals, and loss of pregnancies in the past (Option B) 

Surgery comprises laparoscopic drilling with a minimum of 4 punctures in each ovary. It is done using a laser or by unipolar electrocautery. It restores the endocrinal balance and improves fertility for a year or so.

The advantages of surgery are as follows: 

* Chromotubation and tubal testing can be done at the same time (Option C) 

* One can search for additional infertility causes, such as endometriosis (Option D) 

* There is no need for extensive or continuous side effect monitoring

* Economical in contrast to IVF

* Decreases the synthesis of LH and androgen

* After surgery, medication is used to induce single ovulation to prevent hyperstimulation and multiple pregnancies 

* 60%–70% of women experience pregnancy, and 80–90% ovulate

The disadvantages of surgery are as follows:

* It involves giving anaesthesia and performing an invasive procedure like laparoscopy

* Adhesions may form postoperatively. Thereafter, pelvic adhesions caused by surgery may again reduce the fertility rate. 

* If cautery is used, premature ovarian failure due to destruction of ovarian tissue may be seen

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: 98. The following type of pulse can be seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
The pulse illustrated in the image is a dicrotic pulse that can be seen in sepsis.

A dicrotic pulse (pulsus dicroticus) is characterised by two peaks per cardiac cycle: one in systole and a second, smaller peak in diastole. This pulse type is commonly seen in the following conditions:

* Sepsis

* Fever

* Exercise

* Chronic severe aortic regurgitation

* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)

* Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation

This is seen when the pulse rate and diastolic pressure are low.

Other options:

Option A: Digoxin toxicity is associated with pulsus bigeminus, where each normal heartbeat is followed by a premature beat rapidly, after which there is a compensatory pause, as shown in the image below.



Option C: Aortic stenosis is associated with pulsus parvus (weak) et tardus (late), where the amplitude of the pulse is diminished and the upstroke is slow and delayed, as shown in the image below.



Option D: Constrictive pericarditis is associated with pulsus paradoxus, i.e., a fall of systolic blood pressure by more than 10 mmHg during inspiration. This is an exaggeration of a normal phenomenon and is shown in the image below.

questions.text: 99. Which of the following lenses is prescribed for a 50-year-old patient having no refractive error on examination, who complains of having difficulty in reading the newspaper and performing near vision tasks?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of presbyopia, for which a spherical converging lens or convex lens(plus lens) is prescribed.  

A rough guide for providing presbyopic glasses in an emmetrope can be made from the age of the patient:

* 45 years: +1 to + 1.25D

* 50 years: +1.5 to 1.75D

* 55 years: +2 to +2.25D

* 60 years: +2.5 to + 3D

Presbyopia is not an error of refraction but a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation leading to a progressive fall in near vision. Patients usually complain of difficulty in reading small print, asthenopic symptoms due to fatigue of the ciliary muscle, and intermittent diplopia. The treatment of presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work. 

Presbyopia is caused due to age-related changes in the lens, which include:

* Decrease in the elasticity of the lens capsule.

* Progressive increase in size and hardness of the lens.

* Age-related decline in ciliary muscle power may also.

* Premature presbyopia causes are uncorrected hypermetropia, premature sclerosis of the crystalline lens, presenile weakness of the ciliary muscle, and chronic simple glaucoma.

Other Options: 

Option A: A spherical diverging lens is used for the correction of myopia. 

Option C and D: Concave and convex cylindrical lenses are used for the correction of astigmatism.

questions.text: 101. A child with polyuria and muscle weakness is suspected of having a renal tubular syndrome. Which of the following features helps distinguish Gitelman Syndrome from Bartter Syndrome?
questions.solution:
The feature that helps distinguish Gitelman syndrome from Bartter syndrome is hypocalciuria.

Gitelman syndrome presents with hypocalciuria, whereas Bartter syndrome presents with hypercalciuria.

Gitelman syndrome and Bartter syndrome are rare autosomal recessive disorders affecting the renal tubules.

Defective site Distal convoluted tubule Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle

Bartter syndrome generally causes a more severe clinical presentation.

* Metabolic alkalosis (Option A)

questions.text:
102. A 7-day-old infant was brought with complaints of severe intractable diarrhoea and dehydration since birth. Small intestinal biopsy findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?

Image A – PAS staining Image B – CD10 staining
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, along with the histopathological image, is suggestive of a malabsorption syndrome caused by Microvillous Inclusion Disease (MVID).

Microvillous Inclusion Disease, also known as Davidson disease, is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the MYO5B gene, resulting in defective vesicular transport and poor formation of the intestinal brush border.

Histopathology shows severe villous atrophy with diffuse PAS-positive inclusions near the apical region of enterocytes, while CD10 immunostaining demonstrates absent or markedly reduced apical staining (red arrows) with cytoplasmic granules/inclusions representing microvilli inclusions. Other diagnostic methods include electron microscopy, which reveals the presence of abnormal vesicles, and immunostaining for the brush border protein villin.

In normal enterocytes, CD10 staining shows continuous linear apical membrane positivity, as illustrated in the image below.



Malabsorption syndrome refers to a spectrum of conditions of various etiologies that arise due to diminished absorption of one or more dietary nutrients. The general features of malabsorption syndrome are abdominal pain, diarrhoea, steatorrhea, and weight loss.

Other options:

Option A: Autoimmune Enteropathy is an X-linked disorder presenting with severe, persistent diarrhea and autoimmune manifestations in young children. Histologically, it shows increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, though fewer than in celiac disease, and the presence of neutrophils, which distinguishes it from celiac disease.

Option C: Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive metabolic disorder, resulting from an inability to assemble triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Histopathology reveals epithelial vacuolization due to triglyceride accumulation, which can be visualised using oil red-O staining. The following is a high magnification image of the histopathological slide of a small bowel biopsy showing clear enterocytes due to triglyceride accumulation:



Option D: Congenital lactase deficiency is a condition where lactose cannot be broken down due to a lactase enzyme deficiency, leading to osmotic diarrhea as lactose remains in the intestinal lumen and draws fluid.

questions.text: 103. ASHA provides home-based services under the Home-Based Care of Young Child (HBYC) programme. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this program?

choices.text: It includes five half-yearly home visits by the ASHA
ASHA receives ₹250 after completing all scheduled visits
Nutrition and early childhood development are key domains
Promoting and supporting full immunisation is included as a task

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about the Home-Based Care of Young Child (HBYC) programme is that it includes five half-yearly home visits by the ASHA.

The HBYC programme is an extension of the HBNC programme and involves five quarterly home visits by ASHAs, supported by Anganwadi workers, starting from 2-3 months of age. These visits occur at the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th, and 15th months and focus on interventions in four key domains:

* Nutrition

* Health

* Child development

* WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene)

ASHAs receive an incentive of ₹250 (₹50 per visit) upon completing all scheduled visits under the HBYC programme (option B).

Promoting and supporting full immunisation falls under the health domain and is typically addressed between the 2nd and 5th visits (option D).

Pearl PM0156: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

* Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow

* Must be a resident of that village

* Formal education of up to 10th standard 

* If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard

* At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 

* In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

* Health education and awareness

* Reproductive and child health and family planning

* Facilitate the access to health services

* Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction

* Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments

* Provider of DOTS

* Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.

* Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres

* Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

* 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)

* 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

* A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).

* ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: 104. A 55-year-old female presents to the emergency department with acute chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and jaw. Cardiac troponin is positive, and the ECG shows ST-depression. Which of the following ECG waves is characteristically related to this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the ECG finding, points towards a diagnosis of NSTEMI (Non-ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction). The ST-depression associated with this condition is either downsloping (option B) or horizontal.

NSTEMI results from subendocardial ischemia due to partial occlusion of a coronary artery by a ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with platelet aggregation. The myocardial injury is sufficient to elevate cardiac biomarkers (Troponin I or T) but does not produce ST-segment elevation.

Typical clinical features of NSTEMI:

* Retrosternal chest pain radiating to the left arm, shoulder, or jaw, which may occur at rest or with minimal exertion.

* ECG findings: ST-segment depression and/or T-wave inversion (without ST elevation).

* Elevated cardiac biomarkers: Positive troponin I or T confirming myocardial necrosis.

ST-segment depression in NSTEMI may present in various patterns, but downsloping or horizontal depression is most specific for ischemia, whereas upsloping or sagging patterns have different implications.

ST depression most commonly indicates myocardial ischemia but may also occur with ventricular hypertrophy, bundle branch block, digoxin effect, or hypokalemia. It can also appear as a reciprocal change in posterior MI.



Other options:

Option A: Shows a normal ECG finding, with no ST-segment depression.

Option C: Shows an upsloping ST-segment, which is non-diagnostic and may be seen physiologically after exercise.

Option D: Shows sagging or scooping of the ST-segment, also known as the Salvador Dali sign (shown below), which is characteristic of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: 105. A 60-year-old male presented with fever, chills, and cough with sputum. Later, a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia was made. Which of the following is not a criterion of severe community-acquired pneumonia?

choices.text: Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 20 mg/dL or higher
PaO2/FiO2 ratio less than or equal to 250

questions.solution:
Hyperthermia, or an elevated temperature above 38°C, is not used as a criterion to classify severe community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). Hypothermia, defined as a core body temperature below 36°C, is one of the minor criteria for classifying severe CAP.

The criteria for classifying severe CAP are as follows:

Major Criteria:

* Respiratory failure requiring invasive mechanical ventilation

* Septic shock managed with vasopressor therapy

Minor Criteria:

* Respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute or more 

* Confusion or disorientation 

* PaO2/FiO2 ratio less than or equal to 250 (Option C)

* Multilobar infiltrates on chest imaging

* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 20 mg/dL or higher (Option A)

* Leukopenia (white blood cell count <4000 cells/μL) 

* Thrombocytopenia (platelet count <100,000 cells/μL) (Option D)

* Hypothermia with a core temperature below 36°C

* Hypotension requiring aggressive fluid resuscitation

questions.text:
106. Which of the given clinical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of class III hemorrhagic shock?

PR- Pulse rate; BP- Blood pressure
questions.solution:
A pulse rate of 126 bpm and decreased blood pressure of 80/50 mmHg fall under class III hemorrhagic shock.

Patients with hemorrhagic shock are classified based on their clinical signs and symptoms. According to this classification- a person with a pulse rate i.e PR >120 and decreased BP (blood pressure) falls under class III. Other features include an anxious or confused state, decreased pulse pressure, a respiratory rate (RR) between 30-40/min, and a urine output of 5-15 mL/hr. These patients can be replaced with crystalloids and blood. The blood loss is 30-40% in these patients.

Other options:

Option A: This comes under class I as the pulse rate is below 100 bpm and blood pressure is normal. Features include slight anxiety, normal pulse pressure, RR 14-20/min, and urine output >30 mL/hr. Crystalloids are useful.

Option C: This comes under class IV as the pulse rate is above 140 bpm and blood pressure is decreased. Confusion/ lethargy, decreased pulse pressure, RR >35/min, and negligible urine are seen. Crystalloids and blood transfusion are useful for these patients. 

Option D: This comes under class II as the pulse rate is between 100-120 bpm and blood pressure is normal. The patients falling under this class are mildly anxious with decreased pulse pressure, RR 20-30/min, and urine output of 20-30 mL/hr. Crystalloids are given to these patients.

questions.text: 107. A 48-year-old male patient presents with the given finding. He also has right-sided hemiplegia and exaggerated reflexes on the right side. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given picture shows LMN facial palsy on the left side. The presence of right-sided hemiplegia and exaggerated reflexes indicates right UMN palsy. Together, these two point to the diagnosis of Millard-Gubler syndrome.

Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to a lesion in the ventral pons. It presents with ipsilateral facial palsy due to the involvement of facial nerve fibres leaving the brainstem, and contralateral hemiparesis due to damage to the descending corticospinal tracts. In addition, there is a weakness of the lateral rectus muscle due to damage to the abducens nerve fascicle.

The other brainstem syndrome that occurs at the level of the pons is Foville's syndrome. It occurs due to a lesion in the dorsal part of the pons. The clinical presentation is similar to Millard-Gubler syndrome, except it presents with complete ipsilateral gaze palsy due to abducens nucleus lesion.

Other options:

Option A: Bell’s palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve that affects the ipsilateral upper and lower parts of the face. It is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or weakness that develops suddenly and without an identifiable cause. The condition typically has a rapid and abrupt onset.

questions.text: 108. With an increase in blood pressure, baroreceptors are activated. Which neurotransmitter is released by their afferent fibers at the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS)?
questions.solution:
On activation, baroreceptor afferent fibres release glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS). 

Baroreceptors are activated when the walls of the carotid sinus and aortic arch are stretched due to an increase in blood pressure. As the pressure rises, their firing rate increases. The afferent fibres carry impulses through the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves to the medulla, where they release glutamate to excite neurons in the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS), forming the first synapse in the baroreceptor reflex.

Neurons in the NTS activate those in the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM). The CVLM neurons release the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA (option A) into the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM), thereby reducing the firing rate of these neurons.

As a result, baroreceptor activation suppresses sympathetic nerve activity and enhances vagal stimulation of the heart, leading to vasodilation, venodilation, bradycardia, hypotension, and a decrease in cardiac output.

The image below illustrates the baroreceptor reflex pathway.



Other options:

Option C: Norepinephrine acts mainly as a neurotransmitter of postganglionic sympathetic fibres and as a neurohormone. It is not released at the NTS by sensory afferents.

Option D: Adenosine functions as a neuromodulator that causes vasodilation and can influence neuronal excitability, but does not serve as the primary transmitter in baroreceptor afferent synapses.

questions.text:
109. A 7-year-old boy presents with complaints of headaches, vomiting, and visual disturbances. An MRI of the head shows a lesion, which is sent for biopsy, and the HPE finding is shown below. What is the most likely radiological finding associated with this tumour?

HPE - Histopathological Examination

choices.text: Metastatic skull lesions with bone destruction
Mass arising from the fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and histopathological image are diagnostic of ependymoma, which typically presents as a mass arising from the fourth ventricle and often extends through the ventricular foramina.

Ependymoma is a posterior fossa tumour arising from the ependymal lining of the floor of the fourth ventricle. Ependymal cells are specialised glial cells that line the ventricles and the central canal of the spinal cord. They help produce and maintain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis within the nervous system.

On histopathological examination, ependymoma shows tumour cells arranged around blood vessels, forming perivascular pseudorosettes. Occasionally, ependymal rosettes are seen, which are gland-like, round or elongated structures resembling the embryologic ependymal canal, with delicate processes projecting into the lumen.

Radiological findings of ependymoma as shown below:

* Intraventricular mass arising from the floor of the fourth ventricle, often extending through the foramina of Luschka and Magendie

* Well-demarcated, lobulated lesion that may show calcifications and cystic changes

* Iso- to hypointense on T1-weighted MRI

* Hyperintense on T2-weighted MRI

* Hydrocephalus due to CSF pathway obstruction



Other options:

Option A: Intraocular mass with calcification is typical for retinoblastoma, which exhibits Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and fleurettes. These are true rosettes with an empty lumen.



Option B: Dural mass with “dural-tail” sign is characteristic of meningioma, a predominantly benign, extra-axial tumour attached to the dura. HPE shows whorled clusters of epithelial cells, as shown in the image below. Meningiomas are rarely seen in children.



Option C: Metastatic skull lesions with bone destruction occur in systemic malignancies such as neuroblastoma. Neuroblastoma shows Homer-Wright rosettes (shown in the image below), where the tumour cells surround a central neurofibrillary material–a pseudorosette.

questions.text:
110. In achalasia cardia, which of the following hormones acting on the lower oesophageal sphincter is defective?

VIP - Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide
questions.solution:
Achalasia cardia is a motility disorder in which VIP (vasoactive intestinal peptide) and NO (nitric oxide) are defective.

In this condition, the lower oesophageal sphincter (LES) fails to relax properly, causing retention of food and subsequent dilatation of the oesophagus. The condition arises from an elevated resting tone of the LES and a loss of inhibitory neuronal control, resulting in reduced release of nitric oxide (NO) and vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from the myenteric plexus.

Peristaltic activity begins as a reflex response to the distension of the gut wall caused by luminal contents. Normally, this stretching triggers NO and VIP release from anterograde cholinergic neurons to cause relaxation ahead of the bolus, while acetylcholine and substance P (option D) from retrograde neurons cause contraction behind it. A defect in NO or VIP release disrupts this coordination, producing achalasia.

The following image illustrates these events:



Other options:

Option B: Somatostatin primarily inhibits gastric acid secretion and pancreatic secretions and is not directly involved in LES relaxation.

Option C: Motilin stimulates gastric and intestinal motility during fasting and is unrelated to sphincter relaxation defects.

Pearl PM1301: Mechanism of peristalsis



Pearl PM1528: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

* Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

* Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

* Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)

* Regurgitation

* Chest pain

* Weight loss

* Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text:
111. A dedicated mobile health team plans to screen children aged 5 years living in a village under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK). Through which of the following community settings should they primarily conduct the screening for this age group?

RBSK - Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram
questions.solution:
The mobile health team (MHT) should target Anganwadi Centres to screen children aged 5 years.

The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) provides child health screening and early detection and management of the "4 Ds" prevalent in children: Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Childhood diseases, and Developmental delays and disabilities. This program covers children in the age group of 0 to 18 years.

For implementation, different facilities are targeted based on specific age groups:

* Newborns: Facility-based newborn screening at public health facilities (option A) and community-based screening, including household/home visits (option D) through ASHAs until 6 weeks of age.

* Children aged 6 weeks to 6 years: Screening by the mobile health team at Anganwadi centres (option C).

* Children aged 6 to 18 years: Screening by the mobile health team at government and government-aided schools (option B).

questions.text: 112. A researcher studies the correlation between the incidence of mesothelioma and asbestos exposure using the following study design and timeline. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The given flow chart depicts a study where the outcomes have already occurred before the start of the investigation. This is characteristic of a retrospective cohort study.

A cohort study is an analytical, forward-looking (prospective or longitudinal) design that progresses from exposure to outcome. It is one of the most reliable methods to establish an association between a risk factor and a subsequent disease. A prospective cohort study is expensive and time-consuming, unsuitable for rare diseases, and prone to attrition, confounding, and observer-related biases.

In contrast, in a retrospective cohort study, the outcomes have already occurred, and the researcher collects data from records and follows up until the present. These studies are less expensive and yield faster results compared to prospective ones.

Other options:

Option A: In a case-control study, the direction of investigation proceeds from the effect (disease) to the cause (exposure), because the outcome or disease has already occurred.

Option B: A prospective cohort study involves following individuals forward in time. In this type of study, the outcome has not occurred at the beginning of the investigation. The image given below shows a schematic diagram of a prospective cohort study.



Option C: In nested case-control studies, cases and controls are drawn from a larger pre-existing cohort, where the cohort was followed prospectively.

Pearl PM0268: Cohort Study

* A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).

* It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.

* Design of a cohort study:



* Types of cohort study:

* Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies

* Retrospective (historical) cohort studies

* Combination cohort studies

* Steps of cohort study:

* Selection of study subjects

* Obtaining data on exposure

* Selection of comparison groups

* Follow-up

* Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk

* Advantages of cohort study:

* Incidence can be calculated

* Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time

* Provides direct estimate of relative risk

* Calculation of dose-response ratio

* Minimization of certain biases

* Disadvantages of cohort study:

* Cannot use for uncommon diseases

* Expensive, requires a large population and longer time

* Many common administrative and ethical problems

* High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult

* Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate

* Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Pearl PM0265: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 



* Steps of case control study:

* Selection of cases and controls

* Matching

* Measurement of exposure

* Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio

* Advantages of case control study:

* Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive

* Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects

* Used to investigate rare diseases

* Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified

* No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems

* Disadvantages of case control study:

* Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias

* Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult

* Incidence cannot be measured

* Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors

* Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis

* Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: 113. The device shown in the image below is used to assess:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Placido keratoscope used to assess corneal topography.

It consists of multiple concentric circles from which light is projected onto the corneal surface. The reflection is viewed through a small hole in the centre or captured using a video camera for analysis. The reflection is distorted in corneal curvature abnormalities such as keratoconus. Software analysis can reveal additional information such as corneal power and render surface maps of the cornea.



Other options:

Option A and C: Synoptophore can be used for extraocular movements and strabismus.

Option B: Visual field defects can be evaluated using the Humphry field analyzer (HFA).

questions.text: 114. You are a part of the team spearheading a new experimental treatment modality for a rare type of cancer. When it is time for conducting human trials, ethical guidelines must be followed according to which of the following declarations?
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Helsinki gives a set of ethical principles directed to the medical community for human experimentation.

Pearl PM1820: Health-related International Declarations:

* Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.

* Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: 115. Which of the following is the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptor?
questions.solution:
Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. 

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest sensory receptors found in the skin, measuring approximately 2 mm in length and 1 mm in width. Present within the dermis of both hairless and hairy regions, these receptors contain a central nerve ending surrounded by multiple concentric lamellae of connective tissue, producing an onion-like pattern. They are particularly sensitive to rapid vibrations and deep pressure stimuli.

questions.text:
116. A 24-year-old patient presents with a history of urinary frequency, nocturia, and excessive thirst. Her laboratory evaluation results are given below. Brain MRI shows the absence of a bright spot in the pituitary. Her past medical history includes an episode of meningitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Parameter Value
Urine osmolarity <300 mOsm/L
Urine output >50 ml/kg/day
Random blood glucose 150 mg/dl
Antidiuretic hormone level (ADH) Decreased
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the lab results indicating increased urine output with low urine osmolarity and decreased ADH levels suggest the diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus. 

Diabetes insipidus can be of two types - central or peripheral (nephrogenic). Central DI occurs due to deficiency of ADH. 

Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is a disorder of the posterior pituitary. It is characterized by decreased ADH leading to large volumes of urine production. Patients present with excessive thirst, nocturia, and urinary frequency. The urine is dilute with an osmolarity of < 300 mOsm/L. The 24-hour urine volume is >40 ml/kg and the basal plasma ADH is <1 pg/ml.

Central DI occurs due to damage to the neurohypophysis in the posterior pituitary. It can be congenital or acquired. In this patient, meningitis has led to the development of DI. 

Central DI can be treated with desmopressin, an ADH analogue. Nephrogenic DI requires treatment with a thiazide diuretic, amiloride, low sodium diet, and indomethacin. 

In nephrogenic DI, ADH levels may be normal or increased because the kidney has become resistant to its effects. The two can be differentiated by the water deprivation test. (Option A)

Other options:

Option B: Primary polydipsia would have a bright spot on the brain MRI. Primary polydipsia presents with an excessive thirst that reduces the serum osmolarity. There is a compensatory increase in free water excretion that offsets the increased intake to maintain a normal serum sodium level. 

Option D: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion would have increased ADH secretion, concentrated urine, and hyponatremia.

Pearl PM1536: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality.

Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text: 117. A 40-year-old male patient who is a chronic smoker was admitted to the hospital for COPD and was prescribed a very long-acting beta 2 receptor agonist. Which of the following drug was prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Olodaterol is classified as a very long-acting beta 2 receptor agonist and can be used once daily in COPD maintenance.

Beta agonists are used for maintenance in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Based on their action, they are classified as follows:

* Short-acting beta-agonists (SABA): Albuterol, Levalbuterol, Pirbuterol, Terbutaline, Salbutamol (Option C)

* Long-acting beta agonists (LABA): Salmeterol, Formoterol,(Option A and B, used twice daily), Arformoterol

* Very Long-acting beta agonists: Indacaterol, Olodaterol, Vilanterol

questions.text: 118. A farmer who handles hides of sheep presents with black eschar on his upper back. A swab was taken from the tissue for microbiological evidence on blood agar, as shown below. Which of the following is correct regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: Shows inverted fir tree appearance on Gram stain
Live attenuated vaccine is effective for human use

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis, for which a post-exposure 60-day antibiotic course is given. 

Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive, large, rectangular bacillus (Option A) which shows a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining (Option C), an amorphous purple capsule stained with methylene blue (McFadyean reaction), and an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin stab agar. 

Cutaneous anthrax, also known as hide porter’s disease, is characterised by a necrotic eschar and surrounding non-pitting edema, commonly found in dock workers carrying hides, and current CDC recommendation for postexposure prophylaxis is 60-days of antibiotics along with adsorbed anthrax vaccine for pre-and post-exposure prophylaxis in humans, while the live attenuated vaccine is used as a single dose in animals, not safe for humans (Option D).

questions.text: 119. A person states to his psychiatrist, "I work for the Government and I am so important in my office that the other people will not be able to work without me". This is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The statement is characteristic of a narcissistic personality disorder.

A person with narcissistic personality disorder has a sense of self-importance, grandiosity, and is preoccupied with fantasies of success. They believe that they are special and require excessive admiration. They often react with rage when criticized and are often interpersonally exploitative.

Other options

Option A: A patient with histrionic personality disorder is excitable, overtly emotional, and behaves dramatically. They want to be the centre of attention and exaggerate everything, making it sound more important than it really is.

Option B: A person with antisocial personality disorder does not have regard for the rights of others and frequently violates them.

Option D: A person with borderline personality disorder has significant mood swings. History of unstable relationships/self-destructive acts is frequently present.

questions.text: 120. Which of the following features helps distinguish an ostium primum atrial septal defect (ASD) from an ostium secundum ASD?
questions.solution:
Left axis deviation on ECG differentiates ostium primum from ostium secundum atrial septal defect.

Ostium primum atrial septum defect(ASD) is a type of atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD), involving the lower part of the atrial septum and often associated with a cleft anterior mitral leaflet or other endocardial cushion defects. The ECG hallmark of ostium primum ASD is left axis deviation (LAD) with a superior QRS axis, which is uncommon in most acyanotic CHDs in children.

Ostium secundum is the most common type of ASD. It is located at the mid-intra-atrial septum. It presents with right ventricular hypertrophy due to a significant left-to-right shunt, sometimes causing a right axis deviation.

Other options:

Option A: Systolic murmur at the pulmonary area is seen in both primum and secundum ASDs due to increased pulmonary flow across the pulmonary valve.

Option B: Fixed splitting of S2 is characteristic of any ASD due to delayed pulmonary valve closure from constant left-to-right shunting.

Option D: A pansystolic murmur is seen in ASD with coexisting mitral regurgitation. An isolated atrial septal defect does not result in a pansystolic murmur.

questions.text: 121. A male patient presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of perianal pain and intermittent purulent discharge. Upon examination, he was found to have a perianal fistula. Identify the inter-sphincteric fistula in the image below.
questions.solution:
The intersphincteric fistula in the given image is 1.

The other structures marked in the image are: 

* 2-trans-shincteric fistula

* 3-supra-sphincteric fistula

* 4-extra-sphincteric fistula 

Fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary perianal skin opening and is lined with granulation tissue. The most common cause is a perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms:

* Perianal pain

* Discharge- intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

* Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.

* Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.



Exceptions to Goodsall’s Rule

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Investigations:

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

* Fistulogram

* Endoanal ultrasound

* MRI

* Computed tomography (CT) scan

* Endocoil MRI

* Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

An MRI is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

* Control of constipation

* Sitz bath

* Fistulotomy

* Fistulectomy

* Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)

* Setons

* Advancement flaps

questions.text: 122. A 5-month-old child was brought by the mother to the OPD with the following presentation. Which of the following is correct regarding the presenting condition?

choices.text: Always abnormal up to the age of 4 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and image suggest a diagnosis of infantile esotropia, in which there is alternate fixation in primary gaze. 

Infantile esotropia typically occurs within 6 months of age with no significant refractive error (option B) and no limitation of ocular movements. The angle of deviation is usually quite large, often exceeding 35 degrees, and remains constant.

Up to 4 months of age, occasional brief episodes of small-angle convergence can be physiologic (option A). However, persistent or constant misalignment beyond 4 months is considered abnormal.

Characteristically, binocular vision does not develop, resulting in alternate fixation in the primary gaze and cross fixation in lateral gaze. Specifically, the infant cross-fixates by using the right eye to fixate on targets presented to the left side of their head, and the left eye for targets on the right side. Amblyopia may be indicated if the infant consistently shows a preference for fixating with one eye.

Surgery is the treatment of choice, and amblyopia treatment by patching the normal eye should always be done before performing the surgery. 

Other option:

Option D: Accommodative esotropia, resulting from excessive convergence related to the accommodation reflex, usually develops between ages 2 and 3 often with hypermetropia.

questions.text: 123. A 40-year-old man presents with blurring of vision and the presence of a dark spot with distorted vision in his right eye for the past week. He has been taking steroid tablets for asthma. His best corrected visual acuity measured 6/24 in his right eye and 6/6 in his left eye. Fundus fluorescein angiography was done and it showed the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing smokestack appearance which is a small hyperfluorescent spot that ascends vertically like a smokestack that looks like an umbrella or a mushroom. It is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Central serous chorioretinopathy (CSR) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by a localized serous detachment of the sensory retina at the macula.

Risk factors:

* Age: young adults (20–50 years)

* Sex: male > female

* Steroid intake 

* Emotional stress

* Pregnancy

* Cushing's syndrome

* Hypertension

* Sleep apnea syndrome

It is mostly unilateral. Clinical features include sudden painless loss of vision, relative positive scotoma, micropsia, and metamorphopsia.

Investigations:

* Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent

* FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

* OCT - optically empty neurosensory elevation at macular region.

In the majority of cases, spontaneous resolution is observed. Steroids should be avoided. While the disease tends to be self-limiting, there is a possibility of recurrence. For recurrent and chronic cases, alternative treatment options include laser photocoagulation, photodynamic therapy, and intravitreal anti-VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) injections.

The image below depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/ enlarging dot sign. A small hyperfluorescent spot that gradually enlarges in size seen in central Serous Retinopathy (CSR).



Other options:

Option A: Cystoid macular edema is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. FFA shows a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance). Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression.



Option C: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.



Option D: Best's disease is a hereditary macular disorder which shows the presence of egg yolk lesion or scrambled egg lesion in the macula. The given below is the fundus picture of Best's disease showing an egg yolk lesion in the macula.

questions.text: 124. Which of the following is incorrect about the drug given in the image?

choices.text: Black box warning for cardiac events

questions.solution:
Loperamide, shown in the image above, is a peripheral μ opioid receptor agonist and not an antagonist.

It is an orally active antidiarrheal agent (Option B) and is effective against traveler’s diarrhea, used alone or in combination with antibiotics. It is not recommended for use in children under 2 years of age. Overdosing on this medication can lead to constipation, central nervous system (CNS) depression, and paralytic ileus, particularly in children (Option A).

The FDA has issued a black box warning for loperamide, indicating that exceeding the recommended dosage may lead to serious cardiac events, such as torsades de pointes, cardiac arrest, and even death (Option D). Additionally, in cases of inflammatory bowel disease affecting the colon, loperamide should be used with extreme caution, if at all, to prevent the risk of developing toxic megacolon.

questions.text: 125. A 60-year-old man with longstanding hypertension and left ventricular hypertrophy undergoes an elective Cholecystectomy. His baseline BP is 150/90 mm Hg. All of the following agents can be used to attenuate hypertensive response in this patient before intubation, except?

choices.text: Deepening anaesthesia with a volatile agent
Giving a bolus of an opioid

questions.solution:
Ketamine is not used to attenuate the hypertensive response before intubation because it increases sympathetic tone, leading to hypertension and tachycardia.

Induction of anesthesia and endotracheal intubation can lead to hemodynamic instability in patients with hypertension. Hypertensive patients may have  an accentuated hypotensive response to the induction of anesthesia, followed by an exaggerated hypertensive response to intubation. 

Drugs used to attenuate the hypertensive response act by:

* Deepening anesthesia with a potent volatile agent (Option A)

* Administering an opioid bolus (Fentanyl /Alfentanil/Sufentanil/Remifentanil) (Option B)

* Using lidocaine (1.5 mg/kg intravenously, intratracheally, or topically) (Option C)

* Beta-adrenergic blockade with Esmolol/Metoprolol/Labetalol

questions.text: 126. A person was found dead in suspicious conditions and was brought in by the police for an autopsy. On examination, bluish-green hypostasis was present over his dependent body parts. Which of the following poisons can cause this finding?
questions.solution:
Hydrogen sulphide poisoning can cause bluish-green hypostasis. It occurs from sewer gas or industrial exposure.

Postmortem hypostasis (also known as postmortem lividity or livor mortis or suggilation) refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin, seen on the dependent parts, due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity.

The timeline for the development of postmortem staining:

* Mottled patches in 1-3 hours following the death

* Uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours following the death

* Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis in 6-12 hours following the death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and intracranial lesions.  

* It persists until putrefaction sets in.

questions.text: 127. A 55-year-old man presents with a painless, slowly enlarging lymph node in the right cervical region, persisting for the last 3 months. The lymph node biopsy shows characteristic cells, as shown below. These cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20. What type of Hodgkin lymphoma is this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the immunohistochemistry findings indicate a diagnosis of classical Hodgkin Lymphoma. The image shows a mononuclear variant of the Reed-Sternberg cell, which is typically seen in Lymphocyte-rich Hodgkin Lymphoma.

Hodgkin lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm that arises in a single lymph node or chain of nodes and spreads first to contiguous lymphoid tissues. It usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. The diagnostic hallmark is the presence of Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells.

The RS cell is the characteristic tumour giant cell of Hodgkin lymphoma, derived from germinal centre B cells. It shows a classic “owl-eye” appearance, with a bilobed nucleus, prominent nucleoli, and a clear perinuclear halo.

Hodgkin lymphoma is broadly classified into the following subtypes as per the WHO:

Classical Hodgkin's lymphoma: CD15+, PAX5 and CD30+

* Nodular sclerosis: Lacunar RS cells

* Mixed cellularity: Mononuclear RS cells

* Lymphocyte-rich: Mononuclear RS cells

* Lymphocyte-depleted: Pleomorphic, necrotic, or mummified RS cells

Non-classical Hodgkin's lymphoma: CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EBV-.

* Nodular lymphocyte predominant: L&H (Lymphohistiocytic) or popcorn cells

The following image shows the classic and variant forms of Reed-Sternberg cells:



The following image shows popcorn cells seen in Nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma:

* Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 

* Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 

* L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: 128. A 17-year-old girl presents with lesions on her face as shown in the image. Similar lesions were absent in the chest and back. What management plan is suitable for her?
questions.solution:
The image shows typical erythematous papules and small nodules along with a few whiteheads are suggestive of moderate acne vulgaris. It should be treated with oral antibiotics and topical retinoids.

The severity of acne can be classified as:

Mild Open and closed comedones with few inflammatory papules and pustules
Moderate Papules and pustules mainly on the face, occasional inflamed nodules on the chest and back also
Severe Many large, painful nodules and pustules


The clinical severity and approach to treatment are decided based on the type of lesion and based on extensiveness.

Only comedonal types can be treated with topical retinoids.

Papulopustular type can be treated with topical retinoid combined with an antibiotic (topical or oral) based on severity. More oily skin and the occurrence of nodules should prompt oral antibiotics.

Nodular or conglobate type can be treated with oral isotretinoin.

questions.text: 129. Which of the following is an example of a lack of object permanence?

choices.text: Uncovering a hidden toy after seeing that it was hidden
Banging two toys against each other
Staring momentarily at the spot where the toy disappeared from

questions.solution:
Staring momentarily at the spot where a toy disappeared from signifies a lack of object permanence or constancy (out of sight, out of mind). This is seen at 2 months of age and disappears at 8-9 months of age when the milestone of object permanence is attained.

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when it is not seen. When an object is hidden, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age does not search for it and quickly gives up. However, a 9-month-old baby is able to understand that the hidden object continues to exist, will search for it, and be able to find it under a hidden cloth or behind the examiner's back. The child will enjoy the game Peek-a-boo at this stage of development.

The GIF below demonstrates object permanence.



Other options:

Option A: Uncovering a toy (after seeing it hidden) is an example of object permanence, seen by 8 months of age.

Option B: Banging two toys against each other signifies an active comparison of objects, seen by 8 months of age.

Option D: Pointing to toys signifies interactive communication, seen by 10 months of age.

Stares at own hand 4 Self-discovery
Bangs 2 cubes 8 Active comparison of objects

Egocentric symbolic play (e.g., pretending to drink from glass) 12 Beginning of symbolic thought
Uses stick to reach a toy
17		 Able to link actions to solve problems

questions.text: 130. A chronic smoker presented with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months. Mammography findings are given below. The Hadfield operation was carried out because of the involvement of multiple lactiferous ducts. What type of discharge is associated with this condition?

choices.text: Discharge from the surface of the nipple

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a chronic smoker with complaints of intermittent discharge from bilateral nipples for the past few months and mammography showing the characteristic broken needle calcification, is suggestive of duct ectasia which is associated with greenish discharge. 

Duct ectasia is associated with focal dilatation of the lactiferous duct system. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in non-lactating women. This condition is strongly associated with smoking.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts due to hormonally induced myoepithelial relaxation of the duct wall. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green-coloured secretions. The collection may be discharged as shown below.



In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, due to irritation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin. If the condition does not resolve, it can lead to the formation of a subareolar mass or abscess, and even mammary duct fistulas. Persistence of this condition eventually leads to fibrosis, which can cause slit-like retraction of the nipple.

Mammography reveals coarse rod and branching calcifications, described as broken needle calcification. This occurs due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation. This operation consists of the excision of all the major lactiferous ducts. If a single duct is involved, then a microdochectomy is performed.

Other options:

Option A: Intraductal papilloma is a benign condition wherein a wart-like growth occurs within the mammary ducts. They are made up of glandular and fibrous tissue and vascular vessels. It is associated with blood-stained discharge.

Option C: Galactorrhea is characterised by the spontaneous release of milky discharge from multiple ducts in both nipples. It may be associated with a prolactin-secreting adenoma of the pituitary gland. Drugs that lead to increased prolactin secretion and galactorrhoea include amitriptyline, metoclopramide and H2 receptor antagonists (cimetidine). 

Option D: Paget’s disease is characterized by nipple erythema and irritation. It is associated with pruritus and may progress to crusting and ulceration. It is associated with discharge from the surface of the nipple and not from within the nipple.

questions.text: 131. A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this disease?

choices.text: MRI is the gold standard modality of investigation
Seton's technique induces fibrosis and  has very good evidence of healing
Sphincter division can lead on to sphincter dysfunction and incontinence
Laying open fistulotomy shows improvement but does not eradicate the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of fistula-in-ano. Laying open fistulotomy is the definitive management method to eradicate the disease. 

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms include perianal pain and intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

* Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.

* Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.



However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

* Fistulogram

* Endoanal ultrasound

* MRI

* Computed tomography (CT) scan

* Endocoil MRI

* Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause the persistence of the fistula. (Option A)

Treatment:

* Control of constipation

* Sitz bath

* Fistulotomy

* Fistulectomy

* Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)

* Setons

* Advancement flaps

Other options:

Option B: Seton’s technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. If there is evidence of good healing, it is removed.

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those that are distal to the dentate line, loose placement of a seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

This may be converted to a cutting seton by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helping in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.



Option C: Laying open is the surest method of eradication, but sphincter division may result in incontinence due to sphincter dysfunction.

questions.text: 132. A 40-year-old male factory worker suffers second-degree burns on his forearm while operating machinery. He is certified by the ESI medical board as temporarily disabled and unable to work. Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act, for how long is he eligible to receive the disablement benefit?

choices.text: For a maximum of 91 days from the date of injury
Until the medical board declares him fit to resume work
Until the employer provides alternative duties
For up to 2 years, regardless of recovery status

questions.solution:
90% of the wages are paid in case of a temporary occupational injury until the medical board declares him fit to resume work

Disablement benefits are provided for both temporary and permanent occupational injuries. Under the Act, the insured person is entitled to cash compensation along with free medical care. In cases of temporary disablement, 90% of the wages are paid till temporary disability lasts.

For total permanent disablement, a lifelong pension is granted based on the loss of earning capacity assessed by a medical board, while in partial permanent disablement, a proportional pension is awarded according to the degree of disability.

Other options :

Option A: This refers to the sickness benefit, not the disablement benefit. Temporary disablement benefit is not time-limited to 91 days — it continues as long as the disability lasts and is certified.

Option C: Disablement benefit is not dependent on employer action. It is governed by medical certification from ESI authorities, not workplace arrangements.

Option D: This applies to extended sickness benefit for chronic illnesses, not to disablement due to injury. Disablement benefit ends once the person is declared fit.

Benefits

To the Employees

* Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

* Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.

* Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

* Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 

* The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.

Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.

* Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
