questions.text: 133. A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given karyotyping image shows trisomy of 21, which is seen in Down syndrome. A flat occiput is seen in Down syndrome.

Clinical features: 

* Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly

* Congenital heart disease

* Acute leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum

* Protruding tongue

* Flat face

* Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth

* Brachycephaly/Brushfield's spots (speckled irises)

* Low (depressed) nasal bridge

* Epicanthal fold/Dysplastic ears

* Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure)

* Simian palmar crease and a wider gap between the first and second toes

 The following images show Simian's crease and Brushfield's spots, respectively.





Other options:

Option B: Webbing of the neck and lymphedema can be seen in Turner’s syndrome (45 XO). The image below shows the webbing of the neck.





Option C: Short stature with polydactyly is most commonly seen in Patau syndrome or trisomy 13.



Option D: Disproportionately long arms and legs and gynecomastia can be seen in Klinefelter syndrome. Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY. This results from the meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division).

questions.text: 134. A young man presented with a rapidly moving serpiginous track like erythema as shown below. It started perianally and has spread in a few hours. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and history point towards a diagnosis of larva currens.

The term larva currens (meaning ‘racing larvae’) has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. They move rapidly, as fast as 10cm/hr.

Other options:

Option A: Scabietic burrows as shown below, caused by the itch mite of scabies due to laying of eggs are also serpiginous in form, but do not move rapidly as described in the question. They usually follow the circle of hebra.



Option B: Flagellate dermatitis is a misnomer, as there is no flagellated organism involved. It is rather caused as a side effect of the anticancer drug bleomycin. The image below shows flagellate dermatitis.



Option C: Cutaneous larva migrans, as shown below, is caused by hookworms (except Ancylostoma duodenale or Necator americanus). It may look serpiginous, but it does not move as rapidly as larva currens.

questions.text: 135. A 55-year-old man presents for evaluation of hematuria and reports a history of flank pain. He also has a family history of stroke in his father. A CT scan is provided below. Which of the following valvular lesions is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, along with the CT scan showing bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts, is characteristic of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD). The most commonly associated valvular lesion in ADPKD is mitral valve prolapse.

ADPKD is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the PKD1 gene, located on chromosome 16p (encoding polycystin-1) and the PKD2 gene on chromosome 4q (encoding polycystin-2). Because ADPKD is an inheritable condition, a positive family history of renal disease or related complications (such as stroke from aneurysmal rupture) is frequently present.

The disease typically manifests after the age of 30, though some individuals may remain asymptomatic or undiagnosed for years.

Clinical features include:

* Hypertension (most common)

* Palpable irregular renal mass in the upper abdomen

* Loin/ flank pain

* Hematuria

* Recurrent urinary infections

* Progressive renal failure leading to uremia

Extrarenal manifestations:

* Mitral valve prolapse (seen in up to one-third of patients)

* Less common valvular abnormalities: tricuspid valve prolapse and insufficiency of the mitral, aortic, or tricuspid valves

* Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis, which may rupture and cause subarachnoid haemorrhage

* Hepatic cysts, pancreatic cysts, and colonic diverticulosis

questions.text: 136. A 40-year-old sexually active male presents with multiple, recurrent oral ulcers for the past 1.5 years. He also complains of redness and pain in his eyes. The Pathergy test is positive. Which of the following features is true regarding the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Behcet’s Syndrome. It mimics Crohn’s Disease.

Behcet's Disease is a systemic vasculitis characterised by neutrophil hyperreactivity, affecting males more commonly. Intestinal symptoms mimic those of Crohn’s disease both clinically and endoscopically.

Oral Ulcers are seen in nearly all patients, usually as the first manifestation. They are painful (Option C), recurrent, and heal without scarring. Only the uncommon, major ulcers tend to scar. Recurrent genital ulcers are also common, especially on the scrotum or labia, deeper and scarred upon healing (Option B). Skin Lesions include papulopustular lesions and erythema nodosum-like lesions, often on the lower extremities. Superficial thrombophlebitis signifies venous involvement.

Non-erosive and non-deforming mono/oligoarthritis is seen in about half of cases (Option A). Eye Involvement is often bilateral in the form of Panuveitis. The presence of a hypopyon is another characteristic finding. It can involve deep veins and arteries, leading to the formation of pulmonary artery aneurysms and arterial aneurysms. The pathergy test is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction, unique to this disease.

Diagnosis is clinical, based on, Recurrent oral ulcers(3 times in 12 months period) plus ≥2 of:

* Recurrent Genital Ulcer

* Eye lesions

* Skin lesions

* Positive pathergy test

Oral ulcers, genital ulcers and other mucocutaneous lesions are treated with topical glucocorticoids. Resistant lesions are treated with colchicine, oral glucocorticoids and immunosuppressants. Poor prognosis is seen with male sex, patients with early eye/CNS involvement and frequent relapses.

questions.text: 137. A 40-year-old woman presents with persistent hiccups, paraplegia, and painful bilateral vision loss. Laboratory evaluation reveals the presence of anti–AQP-4 antibodies. The physician decides to initiate therapy with a B-cell depleting agent targeting CD19. Which of the following should be chosen?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, along with anti-AQP-4 antibody positivity, indicates Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO), also known as Devic’s disease. The B-cell depleter used in this condition is Inebilizumab.

Inebilizumab is a humanised anti-CD19 monoclonal antibody that depletes B cells that produce anti–AQP–4 antibodies in Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD). It is approved for relapse prevention and is given as an IV infusion every six months after an initial loading dose.

Neuromyelitis Optica (NMO) is an autoimmune inflammatory disorder characterised by antibodies directed against aquaporin-4 (AQP-4), a water channel protein located on astrocyte foot processes adjacent to endothelial surfaces. Patients who are anti-AQP-4 negative may have antibodies against myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG).

The core clinical characteristics include:

* Optic neuritis

* Acute myelitis

* Area postrema syndrome (unexplained hiccups, nausea,  vomiting)

* Acute brainstem syndrome

* Symptomatic narcolepsy

* Acute diencephalic clinical syndrome with NMOSD-typical diencephalic MRI lesions

* Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD-typical brain lesions.

Acute attacks of NMO are managed with high-dose glucocorticoids, and plasma exchange is employed if there is no response to glucocorticoids. Long-term relapse prevention involves immunosuppressive agents like mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, glucocorticoids, and azathioprine.

Three monoclonal antibodies recently approved for relapse prevention in NMO include:

* Inebilizumab (B-cell depleting agent, option C)

* Eculizumab (terminal complement inhibitor, option A)

* Satralizumab (IL-6 receptor blocker, option D)

Other option:

Option B: Ocrelizumab is a humanised anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody that depletes B lymphocytes. It is approved for relapsing and primary progressive multiple sclerosis, but not for neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

questions.text: 138. A child, while playing in a field, stepped his right foot over a sharp-pointed stone. Immediately, as a reflex action, he lifted his right leg and extended the left leg. The action of the left leg is attributable to which of the following reflexes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, when the right foot is placed on the sharp stone, the right leg is lifted off due to the flexor withdrawal reflex, while the left leg is extended due to the crossed-extensor reflex.

When a painful stimulus is applied to a limb, the limb is immediately flexed to pull away from the danger. This reflex is called the flexion withdrawal reflex. Within 0.2 to 0.5 seconds, the extensor muscles of the opposite limb contract to shift the weight of the body onto the other side, in the case of the lower limb, or to push the dangerous stimulus away from the body. This reflex is called the crossed-extensor reflex.

After the painful stimulus is removed, the crossed extensor reflex has a longer period of after-discharge when compared to the flexor reflex. This prolonged after-discharge results from reverberating circuits among the inter-neuronal cells.

The image below shows the flexor reflex:



The image below shows the crossed extensor reflex:



Other options:

Option A: The patellar tendon reflex, which is activated by tapping the patellar tendon, is a type of stretch reflex.

Option B: Positive supportive reaction is a primitive postural reflex, wherein the pressure applied to the footpad causes extension of the limb.

Option D: The Golgi tendon reflex provides a negative feedback mechanism that prevents the development of excessive tension in a muscle.

questions.text: 139. A 10-year-old boy returned from a birthday party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools but no fever. Other children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. The growth of the organism on nutrient agar is shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this organism?

choices.text: Golden yellow pigmentation is due to β-carotene
Confluent growth presents a characteristic “oil-paint appearance”

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus, where the incorrect statement is 'Non-motile and sporing'.

S. aureus shows spreading ( a form of sliding motility) and comet formation (a form of gliding motility). The symptoms appear within 5-6 hours with vomiting, loose stools, but no fever. Milk-based products are easily contaminated with S. aureus toxin. 

The common toxin-mediated staphylococcal diseases are as follows:

* Food poisoning

* Toxic shock syndrome

* Scalded skin syndrome

On nutrient agar, Staphylococcus shows golden yellow pigmentation due to β-carotene (Option B), with optimum pigment production at 22°C (Option C). Pigment production is enhanced when 1% of glycerol or milk is incorporated in the medium. On the nutrient agar slope, the confluent growth presents a characteristic “oil-paint appearance”. (Option D) 

Note: Spore formation has not been seen with S. aureus.

questions.text: 140. A 37-year-old woman (P1L1) has presented with secondary amenorrhea for the past 10 months. She reports hot flashes. She has been trying to conceive for over a year without success. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings include ↑ FSH and LH, ↓ Estradiol, with normal TSH and Prolactin. She expresses a strong desire to become pregnant. Which of the following is the most effective method to help her conceive?

choices.text: In vitro fertilization using donor oocytes

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, with the woman expressing a strong desire to conceive, the most effective method in  management is in vitro fertilisation using donor oocytes.

The clinical and hormonal profile suggests premature ovarian insufficiency (POI), previously referred to as premature ovarian failure. This condition is defined by secondary amenorrhea for at least 4 months in a woman under 40, along with elevated gonadotropins (FSH >40 IU/L on two occasions at least one month apart) and low estradiol levels, indicating hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. The absence of any other systemic illness and normal TSH and prolactin levels further support this diagnosis.

In women with POI, the ovarian reserve is severely diminished, and spontaneous ovulation is rare. One of the key tests for assessing ovarian reserve is anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), which reflects the quantity of antral follicles. AMH is produced by granulosa cells of ovarian follicles, and levels <1 ng/mL typically suggest poor ovarian reserve. Other markers include a high FSH in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3), low estradiol (<75 pg/mL), low antral follicle count (<4–5), and low inhibin B (<40 pg/mL), all indicating reduced follicular activity and diminished reproductive potential.

Given the lack of functional ovarian follicles, ovulation induction agents like clomiphene citrate or pulsatile GnRH are ineffective. The only viable option for pregnancy in these patients is assisted reproduction with donor oocytes, which has high success rates and is considered standard of care. Using combined oral contraceptives has no role in fertility management, and the priority in a woman strongly desiring pregnancy is to proceed directly to IVF with donor oocytes.

questions.text: 141. A patient presents with pain and swelling in her finger for the past 4 days. Which anatomical structure is primarily affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image describing pain and swelling around the fingernail are suggestive of a case of acute paronychia, which is an infectious inflammation of the nail fold.

Nail fold is the skin that surrounds and protects the base and sides of the nail. It is a soft tissue skin fold, not part of the nail plate. Paronychia refers to an infection of the proximal and lateral nail folds. It results from the disruption of the protective barrier between the nail and the nail fold, introducing pathogens and predisposing the area to infection. It is more common in women. It can be acute if it lasts < 6 weeks or chronic if it lasts for >6 weeks.

Acute paronychia is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents clinically as erythematous, swollen, and tender lateral nail folds, and an area of fluctuance is seen if an abscess is present. In addition, papulosquamous disorders like psoriasis and pemphigus can also cause paronychia. Predisposing factors include nail biting, torn hangnails, or local trauma such as a splinter or thorn prick.

If superficial, the infection may drain spontaneously or be easily incised with a scalpel. Deeper infections may form a collar-stud abscess and require incision and drainage, sometimes involving removal of part of the nail plate. Penicillinase-resistant antibiotics are started initially, and a lack of improvement within 48 hours warrants surgical management. Twice-daily soaking in an antiseptic solution like chlorhexidine promotes healing. Complications include osteitis or, rarely, amputation. Radiography is advised when trauma or a distal phalanx fracture is suspected.

The image below shows the normal anatomy of a nail:



The diseases of other parts of the nail are:

* Nail bed and plate - Onychomycosis

* Nail plate - green nail syndrome

questions.text: 142. A 50-year-old woman presents with seizures and headaches. MRI of the brain reveals a mass lesion. Histopathological examination of the mass is shown below. What is the most likely cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given histology shows syncytial or whorled clusters of epithelial cells. These histological features and the MRI showing a brain mass suggest meningioma. They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. 

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumours, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas. 

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits.

The tumor spreads sheet-like along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcifications.

Other options:

Option A: Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin formation in the neurons of the central nervous system. They are affected in diseases such as multiple sclerosis, and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

Option B: Schwann cells are responsible for myelin formation in the neurons of the peripheral nervous system. They are affected in Guillain-Barre syndrome.

Option D: Ependymal cells are specialized cells lining the ventricles and spinal canal of the spinal cord. These cells produce cerebrospinal fluid and play a role in the fluid homeostasis of the nervous system.

questions.text: 143. You are working as a medical officer in an area affected by an earthquake. Which of the following steps will you take as part of disaster relief for the community?

choices.text: Mass vaccination against cholera and typhoid
Maintaining minimum residual free chlorine levels >1mg/L

questions.solution:
Source reduction for vector control is done as part of disaster relief.

The disaster relief phase starts when assistance from outside reaches the affected area. It involves providing critical supplies and preventing the spread of communicable diseases. Source reduction for vector control is important to reduce the incidence of dengue, malaria, leptospirosis, plague, and typhus, especially in an area where these diseases are endemic.

The following image shows the steps of disaster management:



Other options:

Option A: Routine mass vaccination for typhoid and cholera is not recommended by WHO in disaster settings because the vaccines are often multidose, require many workers, are difficult to supervise safely, and may create a false sense of security that reduces focus on essential control measures. However, such vaccination is advised for health workers. 

Option B: As the risk of microbial contamination runs high post-disaster, chlorination of water bodies is done to maintain residual free chlorine levels up to 0.2-0.5 mg/L. This reduces the risk of waterborne disease. 

Option C: Providing monetary support for losses is not the responsibility of the medical officer.

questions.text:
144. A man presents with recurrent attacks of jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and fever for the last 2 years. Ultrasound of the abdomen reveals dilatation and thickening of the bile duct. Stool microscopy performed reveals flask-shaped eggs. What can be the causative organism of the disease?

* Paragonimus westermani

* Clonorchis sinensis

* Fasciolopsis buski

* Opisthorchis viverrini
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of chronic infection with liver flukes, Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini. 

Chronic infection with Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke) and Opisthorchis viverrini can lead to mechanical obstruction of the bile duct, resulting in cholangitis, dilatation, and fibrosis of the bile duct, ultimately increasing the risk of cholangiocarcinoma. 

Stool microscopy reveals characteristic flask-shaped eggs (shown below). The eggs of Clonorchis and Opisthorchis are morphologically indistinguishable. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for treatment.



Other statements: 

Statement 1: Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke that presents with hemoptysis and eosinophilic granulomatous inflammation. 

Statement 3: Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke that presents with obstructive and malabsorption symptoms of the intestine, with yellow-green stool.

questions.text:
145. A pathologist studying cell injury identifies various changes occurring in an injured cell, progressing to cell death. Which of the following sequences represents the correct chronological order of these changes?

* Gross morphological changes

* Ultrastructural changes

* Light microscopic changes

* Biochemical changes
questions.solution:
The correct order of changes occurring following cell injury is: Biochemical changes (4) → Ultrastructural changes (2) → Light microscopic changes (3) → Gross morphological changes (1)

The earliest injury affects cellular metabolism, resulting in biochemical derangements. These trigger organelle dysfunction, which appears as ultrastructural changes. As the damage progresses, these alterations become large enough to be seen under a light microscope and finally manifest as gross tissue changes.

This can be explained with the following examples:

* Biochemical changes: Activation of caspases, which initiate molecular pathways leading to cell death. This can be detected using biochemical assays.

* Ultrastructural changes: Changes visible under electron microscopy, such as mitochondrial swelling and plasma membrane disruption.

* Light microscopy changes: Cell shrinkage and chromatin condensation, observable under the light microscope.

* Gross morphological changes: Visible tissue changes, such as coagulative necrosis.

questions.text: 146. Which of the following drugs is correctly matched to its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist.  

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist analogue. Its initial action stimulates the receptors, leading to an increase in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), which is referred to as the "flare effect." However, prolonged stimulation of the GnRH receptors by these analogues results in their downregulation, ultimately decreasing gonadotropin secretion.

Leuprolide is approved for treating conditions such as endometriosis, uterine fibroids, advanced prostate cancer, and precocious puberty. It is important to note that GnRH agonists are contraindicated in pregnant women. Additionally, long-term use of this medication carries a risk of osteoporosis.

Other options: 

Option A: Pasireotide is a somatostatin analogue approved for acromegaly and Cushing's disease.

Option B: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of acromegaly. 

Option D: Ganirelix acetate is a GnRH receptor antagonist FDA-approved to suppress the LH surge and thus prevent premature ovulation in ovarian-stimulation protocols as part of assisted reproduction technology.

questions.text: 147. Name the deep muscle of the hand marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the given image is the Adductor Pollicis.

The Adductor pollicis has two heads. The oblique head originates from the bases of the second and third metacarpals and the adjacent carpal bones (capitate in particular), while the transverse head arises from the anterior surface of the shaft of the third metacarpal. Both heads insert into the medial side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb.

The adductor pollicis is the largest and most powerful intrinsic muscle. It acts to adduct the thumb. It is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. The adductor pollicis is tested by asking the subject to adduct the thumb at right angles to the palm against resistance.

Other Options:

Option A: Opponens pollicis origin is from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercle of the trapezium. Insertion is along the lateral side of the first metacarpal. It flexes the metacarpal of the thumb and stabilises the trapeziometacarpal joint. It is supplied by the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Option C: Abductor pollicis brevis originates from the flexor retinaculum and the tubercles of the scaphoid and trapezium, and inserts on the lateral side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. It acts to abduct the thumb at the carpometacarpal and metacarpophalangeal joints, and is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Option D: Flexor pollicis brevis has two heads. The superficial head originates from the flexor retinaculum and trapezium, and the deep head originates from the trapezoid and capitate bones. Both insert into the lateral side of the base of the proximal phalanx of the thumb. The muscle acts to flex the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal joint. The superficial head is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve, while the deep head is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: 149. A 45-year-old female presents with papilledema. MRI shows a thrombus in a dural venous sinus marked in the given image. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this structure?

choices.text: Lies in the inferior margin of the falx cerebri
Receives the Great Vein of Galen as a tributary
Lies within the meningeal layer of dura mater
It drains into the confluence of sinuses

questions.solution:
The structure marked is the Superior Sagittal Sinus, and the clinical scenario is suggestive of Superior Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis. It drains into the confluence of sinuses.

Superior sagittal sinus ends near the internal occipital protuberance by draining into the confluence of sinuses. It turns to one side, usually the right and becomes continuous with the right transverse sinus. It generally communicates with the opposite sinus. The junction of all these sinuses is called the confluence of sinuses.

The superior sagittal sinus runs in the superior margin of the falx cerebri. It begins near crista galli and receives tributaries from the cortical veins draining the superior part of the frontal, parietal and occipital lobes. It also receives tributaries from the cortical veins draining the anterior part of the orbital surface of the frontal lobe.

Acute and complete thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus is a severe condition that causes acute elevation of intracranial pressure. Slow and progressive occlusion is seen with sagittal meningiomas, which may not show any clinical manifestations because of the development of compensatory collateral venous drainage.

The inferior sagittal sinus runs in the inferior margin of the falx cerebri (Option A). The inferior sagittal sinus receives the great vein of Galen as its tributary (Option B). They unite to form the straight sinus. All dural venous sinuses except the inferior sagittal and straight sinuses lie between the endosteal and meningeal layers of dura mater (Option C). The inferior sagittal sinus and the straight sinus lie within the meningeal layer of dura mater.

questions.text: 150. A 47-year-old woman comes with complaints of a chronic cough. Her chest X-ray shows hilar lymphadenopathy. Blood tests show increased levels of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). Which of the following additional findings is she likely to have?

choices.text: Raised levels of White blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough, hilar lymphadenopathy, and elevated ACE levels likely has sarcoidosis. Metastatic calcification can occur in sarcoidosis and this can include the vasculature and major organs in the body.

Metastatic calcification can also be seen in renal failure, and milk-alkali syndrome. Advanced Atheromatous plaque and Monckeberg medial sclerosis present with dystrophic calcification.

Pathologic calcification is the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts. It is of two types namely metastatic and dystrophic calcification.

Metastatic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissues. Metastatic calcification can be seen in interstitial tissues of the gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins. It occurs in case of hypercalcemia secondary to some disturbance in calcium metabolism. The principal causes of hypercalcemia:

* Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)

* Resorption of bone tissue in multiple myeloma, skeletal metastasis, and Paget's disease

* Vitamin-D-related disorders such as Vitamin D toxicity and sarcoidosis 

* Renal failure causes retention of phosphate which leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism

* Aluminum intoxication

* Milk-alkali syndrome due to excess ingestion of calcium and absorbable antacids (milk or calcium carbonate) 

Dystrophic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in dying tissues and areas of necrosis. It occurs even in the presence of normal calcium levels. It may be seen in atherosclerosis, aging/damaged heart valves, and tuberculous lymph nodes. Papillary thyroid cancer has dystrophic calcification in the form of psammoma bodies.

questions.text: 151. A 21-year-old woman presents with complaints of postcoital spotting and vaginal discharge. Menarche occurred at age 13, and her cycles are regular. Pelvic examination reveals a small hypoplastic cervix and a shallow vaginal canal. Colposcopic evaluation of the upper third of the vagina shows glandular, red, velvety patches. Cytology reveals benign columnar epithelial cells without atypia. Her mother reports taking diethylstilbestrol during pregnancy to prevent miscarriage. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is vaginal adenosis.

Vaginal adenosis is a benign condition most commonly associated with in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol, a synthetic estrogen once prescribed to prevent miscarriage. In affected daughters, DES disrupts normal development of the vaginal epithelium, resulting in areas of glandular columnar epithelium persisting in the vagina, instead of being replaced by normal squamous epithelium. These changes are often found in the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall and may appear as red, velvety patches on colposcopy.

While most patients with vaginal adenosis are asymptomatic, some may present with postcoital bleeding, vaginal discharge, or spotting, as seen in this patient. Cytology typically reveals benign columnar epithelial cells without atypia, which supports a non-malignant diagnosis. Although there is a known association between DES exposure and clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina, this malignancy is rare, and vaginal adenosis remains the most common lesion seen in DES-exposed daughters.

Other Options:

Option B: Diethylstilbesterol does increase the risk of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia in daughters. A part of the full thickness of the stratified squamous epithelium of the cervix is replaced by dysplastic cells. Changes in the epithelium are in the region of the transformation zone.

Option C: Gartner's cyst is a benign vaginal cyst that arises from the remnant of the mesonephric duct. Usually asymptomatic, can present with dyspareunia, vaginal pain and difficulty in inserting tampons. It is a tense cyst found within the lateral vaginal wall during examination. Diethylstilbesterol usage does not cause it.

Option D: Diethylstilbesterol does increase the risk of vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia in daughters. It is a cellular abnormality limited to the epithelium of the vulval skin, excluding the keratinised layer.

questions.text: 152. A 19-year-old girl with chronic ear discharge presents with headache, vomiting, and transient visual blurring. She is afebrile with bilateral papilledema and no focal deficits. CSF pressure is high; contents are normal. The MR venogram shows narrowing of the right sigmoid sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient’s history of chronic ear discharge, afebrile status, bilateral papilledema, high CSF pressure with normal content, and narrowing of the sigmoid sinus on MR venography is characteristic of otitic hydrocephalus.

Otitic hydrocephalus is a rare intracranial complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), characterized by raised intracranial pressure (ICP) due to thrombosis or compression of the sigmoid or transverse sinus, without direct infection of brain parenchyma. The condition typically presents with features of increased ICP (headache, vomiting, transient visual blurring, and papilledema) but with normal sensorium, no fever, no focal neurological deficits, and normal CSF composition despite elevated pressure.

Treatment focuses on lowering intracranial pressure and managing the underlying ear infection. Intracranial pressure can be reduced using acetazolamide, corticosteroids, and repeated lumbar punctures or a lumbar drain; a lumboperitoneal shunt may be required if pressure remains high. The ear infection is treated with appropriate antibiotics and, if needed, mastoid exploration to address sinus thrombosis. Early neurosurgical consultation is essential to prevent complications such as brain herniation or blindness.

Other options:

Option A: Superior sagittal sinus thrombosis is unlikely to cause the above findings. However, lateral sinus thrombosis may lead to otitic hydrocephalus.

Option B: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with identical raised ICP features but occurs without an underlying cause like CSOM or sinus compression. 

Option D: Early cerebellar abscess would show focal cerebellar signs (e.g., ataxia, nystagmus), fever, or signs of space-occupying lesion on MRI. The normal imaging and absence of deficits rule this out.

questions.text: 153. Suspicious deaths were occurring after receiving parcels via mail in the USA. The microscopy of the specimen collected showed the following appearance. The bioterrorism agent involved can also show ___________
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a bioterrorism agent with the gram stain showing a box car appearance/bamboo stick appearance is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis (Category A bioterrorism agent). Bacillus anthracis can also show a medusa head appearance on microscopy.

Bacillus anthracis is a non-motile gram-positive bacillus that has a characteristic box car or a bamboo stick appearance on gram staining. On the agar plate, they form irregular round colonies that are raised, dull, greyish-white colonies giving a frosted glass appearance as given in the image below.



Long interlacing chains of bacilli, resembling matted hair, are present on the edge of the colonies giving it a medusa-head appearance when seen on low-power microscopy.

M’Fadyean’s reaction is used to demonstrate the polypeptide capsule which is stained with polychrome methylene blue. It also shows an inverted fir tree appearance on gelatin slab culture. On a solid media containing penicillin, the colonies give a string of pearls appearance as given in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: A fried egg appearance of colonies is seen in the case of Mycoplasma.



Option C: Draughtsman or carrom coin appearance of colonies on blood agar is seen in the case of Streptococcus pneumonia, as given in the image below.



Option D: A fluorescent antibody-stained specimen of Yersinia pestis reveals rod-shaped bacteria with characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin or hairpin-like appearance.

questions.text: 154. A 29-year-old pregnant, immunocompetent woman presents with dysuria, urgency, and urinary frequency for the past 2 days. She denies fever, flank pain, or vaginal discharge. To obtain a sterile specimen due to recent contamination in prior samples, a suprapubic aspiration is performed. Urine culture grows 10² CFU/mL of E. coli. Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation?

choices.text: The colony count is too low to diagnose UTI; repeat testing is required
Diagnostic of acute bacterial cystitis due to significant bacteriuria
The result suggests colonisation rather than infection
The patient’s symptoms are inconsistent with cystitis; further imaging is necessary

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a sterile urine sample obtained via suprapubic aspiration grows 10² CFU/mL of E. coli. The most appropriate interpretation is that this is diagnostic of acute bacterial cystitis due to significant bacteriuria. Any growth of microorganisms in the culture of a single specimen obtained by suprapubic aspiration is considered significant bacteriuria.

In symptomatic women, the threshold for diagnosing acute bacterial cystitis is much lower than in asymptomatic cases. While asymptomatic bacteriuria is defined by ≥10⁵ CFU/mL in a voided specimen without symptoms, symptomatic women with classic signs of cystitis (such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency) may have true infections even with colony counts as low as 10² CFU/mL, especially when obtained via a sterile method like suprapubic aspiration.

The presence of E. coli, the most common uropathogen, in any significant amount in a sterilely collected urine sample from a symptomatic patient supports the diagnosis of acute bacterial cystitis. Therefore, further imaging is not necessary to diagnose acute bacterial cystitis. Imaging is done for complicated urinary tract infections, recurrent infections or when there is suspicion of upper tract involvement (e.g. pyelonephritis).

questions.text: 155. A 60-year-old male presents with a finding as shown in the image. Which of the following types of joints are mainly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows Dupuytren’s contracture affecting the ring and the little finger. Joints affected in this condition are the Hinge and Ellipsoidal type of synovial joint.

Dupuytren’s contracture is caused by progressive fibrosis of the palmar fascia, leading to a fixed flexion deformity. It typically affects the Metacarpophalangeal joints and Proximal interphalangeal joints, which become functionally limited. It is seen in patients with a history of chronic alcohol consumption, diabetes mellitus, rheumatoid arthritis, and in workers who handle repetitive vibrations.

The metacarpophalangeal joint(MCP) is a type of ellipsoidal joint. Ellipsoidal joints are biaxial. It allows primary movements such as flexion, extension, adduction, and abduction. The proximal Interphalangeal joint(PIP) is a type of hinge joint. Movement takes place about a single stationary axis. It allows only flexion and extension.

questions.text: 156. A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent fever, lower abdominal pain, and increased frequency of micturition for the past 6 months. Urine appears pale and opalescent with the presence of red blood cells and pus cells. Urine culture showed no growth. A CT scan was done as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing putty kidney are suggestive of renal tuberculosis. The given image shows a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty hence called putty kidney.

Renal TB is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.

Clinical features of renal TB:

* More common in males

* Increased frequency of micturition

* Polyuria

* Painful micturition with often haematuria.

* Loin pain and suprapubic pain. Suprapubic pain is more common due to cystitis.

* Tuberculous kidney is rarely palpable unless there is hydronephrosis or perinephric abscess.

* Sterile pyuria- urine is pale and opalescent with the presence of pus cells without organisms in acid urine—abacterial aciduria (other causes: interstitial cystitis, chlamydia).

Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria. Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl–Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured.

The most sensitive imaging modality in renal tuberculosis is CT urography/pyelography. NCCT is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications.

 Manifestations of renal TB as seen on CT are as follows:

* Early: Papillary necrosis

* Progressive:

* Multifocal strictures

* Generalized or focal hydronephrosis

* Mural thickening and enhancement

* Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma

* End-stage:

* Progressive hydronephrosis

* Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney

Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Surgical management involves partial or total nephrectomy and reconstructive surgery (e.g. for ureteric strictures) and surgery to the bladder such as augmentation cystoplasty.



Other options:

Option A: Staghorn calculus (shown below) is found in urinary infections with proteus, pseudomonas, and staphylococcus usually, and is not a cause for sterile pyuria.



Option B: Myeloma kidney often presents with Bence-Jones proteinuria.

Option C: Nephrocalcinosis is the deposition of calcium (shown below) in the kidney parenchyma or tubules which is seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: 157. A 25-year-old primigravida presents to your hospital at 42 weeks of gestation. She does not complain of abdominal pain, contractions, or discharge per vaginum. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an abdomen girth consistent with the reported gestation age. USG and Fetal NST are normal. A decision is taken to induce labor and the device shown in the image is used. This device releases which of the following?
questions.solution:
The obstetric device shown in the above image is of Cervidil vaginal insert. This provides the release of 0.3 mg/hr of Prostaglandin E2.

Cervidil vaginal insert: It is a thin, flat, rectangular polymeric wafer held within a small, white mesh polyester sac. It contains 10 mg of Prostaglandin E2 (dinoprostone) released at a rate of 0.3mg/hour. The sac has a long attached tail to allow easy removal from the vagina.

It is advised to lie down for at least 2 hours following insertion. The insert is removed after 12 hours or with labor onset and at least 30 minutes before the administration of oxytocin.

questions.text: 159. A 35-year-old man files a medical negligence case against a surgeon who operated on him for inguinal hernia three and a half years ago. Which of the following defenses against negligence will be applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Res Indicata is the defence against negligence that will be applicable in this case. 

Res indicata specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed as being beyond the period of limitation. Legal action may still be brought up to three years after the alleged negligent act, where a patient and doctor have entered into a specific contract that requires the provision of care.

Other defences against negligence

* No duty owed to the plaintiff

* Duty discharged according to prevailing standards

* Misadventure may be therapeutic (option D), diagnostic, and experimental. Therapeutic misadventure is a situation in which a patient has suffered harm or has died as a result of an error made by a doctor or agent of the doctor or the hospital.

* Error of judgment

* Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant

* Res judicata (337 BNSS/300 CrPC, option C) - If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 

* Limitation (Res indicata) - A suit for damages for negligence must be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence against the doctor. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action may be undertaken for up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Other option:

Option A: 'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed, such as swabs left in the abdominal cavity post-laparotomy.

Pearl PM2391: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

* Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.

* Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions

* Refuses to take the treatment

* Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice

* Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

* Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

* Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

* Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.

* Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

* Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: 160. A 25-year-old male who is a diagnosed case of asthma showed no improvement even after a maximal high dose of ICS-LABA. The physician decided to initiate add-on therapy. Which of the following will not be chosen by him?
questions.solution:
Roflumilast, a phosphodiesterase-4 (PDE-4) inhibitor, will not be chosen by the physician as an add-on therapy in a patient with severe asthma. It is primarily used for managing COPD exacerbations.

A patient is said to have severe asthma when there is no or poor response to high-dose inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) + long-acting β2-agonist (LABA) therapy, despite good adherence and appropriate management of contributory factors. Severe asthma may also be diagnosed when asthma control worsens upon tapering high-dose therapy.

In such cases, add-on therapy is considered, and the choice of drug depends on the patient’s phenotype and the inflammatory pathway involved.

Add-on options include:

Biologic therapies:

* Omalizumab - anti-IgE

* Mepolizumab, Reslizumab, Benralizumab - anti-IL-5

* Dupilumab - anti-IL-4Rα

* Tezepelumab - anti-TSLP (thymic stromal lymphopoietin, option C)

Non-biologic options:

* Azithromycin (option D)

* Bronchial thermoplasty (option A)

questions.text: 161. A patient with a posterior neck injury is having difficulty flexing the cervical spine and maintaining posture. MRI reveals injury to a muscle attached anterior to the cervical vertebral bodies. Which of the following muscles is likely involved?
questions.solution:
The muscle attached anterior to the cervical vertebral body and leading to flexion of the head is Longus Colli. 

The longus colli is attached to the anterior vertebral surface between the atlas and the third thoracic vertebrae. Its major function is to flex the neck forward. 

The longus group of muscles, located in the anterior neck deep to the prevertebral fascia, includes the longus capitis and longus colli. The longus capitis functions to flex the head on the neck when acting bilaterally and assists in lateral flexion of the head when acting unilaterally. The longus colli flexes the cervical spine and also contributes to lateral flexion and slight rotation of the neck during unilateral action. 

The splenius muscles, including Splenius capitis (Option A) and cervicis (Option C), are found in the posterior neck. When these muscles contract bilaterally, they extend the head and neck, while unilateral contraction causes lateral flexion and ipsilateral rotation of the head and neck. 

Scalenus anterior (Option D)is a lateral vertebral muscle. It is attached to the anterior tubercles of the transverse processes of the third, fourth, fifth and sixth vertebrae. When acting bilaterally, they elevate the first and second ribs during forced inspiration and assist in neck flexion. When acting unilaterally, they laterally flex the neck to the same side.

questions.text: 162. A 29-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has no other complaints. On the hysterosalpingogram, the right fallopian tube has a tobacco pouch appearance. Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario of primary infertility and a hysterosalpingogram finding of the "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube is suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The ampullary part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis.     

The fallopian tubes are almost always involved in genital tuberculosis. The lesions are generally bilateral. The mode of spread of the disease is hematogenous, arising from a primary infective focus in the lung. The ampulla is most commonly affected, while the fimbriae and interstitium are spared. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The most frequent location is the lungs (50%), although it can also come from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, the gastrointestinal system, or as part of a broad miliary infection. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route or lymphatics sometimes. 

In Genital tuberculosis, the leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. 

Hysterosalpingogram may reveal the following: 

* Tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx

* Lead pipe appearance (rigid, nonperistaltic pipe)

* Beading and variation due to filling defects

* Calcification of the tube

* Cornual block

* Jagged fluffiness of tubal outline

Hysteroscopy will reveal the presence of synechiae, partial obliteration of the cavity, the golf-hole appearance of the tubal ostia, and the presence of ulcers.

questions.text: 163. A 40-year-old man presents with acute chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and jaw. A diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is made. Which of the following complications is not correctly matched to its underlying changes?

choices.text: Severe arrhythmia - Disruption of conduction pathway
Myocardial rupture - Early phagocytosis of dead cells
Ventricular aneurysm - Early coagulative necrosis with edema
Pericarditis - Coagulative necrosis with neutrophilic infiltration

questions.solution:
Ventricular aneurysm following myocardial infarction is a late complication, resulting from the formation of a thinned wall of fibrous scar tissue after a large transmural anteroseptal infarct. It is not related to early coagulative necrosis with edema, which appears within 4–12 hours of infarction.

The following are the complications that can be seen in a patient following an acute myocardial infarction, along with their underlying mechanisms:

Complication Underlying Mechanism
Severe arrhythmia (option A) Ischemic myocyte injury, and disruption of conduction pathways causing electrical instability.
Myocardial rupture (option B) Macrophage digestion and phagocytosis of necrotic myocardium before collagen deposition → soft, friable wall prone to rupture (typically 3–7 days).
Ventricular aneurysm (option C) Progressive fibrotic scarring and thinning of the infarcted wall leading to bulging during systole (late complication: weeks to months).
Pericarditis (option D) Transmural myocardial necrosis with neutrophilic inflammation extending to the epicardium, producing a fibrinous pericardial reaction (~2–3 days).
Mural thrombus Endocardial damage with stasis and turbulence over akinetic infarcted myocardium → thrombogenesis and potential embolisation.
Papillary muscle dysfunction/rupture Ischemic necrosis or frank rupture of papillary muscle → acute mitral regurgitation due to leaflet tethering/loss of support.
Chamber dilation Stretching and thinning of weakened infarcted myocardium with remodelling, producing ventricular dilation.
Heart failure (pump failure) Extensive loss of contractile myocardium (often >40% LV involvement), causing inadequate cardiac output and pulmonary/systemic congestion.

questions.text: 164. Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin result in the formation of ______.
questions.solution:
Incoordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibers of the uterus due to injudicious use of oxytocin results in the formation of a constriction ring/ Schroeder's ring.

It is usually situated at the junction of the upper and lower segments of the uterus around the neck of the fetus in cephalic presentation.

Common causes are:

* Injudicious use of oxytocics

* Premature rupture of membranes

* A premature attempt at instrumental delivery

Bandl's ring/Pathological retraction ring

* It is formed in cases of obstructed labor.

* In obstructed labor, the upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigorously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates. With each contraction, there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

* The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring/Bandl's ring.

questions.text: 165. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the given image?

choices.text: Needle 1 has a low risk of post-dural puncture headache
Needle 3 has a high risk of blockage of the needle aperture
Needle 3 has a lower risk of accidental epidural injection
Needle 2 is a traumatic spinal needle

questions.solution:
Image 3 depicts a Ballpen (Rusch) spinal needle, which has a lower risk of accidental epidural injection.

The given image shows various types of spinal needles.

1-Quincke’s needle- Traumatic and has the highest risk of post-dural puncture headache. 

2-Sprotte needle- Atraumatic Spinal needle

3-Ballpen (Rusch) needle- Lower risk of accidental epidural injection and low risk of blockage of needle aperture.

Ballpen needle (stylet point needle) - The needle opens at the distal tip, leading to less risk of injection into the epidural space. There is no coring of tissue or aperture blockage. Less advancement of the needle is needed, which lowers the risk of neurological damage. It also has atraumatic insertion with a PDPH rate comparable to Whitacre and Sprotte.

The Quincke spinal needle is a cutting needle that has a diamond-shaped cutting bevel and an opening at the tip. It has easier insertion and less risk of failed spinals but a higher incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH), increased nerve damage risk, less tactile feedback, and a risk of tissue coring and aperture occlusion.

Whitacre needle (atraumatic pencil-point) has a blunt conical tip that separates dural fibres instead of cutting them, reducing CSF leakage and PDPH. It also produces a reliable tactile “dural click” when puncturing the dura.

Sprotte needle (modified atraumatic pencil-point) has a tapered tip that allows less traumatic dural entry and further reduction in PDPH rates compared to Whitacre.



Pearl PM0446: PDPH- Post-Dural Puncture Headache

* May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).

* Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.

* Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.

* Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.

* Prevention by thinner needle

Management:

* Supine position

* IV fluids

* Caffeine and analgesia

* Epidural blood patch

questions.text: 166. A patient on treatment for testicular cancer is on a cisplatin-based chemotherapy regimen. Which of the following drugs can be used to reduce the nephrotoxicity caused by Cisplatin?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity can be reduced by the use of Amifostine.

Cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity can be reduced by pretreatment hydration and chloride diuresis. Amifostine, a cytoprotective thiophosphate agent, decreases renal toxicity associated with repeated cisplatin administration. Amifostine is also a known radioprotector and must be administered 30 minutes before irradiation.

Cisplatin is used in testicular, ovarian, bladder, esophageal, gastric, lung, head and neck, anal, and breast cancer. Cisplatin, in combination with bleomycin, etoposide, or with ifosfamide and vinblastine, cures 90% of patients with testicular cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Leucovorin or folinic acid antagonizes methotrexate toxicity, which can act without being reduced by DHFRase.

Option B: Mesna, when administered systematically, is excreted in the urine and prevents bladder cancer by binding to the vesitoxic metabolites of cyclophosphamide and ifosfamide.

Option C: Dexrazoxane is given before administration of doxorubicin to prevent its cardiotoxic effects.

questions.text: 167. A 10-month-old infant presents with hepatomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia. Both von Gierke disease (GSD I) and Cori disease (GSD III) are considered. Which biochemical finding would best differentiate von Gierke disease (GSD I) from Cori disease (GSD III)?
questions.solution:
Lactic acidosis would best differentiate von Gierke disease (GSD I) from Cori disease (GSD III).

In Von Gierke disease, deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase impairs both glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, resulting in the accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate, which is shunted to lactate, causing persistent lactic acidosis, even in normoglycemia.

In contrast, Cori disease involves debranching enzyme deficiency; gluconeogenesis remains intact, so lactate is cleared, and acidosis is uncommon or absent.

Other options:

Option A: Ketotic hypoglycemia occurs in both and is not a differentiating factor.

Option B: Hepatic glycogen accumulation is seen in both conditions.

Option D: Elevated transaminases with hepatomegaly are non-specific findings common to many hepatic glycogen storage disorders.

questions.text: 169. A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with a growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumor and underwent surgical resection. Despite postoperative treatment with octreotide, his IGF-1 levels remain elevated. Which of the following is least likely to be used as the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is least likely to be used as the immediate next step in the management of the given clinical situation.

In a patient with a growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumour, the preferred initial treatment is surgical resection of the tumour. If disease control is not achieved post-surgery, patients are started on somatostatin receptor ligands (SRL) like octreotide or lanreotide.

If there is inadequate disease control after initiating SRL therapy, the following options are considered:

* Adding pegvisomant (a GH receptor antagonist, option A)

* Increasing the dose of SRL (option B)

* Reoperation (option C)

Radiotherapy is usually reserved for later stages of management when surgery and medical therapies fail to control the disease. Radiotherapy can also be started when single-drug therapy fails, which cannot be ascertained here, as increasing the octreotide dose is still an option.

The following flowchart explains the management of a GH-secreting pituitary adenoma:



Note: IGF-1 levels are monitored periodically to check if disease control is achieved. Primary SRL therapy can be considered when surgery is contraindicated or refused. Cabergoline may also be added post-surgery (for mild GH/IGF-1 elevation) if adequate control is not achieved.

questions.text: 170. During a cholera outbreak, a very high dose of chlorine is added to the village’s water supply, followed by dechlorination before consumption. Which of the following methods of disinfection uses this technique?
questions.solution:
The method of adding a large amount of chlorine to water followed by dechlorination is termed superchlorination.

Superchlorination is reserved for heavily contaminated water whose quality keeps fluctuating. It comprises adding a very large amount of chlorine to water to rapidly destroy all pathogenic organisms, or oxidise organic matter, and removing excess chlorine after disinfection.

Other options:

Option A: Breakpoint chlorination refers to adding chlorine to water to a point where residual chlorine starts appearing in the water. It achieves the same result as superchlorination in a rational manner.

Option B: The double pot method of chlorination is used to disinfect wells containing about 4500 L of water for up to 2-3 weeks. In this method, the inner pot is filled with a slightly moistened mixture of sand and bleaching powder and is introduced into the outer pot. Both pots have holes to allow the free passage of water. The mouth of the outer pot is closed with a foil and is lowered into the well. It should be kept immersed at least 1 m below the water level. The presence of two pots removes the risk of over-chlorination.



Option D: Controlled superchlorination is another name for breakpoint chlorination.

Pearl PM1598: Chlorination of Water

* Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.

* It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.

* It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.

* The action of chlorine:

* Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.

* H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl HOCl → H + OCl

* The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.

* Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.

* Principles of chlorination:

* The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.

* The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.

* The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.

* Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.

*  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.

* The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.

* Methods of chlorination:

* Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.

* Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.

* Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.

* Break point chlorination:

* The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.

* Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.

* In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.

* This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.

* It is also called controlled superchlorination

* Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.

* Orthotolidine (OT) test:

* It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.

* The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.

* When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.

* Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:

* This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.

* It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Pearl PM1594: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

* Storage

* Filtration:

* Slow sand filters

* Rapid sand filters

* Disinfection:

* Chlorination

* Ozonation

* UV radiation

* Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

* Household purification of water:

* Boiling

* Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.

* Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters.

* UV radiation

* Multi-stage reverse osmosis

* Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: 171. A 4-year-old child is brought to the casualty after having suddenly collapsed during playing. There is no pulse, CPR is started. After 2 minutes of CPR, the monitor shows ventricular fibrillation rhythm. The first attempt at defibrillation was unsuccessful. What is the energy to be set for defibrillation in the second attempt?
questions.solution:
In a pediatric cardiac arrest, the energy for defibrillation for the second shock is usually set at 4 J/kg for both monophasic and biphasic waveforms. Initial defibrillation energy in pediatric cardiac arrest is 2 J/kg.

If a pediatric defibrillator is not available, then an adult defibrillator can be used.

In children the most common cause of cardiac arrest is asphyxia. But a sudden witnessed collapse in a child is usually due to ventricular fibrillation.

For adult defibrillation, the energy that must be applied is:

* Monophasic defibrillator– 360 J

* Biphasic defibrillator- 120-200 J (manufacturer recommended)

questions.text: 172. Which of the following is not a likely cause of neonatal seizures?
questions.solution:
Neonatal seizures are not caused by hypermagnesemia. Magnesium inhibits acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, causing CNS and muscular depression.

Clinical Features (appear when Mg > 4.5 mg/dL):

* Hypotonia, hyporeflexia, poor suck, lethargy

* Hypotension, flushing

* Prolonged PR, QRS, QT intervals on ECG

* Severe cases: heart block, respiratory depression, or cardiac arrest

Most commonly seen in neonates born to mothers treated with IV magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia/eclampsia. It may also result from excessive intake via TPN, antacids, or laxatives.

Other Options:

Option A: Hyponatremia can cause seizures, most commonly seen in ages 1-4 days. It is often secondary to water intoxication or inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

Option B: Hypocalcemia can cause neonatal seizures in the first 2-3 days of life. This is seen with low birth weight neonates. It can also cause seizures in slightly older neonates with normal birth weight who consume milk with an unfavourable ratio of phosphorus to calcium.

Option D: Hypomagnesemia causes seizures in ages 1-4 days and is often associated with hypocalcemia.

questions.text: 173. An anxious pregnant mother rushed to the emergency department with complaints of decreased fetal movements. A non-stress test was done and variable decelerations are noted. What does this signify?
questions.solution:
Variable deceleration indicates cord compression.

Decelerations are variable in all respect of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing to the uterine contractions. It is the most common type. Accelerations often precede and follow the deceleration.

Note: Deceleration is a decrease in fetal heart rate below the baseline by 15 bpm for more than 15s.



Pearl PM1825: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression



 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia



 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: 174. A 28-year-old primigravida in her 38th week of gestation is being evaluated for labor. On pelvic examination, the diagonal conjugate measures 12 cm, and the interspinous distance is 10 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate interpretation of this pelvic assessment?

choices.text: The pelvic inlet is likely adequate for vaginal delivery
The pelvic outlet is narrow, requiring a forceps delivery
The interspinous distance indicates a risk of shoulder dystocia

questions.solution:
A diagonal conjugate of 12cm suggests that the true conjugate is approximately 10cm. The interspinous distance is 10cm. All of these values are considered adequate for vaginal delivery.

True(anatomical) conjugate is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the pubis symphysis. It cannot be estimated directly. It is inferred by subtracting 1.2cm from the diagonal conjugate.

Cephalopelvic Disproportion(CPD) can occur at the inlet, mid-pelvis, or the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

Inlet CPD:

* Obstetric conjugate < 10 cm.

* Diagonal conjugate < 11 cm.

* Transverse diameter < 12 cm.

Midpelvis CPD:

* Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis ≤13 cm.

* Interspinous diameter < 8 cm.

Outlet CPD:

* Interischial diameter ≤ 8 cm.
