questions.text:
175. With respect to the Lineweaver-Burk plot shown for a given enzyme and inhibitor, which of the following happens on increasing inhibitor concentration?

V - Reaction velocity [S] - Substrate concentration

choices.text: Decrease in binding affinity of substrate to enzyme
Decrease in the Km value of the enzyme
Decrease in the slope of red line
Decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second

questions.solution:
The red line in the graph represents a reaction with a noncompetitive inhibitor. Increasing inhibitor concentration will lead to a decrease in the maximum number of product molecules catalyzed per second.

In non-competitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds the enzyme other than the active site. It causes a change in the activity of enzymes, as a result of which the reaction is not catalyzed. The total number of products hence formed is less. It, however, does not affect the affinity (represented by Km value) (Option A) of the enzyme to bind the substrate.

This can be plotted on a graph. 1/v0 is plotted versus 1/[S] and a straight line is obtained. This plot can be used to calculate Km and Vmax as well as to determine the mechanism of action of enzyme inhibitors, where v0 is the reaction velocity and [S] is the substrate concentration.

In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases (or 1/Vmax increases) but Km is unchanged (Option B). Hence, the graphs of inhibited and uninhibited reactions have the same x-intercepts (converge at -1/Km) but different y-intercepts.

On increasing the inhibitor concentration, the slope of the red line (1/V vs 1/S) increases (Option C), or in other words, Vmax decreases.



Pearl PM0912: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

* Competitive inhibitors

* Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: 176. A genital examination is being performed on a patient with perineal laceration post-vaginal delivery. The tear extends into the fascia and the musculature of the perineal body but the anal sphincter muscles remain intact. Which of the following grades of perineal laceration does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
As the tear extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body and the anal sphincter muscles remain intact indicates this is a second-degree perineal tear.

The perineal tear is more common in primigravida and results from over-stretching or sudden stretching of the perineum during childbirth. Trauma to the perineum can also result in perineal tears.

Clinical features include the inability to hold the flatus and feces. Soreness over the peri-anal region can be seen due to constant irritation by stool. Palpation reveals the decreased/absence of a sphincteric grip depending on the degree of tear.

All recent tears should be repaired immediately. If there is a delay of 24 hours, the repair has to be withheld and the patient has to be started on antibiotics to prevent infection. Complete perineal tears that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery. In 3 months of time, any local infection that might have been present would subside, and the general condition of the patient will also improve. However, if the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms making the surgery difficult.

Pearl PM1823: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: 177. Chromatin immunoprecipitation is used for the study of
questions.solution:
Chromatin immunoprecipitation(ChIP) is a technique used to identify the discrete DNA sequences to which specific proteins bind. For example, it is used to identify the DNA sequence target for transcription factors, histone modifiers, etc.

ChIP-sequencing is a powerful technique used to study protein–DNA interactions, helping identify where transcription factors, histone modifications, or other chromatin-associated proteins bind to the genome. It combines chromatin immunoprecipitation with next-generation sequencing (NGS) to provide a comprehensive view of protein binding sites across the genome.

There are two main variants of this technique: standard ChIP-Seq and ChIP-Exo. In standard ChIP-Seq, the immunoprecipitated DNA is directly sequenced using NGS. In contrast, ChIP-Exo involves treating the cross-linked protein–DNA complexes with exonucleases, which remove unprotected DNA regions not directly bound to the protein. This additional step enables ChIP-Exo to achieve single-nucleotide resolution, allowing highly precise mapping of protein binding sites in vivo.

questions.text: 178. A couple has come for pre-conceptional counseling to make a decision on pregnancy planning. The method of communication used for counseling to help the couple to make a decision about health is known as_________.
questions.solution:
The method of communication used for counselling, wherein a person is helped to make a health decision is known as the GATHER approach, e.g. contraceptive counselling. Expansion:

* G- Greet

* A- Ask

* T- Tell options or give answers

* H- Help in making choices

* E- Explain everything about the decision

* R- Return for follow-up

Other options:

Option A: Delphi method: It is a systematic interactive forecasting method which is used to obtain a consensus forecast, i.e. to determine the degree of agreement on a topic. This method uses questionnaires, which are answered by experts in two or more rounds.

Option C: Spikes protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organised manner to patients and families.

Option D: Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task, skill, or procedure. It arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing’ and 'seeing is believing’ philosophies.

Pearl PM0174: Methods of Health Communication

questions.text: 179. An 8-year-old child has a tumour in the mid pons. Which of the following patterns of breathing can be seen in this child, assuming that the vagal afferents are also abolished?
questions.solution:
Apneusis is the pattern of breathing seen in this child because a tumour in the mid-pons inhibits the signal charges from the apneustic centre.

At a mid pontine level lesion, the apneustic centre is intact while the pneumotaxic centre is separated. Concurrent removal of vagus inputs causes this abnormal breathing pattern, characterised by deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration, followed by a brief, insufficient release.

B

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

Irregular but rhythmic respiration

D

Spontaneous respiration ceases

questions.text: 180. A pregnant woman who presented with vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain, and several episodes of vomiting was diagnosed with complete molar pregnancy. On transvaginal ultrasonography, the following finding is seen in her left ovary. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Theca lutein cyst of the ovary is commonly associated with women diagnosed with complete mole.

Theca lutein cyst result from ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels. Theca lutein cysts, usually regress spontaneously following the evacuation of a molar pregnancy. In some cases, a larger cyst may undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage. Management includes detorsion. Oophorectomy is performed if there is an excessive infraction after detorsion.

Hydatidiform mole is an abnormal condition of the placenta, characterized by partly degenerative and partly proliferative changes in the chorionic villi. It may be either partial or complete.

The patient presents with a characteristic history of abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding or spotting, and vomiting during the first trimester. Also, there may be a history of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. On examination, the size of the uterus is larger for gestational age and the fetal heart sounds are absent.

A USG scan shows a snowstorm appearance which is characteristic of a complete mole.



Suction and evacuation are the treatment of choice. Hysterectomy is done only if there is uncontrolled hemorrhage or perforation during surgical evacuation or if the age of the patient is above 35 years and has completed her family.

Serum hCG levels are checked within 48 hours of evacuation and are used as a baseline for future comparisons. It is then checked every week till it normalizes, which usually takes around 4 to 8 weeks. After the hCG values return to normal, a regular follow-up is done monthly for 6 months.

Pearl PM1832: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

questions.text: 181. A 45-year-old male is scheduled for an elective appendicectomy. The anesthesiologist is considering the use of xenon as an inhalational agent. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this agent?

choices.text: Given with caution in renal failure

questions.solution:
Xenon protects against neuronal ischemia.

Xenon is an inert, odorless, nonexplosive noble gas that has anesthetic properties. It has a MAC of 71% and a blood/gas coefficient of 0.115, providing fast onset and emergence. Its anesthetic effects are mediated by NMDA inhibition (Option A).

Xenon has minimal impact on cardiovascular, hepatic, or renal systems and is considered safe in hepatic and renal failure (Option D). It protects against neuronal ischemia and, when combined with hypothermia, prevents cerebral damage post-ischemic brain injury. 

It also causes less postoperative delirium (Option C) than sevoflurane anesthesia in patients undergoing off-pump coronary artery bypass graft surgery. It has no ozone layer effect, unlike nitrous oxide. Xenon is costly and has limited availability. Thus, preventing its widespread use.

questions.text: 182. A 35-year-old female patient with a history of recurrent episodes of numbness, weakness, and visual disturbances is suspected to have multiple sclerosis. All of the following can be seen in CSF analysis in Multiple sclerosis except
questions.solution:
Albuminocytologic dissociation is not seen on CSF analysis of a patient with multiple sclerosis. Albuminocytologic dissociation is seen in Guillian-Barré syndrome.

Condition CSF findings

  • Pleocytosis (5–50 cells / cu mm; lymphocytes)

CSF analysis

CSF is ultra-filtrate of plasma. It is continuously secreted by the choroid plexus inside the ventricles of the brain and circulates in the subarachnoid space of the brain and spinal cord through CSF pathways.

The main function of the CSF is to reduce the buoyancy of the brain. It also supplies nutrition and also helps in the removal of various substances like amino acids, neurotransmitters, metabolic byproducts, and cells.

The presence of RBCs (More than 1000 cells/ cu mm) or xanthochromia confirms the diagnosis of SAH.

questions.text: 183. A patient with stroke who was bedridden for a couple of weeks was started on LMWH, and overlapped with warfarin, for prophylaxis of DVT. Which of the following clotting factors is last to decrease in the bloodstream after warfarin administration?
questions.solution:
Factor II is the last clotting factor to decrease in the bloodstream after warfarin administration because of its longer plasma t1/2 value than others.  

Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist and an oral anticoagulant that interferes with vitamin K-dependent clotting proteins, which include prothrombin (factor II) and factors VII, IX, and X. Warfarin also inhibits the synthesis of the vitamin K-dependent anticoagulant proteins, proteins C and S.

The half-life values for coagulation factors are factor VII - 6 hours, factor IX - 24 hours, factor X - 36 hours, and factor II - 50 hours. Due to the long half-life of factor II, the full antithrombotic effect of warfarin typically takes 4 to 5 days to achieve. Therefore, it's necessary to overlap warfarin with a rapidly acting parenteral anticoagulant, such as heparin, low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), or fondaparinux, for patients with thrombosis or those at high risk of developing thrombosis.

Other options

Option A: Factor Ⅶ has the shortest half-life. Hence, it is the first factor to fall after warfarin therapy.

Option C: Factor IX decreases after Factor Ⅶ. It contributes to the intrinsic pathway, so its fall affects APTT later.

Option D: Factor X falls after Factor IX, but not the slowest to decline.

questions.text: 184. A 63-year-old male patient with dyspepsia, weight loss, and melena is being evaluated with a barium upper gastrointestinal study. An outpouching with a smooth, deep ulcer crater is seen along the lesser gastric curvature and is diagnosed to be a benign gastric ulcer. Which of the following radiological feature is suggestive of a benign gastric ulcer?
questions.solution:
The radiological feature that is suggestive of a benign gastric ulcer is Hampton's line.

The Hampton's line is a thin millimetric radiolucent line seen at the neck of a gastric ulcer in barium studies, indicating its benign nature. It is caused by a thin line of mucosa overhanging the ulcer's crater. 

Other features of a benign ulcer include-

* Location on the lesser curvature

* Extends beyond the gastric wall

* Smooth ulcer mound - representative of edema

* Smooth folds reaching up to the edge of the ulcer

* Heals completely

Other options:

Option A: Hampton's hump is a radiologic sign associated with pulmonary embolism. It consists of a shallow wedge-shaped opacity in the periphery of the lung with its base against the pleural surface.



Option C: Carman meniscus sign is seen in malignant gastric ulcers and describes the lenticular shape of barium in the shallow/flat malignant ulcer, in which the inner margin is convex toward the lumen (benign ulcers are concave towards the lumen). Other features of malignant ulcers include irregular ulcer base, nodular mound, and thickened, interrupted, and fused folds around the ulcer.

Option D: Ram’s horn sign is seen in Crohn’s disease of the stomach leading to deformity of the antrum with a tubular shape, conical narrowing, and limited distensibility of the stomach, resembling the shape of a horn.

questions.text: 185. A 70-year-old woman presents to your PHC with shortness of breath for 2 weeks. Preliminary history and examination are suggestive of mitral stenosis secondary to valvular calcification. Which of the following X-ray views can best visualise this change?
questions.solution:
In case of mitral stenosis, a calcified mitral valve is best visualised in the lateral view of chest X-ray.

Mitral stenosis is a narrowing of the mitral valve orifice, most commonly caused by rheumatic heart disease. It can also be caused due to age-related degenerative calcification of the valve leaflets and annulus. Progressive calcification leads to reduced valve mobility, obstruction to left ventricular inflow, and symptoms of pulmonary congestion and dyspnea.

Mitral annular calcification is best visualised on the lateral view of a chest X-ray. It may also be observed on a penetrated (high-intensity) PA projection, but less distinctly. On the lateral view, it appears as dense, curvilinear opacities outlining the mitral valve ring, located near the posteroinferior aspect of the heart, as shown in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: PA is the most standard view for chest X-ray. It provides an accurate estimate of heart size and demonstrates cardiac borders, useful for identifying chamber enlargement. The earliest change in mitral stenosis, straightening of the upper left cardiac border, is seen in this view.

Option B: AP view is usually taken when the patient cannot stand upright. In this view, the heart appears magnified due to beam divergence. The diagnostic utility of this view is limited.

Option D: A Lordotic view is obtained with the patient leaning backwards (~15°), allowing X-rays to pass upward through the apices. It is useful for evaluating lung apices but is not employed for cardiac assessment.

questions.text: 186. A person died by hanging himself. He was found sitting on a stool with a rope tied around his neck. The knot is found tied below the occiput. Which of the following options best describes the type of hanging seen in this case?
questions.solution:
This scenario best describes the partial and typical type of hanging.

Hanging (self-suspension) is a type of asphyxial death that results from suspending the body by a ligature around the neck. Based on suspension, hanging is classified into:

* Complete hanging: Here, the weight of the entire body acts as a constricting force

* Partial hanging: Here, the body is partially suspended; the weight of the head (5-6 kgs), arms, and chest acts as a constricting force

Based on the knot position, hanging is classified into:

* Typical Hanging: Knot is placed in the back of the neck below the occiput

* Atypical Hanging: Knot is placed anywhere other than the occiput

questions.text: 187. A pregnant woman at her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following are likely to be seen physiologically?

choices.text: Increase in 1, 2, and 7; no change in 3, 5 and 6
Increase in 1, 2 and 4; no change in 3, 5 and 7
Increase in 1 and 7; no change in 2 and 4
Increase in 3, 5 and 6; no change in 1 and 2

questions.text: 188. A young woman presented with ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her left eye for 10 days. She explains that her symptoms started after she had slept without removing her contact lenses. Her left eye is shown in the image below. Intra-ocular pressure is normal in both eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows localized bulging of the cornea surrounded by a white cicatricial ring suggestive of descemetocele. 

Descemetocele (Keratocele) is a localized bulge of Descemet's membrane. Patients with regular use of contact lenses are at higher risk of developing keratitis. Infections from organisms like pneumococci, pseudomonas, and other septic organisms destroy all the layers of the cornea except for Descemet's membrane. However, this membrane alone is not able to support the intraocular pressure and therefore herniates.

Patients will complain of pain, photophobia, and blurred vision. The bulging membrane may persist, surrounded by a white cicatricial ring, or may rupture. It presents with severe pain and is a sign of impending perforation.



Other options:

Option A: A Healed corneal ulcer will have a visual impairment and irregular opacity on the cornea.

The image below shows a healed corneal ulcer.



Option C: In perforated corneal ulcers, patients complain of a sudden gushing of hot fluid out of the eyes. Following this pain suddenly reduces. On examination, there is corneal opacity, prolapse of the iris, anterior dislocation of the lens, and reduced intraocular pressure.

Option D: Mooren's ulcer is a superficial ulcer that may occur due to autoimmune diseases. It starts as patches of grey infiltrate at the corneal margin. The ulcer then progresses to the whole of the cornea.

The image below shows Mooren's ulcer in the periphery of the cornea.

questions.text: 189. A child with repetitive blinking of the eyelids and staring blankly most of the time in the classroom, is brought to the hospital. The doctor suggests starting ethosuximide for treatment. What is the deadly adverse effect of the drug?
questions.solution:
The deadly side effect of ethosuximide, a T-type calcium channel blocker, is bone marrow suppression.

The given clinical vignette of repetitive blinking and staring is suggestive of typical absence seizures. Ethosuximide is the first-line drug for the treatment of typical absence seizures.

Ethosuximide reduces low-threshold T-type Ca²⁺ currents in thalamic neurons, which are crucial for generating the 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges seen in absence seizures. At therapeutic concentrations, it selectively inhibits these currents without affecting other neuronal firing properties or GABAergic transmission, thereby preventing the abnormal thalamic oscillations that produce absence seizures.

Ethosuximide's common dose-related side effects include gastrointestinal issues, with some cases leading to death from bone marrow depression, and other effects may include urticaria, skin reactions, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, and systemic lupus erythematosus. Though ethosuximide is not nephrotoxic, it is metabolized in the liver and in rare cases can lead to liver damage.

Typical absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness without a loss of postural control. There is typically no postictal confusion. Absence seizures are often rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude clonic movements of the hands. A common initial indication of absence epilepsy is often an unexplained tendency to "daydream" and a noticeable decline in school performance. The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a burst of generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges.

Other options

Option A: Hyponatremia is seen with antiepileptics like Carbamazepine.

Option C: Drugs like Valproate and Rufinamide can cause short QT syndrome.

Option D: Nephrotoxicity is seen with drugs like Phenytoin, Topiramate, Valproate, and Carbamazepine.

questions.text: 190. A 32-year-old woman with an obstetric score of G2P1, presented to the hospital at 37 weeks of gestation, with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain abdomen and vaginal bleeding. She has a past history of classical Cesarean section 3 years ago. A uterine scar rupture is suspected in this patient. All of the following findings indicate uterine scar rupture, except ______.

choices.text: Loss of station of presenting part

questions.solution:
Maternal tachycardia (not bradycardia) is a feature of uterine rupture.

Uterine rupture is one in which all the layers of the uterus (endometrium, myometrium, and serosa) are disrupted any time after 28 weeks of pregnancy.

A previous history of classical cesarean section, obstructed labor, manual removal of placenta, dilatation, and curettage are some risk factors for uterine scar rupture.

Clinical features of scar dehiscence:

* Maternal tachycardia

* Fetal bradycardia

* Maternal hypotension

* Uterine scar tenderness

* Bleeding per vagina

* Hematuria 

* Loss of station of presenting part

Management of uterine scar rupture includes resuscitation and laparotomy. Following resuscitative measures and laparotomy, subtotal hysterectomy is usually done unless there is sufficient reason to preserve the uterus.

Primary small cell lung carcinoma shows TTF-1 positivity and Napsin A negativity.

Small cell carcinoma of the lung is a neuroendocrine tumour that arises from Kulchitsky cells, the neuroendocrine progenitor cells of the bronchial epithelium. It is a highly malignant tumour strongly associated with cigarette smoking, and it typically originates from the major bronchi.

Histopathology of small cell lung carcinoma (given in the image below) shows clusters of small cells, which are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and a prominent nuclear moulding. These cells have scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The Azzopardi effect is characterised by basophilic staining of vascular walls resulting from the coating of DNA from necrotic tumour cells.



Neuroendocrine markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

* Chromogranin

* Synaptophysin

* CD56

Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) is a nuclear transcription factor that is expressed in tumours arising from the thyroid and lungs. TTF-1 positivity is associated with primary lung adenocarcinoma and neuroendocrine tumours that originate within the lungs or outside the lungs, including primary small cell lung carcinoma.

Napsin-A, an enzyme present in the cytoplasm of type II pneumocytes, is instrumental in the maturation of surfactant. Napsin-A positivity is associated with primary lung adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: 194. Which of the following enzymes is directly involved in a cataplerotic reaction that diverts a TCA intermediate for biosynthetic use?
questions.solution:
ATP Citrate lyase is directly involved in a cataplerotic reaction that diverts a TCA intermediate for biosynthetic use.

Cataplerosis refers to the removal of TCA cycle intermediates for biosynthetic functions. Glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) catalyzes the conversion of α-ketoglutarate to glutamate. This glutamate can then be used for the synthesis of other amino acids (via transamination), neurotransmitters like GABA, or purine and pyrimidine. Because this reaction withdraws α-ketoglutarate, a central TCA intermediate, it represents a true cataplerotic pathway.

Examples of such reactions are:

* Citrate is cleaved by ATP citrate lyase to yield acetyl-CoA, the precursor for fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis.

* Succinyl CoA combines with glycine in the presence of ALA synthase to begin porphyrin synthesis.

* Transamination of oxaloacetate to aspartate, which is used for the urea cycle, nucleotide synthesis, and other biosynthetic pathways.

Other options:

Option A: Pyruvate carboxylase catalyzes an anaplerotic reaction, replenishing oxaloacetate from pyruvate to maintain TCA cycle flux.

Option C: Citrate synthase combines oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to form citrate, committing substrates to the cycle but not removing intermediates.

Option D: α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase continues the oxidative decarboxylation of α-ketoglutarate within the cycle, not diverting it.

questions.text: 195. A 50-year-old man complains of cramp-like pain in his calf for a month which increases with a downhill walk and decreases with an uphill walk. Pain is relieved on sitting or forward bending. What is the cause of pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the characteristic features of neurogenic claudication, where the pain increases on the extension of the spine such as in walking downhill. It is relieved on sitting or forward flexion at the waist such as in an uphill walk.

It may be seen in cases of nerve compression from lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or spinal stenosis. Symptoms become most prominent when there is a reduction of the interlaminar space; this occurs with prolonged standing when the spine is in an erect position.

Claudication pain may be of different types and can be differentiated as follows:

* Vascular (intermittent) claudication pain is brought on by walking and is relieved by rest within 5 minutes. 

* Claudication pain present on taking the first step of walking is classical for osteoarthritis. (Option A)

* Neurogenic claudication occurs with changes in the position of the back such as bending forward and straightening. It takes more time to be relieved by rest (more than 5 minutes).

The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent claudication. It is usually felt in the calf when the superficial femoral artery is affected.

The distance that a patient is able to walk without pain or stopping is called claudication distance which varies only slightly from day to day. Such distance may even decrease further when the oxygen requirement of the muscles is increased as in cases like walking uphill, walking fast or carrying heavy weights.

Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery. Classically, the muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease.

Rest pain occurs when the occlusive disease progresses in severity and anaerobic respiration occurs even at rest. Though this pain is present during the day, it is exacerbated on lying down at night due to loss of gravity dependent perfusion of the foot. This may be relieved by hanging the foot out of the bed to restore the gravitational effects.

Intermittent claudication Neurogenic claudication Osteoarthritis
Pain after walking a certain distance Pain after walking or standing for some time Maximum pain on the first step.
Pain quickly relieved on resting. Pain relieved on flexion Pain relieved on resting.

questions.text: 196. A 40-year-old man is rushed to the emergency room with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting bluish green vomitus for the past 30 minutes. He reports a metallic taste in his mouth, and the lining of the oral mucosa also appears to be bluish. Poisoning with which of the following agents is most likely in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a person with bluish-green vomitus, metallic taste in the mouth, and bluish-tinged oral mucosa is suggestive of copper poisoning.

Copper poisoning is usually accidental. It can occur either by inhalation of fumes in industrial workers or copper welders or by ingestion of contaminated food cooked in improperly tinned utensils. 

Acute copper poisoning presents with symptoms like metallic taste, bluish-green vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, jaundice, renal failure, and blue discolouration of the mucosa that appears 15–30 minutes after ingestion. Urine may show casts, albumin, or blood. Severe cases can lead to shock, cramps, coma, and death. The following image shows copper sulphate, a common cause of copper poisoning:



Treatment of copper poisoning includes:

* Perform a stomach wash with warm water

* Egg albumin acts as an antidote by forming insoluble, non-toxic copper albuminate

* Gastric lavage with 1% potassium ferrocyanide solution can also be done; it forms cupric ferrocyanide, which is non-poisonous

* Administer Calcium EDTA or BAL (British Anti-Lewisite) as chelating agents

* Maintain fluid and electrolyte balance carefully

Other options:

Option A: In acute iron poisoning, within the first few hours, there is abdominal pain, and black or grey haemorrhagic vomitus and stools with a metallic odour. The vomitus is never bluish-green.

questions.text: 197. A patient underwent the following procedure for the management of portal hypertension. Which of the following is an early complication of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) procedure with the viatorr device. An early complication of the TIPS procedure is metabolic encephalopathy.

The main indication of TIPS is variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopic treatment and intractable ascites.

The shunts are inserted under local anesthesia, analgesia, and sedation, using fluoroscopic guidance and ultrasonography. A guidewire is inserted via the internal jugular vein and superior vena cava into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.

The major complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the main contraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.

Portal hypertension is defined by a portal pressure >5 mmHg.

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is a treatment option whereby a percutaneous connection is created within the liver, between the portal and systemic circulations, to reduce portal pressure in patients with complications related to portal hypertension.

Complications of TIPS procedure:

* Intraoperative complications- capsular hemorrhage

* Early complication- hepatic encephalopathy

* Late complication- recurrent variceal bleed

* Delayed complication- total shunt occlusion

Shunts for portal hypertension:

* Non-selective shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted

* Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)

* ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)

* Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)

* Selective shunt- only splenic blood is shunted

* Warren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)

* Inokuchi shunt

questions.text: 198. You suspect poisoning from a toxin derived from a plant, as shown below. Which of the following accurately describes the mechanism behind its toxicity?

choices.text: Acts on the voltage-gated Na⁺ channel
Acts on the voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels

questions.solution:
The image shows a plant of Aconitum. Aconite, derived from it, acts on the voltage-gated Na channels. 

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Aconitum napellus, also called Monk’s Hood. All parts of this plant are poisonous, but roots and tubers are the most potent. Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves and skeletal and smooth muscles. Aconitine binds with high affinity to the open state of the voltage-sensitive sodium channels, thereby causing a persistent activation of the sodium channels, which become refractory to excitation. 

The following symptoms are seen-

* Gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain, and diarrhea)

* Cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), and

* Neurological (vertigo and restlessness)

Ocular examination is characteristic of hippus (alternate dilation and contraction of pupils). Death occurs due to respiratory failure or ventricular fibrillation. There is no specific antidote for aconite, and treatment is supportive.

Other options:

Option A: Strychnine, derived from Strychnine nux vomica (image below), is a spinal poison that acts by blocking the action of glycine. It leads to spastic paralysis.



Option C: Voltage-gated calcium channels are acted upon and blocked by spider toxins such as ω-Aga IVA.

Option D: Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the release of ACh and leads to flaccid paralysis.

questions.text: 199. A 35-year-old male presents with an extensively pruritic lesion on his elbow, as shown below. Which of the following histopathological findings is typically associated with it?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis, with the image showing a psoriatic plaque with a silvery center surrounded by a reddish border. It is typically associated with elongation of rete ridges.

Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory dermatosis with an autoimmune basis affecting the skin, mostly extensor surfaces like elbows, knees, scalp, etc. The typical lesions are pink-salmon-colored plaques covered by loosely adherent silvery scales due to increased cell turnover.

The histopathological features of psoriasis includes:

* Irregular epidermal thickening (acanthosis)

* Hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis

* Suprapapillary thinning

* Clubbing and elongation of rete ridges at the base

* Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in the malpighian layer)

* Munro microabscesses (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)

* Absence of stratum granulosum

* Dilated, tortuous blood vessels in the dermis

* Suprapapillary mononuclear leukocytic infiltrates



Other options:

Option A: Suprabasal splitting is typically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris. Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins, desmogleins 1 and 3, expressed in the skin and mucosa. Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring.



Option B: Subepidermal splitting (as seen in the image below) is typically seen in Bullous Pemphigoid due to antibodies against BpAg-1 and BpAg-2 in hemidesmosomes. Patient presents with tense bullae over the trunk, abdomen, and flexural aspects of the extremities. It can also be seen in Dermatitis Herpetiformis, which is an autoimmune disease where the antibodies target epidermal transglutaminase-3, resulting in the collection of neutrophils at the dermal papilla.



Option D: Saw-toothed rete ridges are typically seen in Lichen Planus. A fully developed lichen planus papule also shows acanthosis of the epidermis, thickening of the granular layer, and hyperkeratosis. The image below shows the histopathological changes in lichen planus.

It is a fine, peripherally attached, and centrally detached scale at the edge of an inflammatory lesion. It is seen in pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: 200. The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

* Line A (Option A) depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)

* Line B (Option B) depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.

* Line D (Option D) depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.
